The movie based of the 1982 C.Ron Hobbard Scientology novel "Battlefield Earth" has to do with the aftermath of an alien invasion of the earth in which almost the entire human race was wiped out. Those humans still alive some 1,000 years after D-Day, when the invading Psychols defeated all the armies on earth back in the year 2000, are living in more or less cave man times being hunted down by the evil Psychols to do manual labor in their coal and gold mines.Jonnie, Barry Pepper, living in the caves with his fellow surviving humans in the Colorado Rockies decides to take off for civilization in the nearby destroyed city of Denver with him not knowing what's in store for him and his fellow humans that he later hooks up with. Running into a group of Psychols Jonnie & friends are quickly captured and inducted into the human, or man-animal, work gangs. The human work gangs do mining for gold in around the Boulder Colorado area by the Psychols who's head of security on earth is Terl, John Travolta, is in charge of.Terl who's being eaten up by the fact that he has to stay on earth forever by his boss, back on his home planet of Psychol, which makes him even meaner and more despicable then he already was. Were later given to understand that the sleazy Terl had a secret tryst with the boss' daughter that lead to him being banished to live out his last years on earth the worst, according to Terl, planet in the Milky Way Galaxy. Finding out from a satellite photo that there's a secret and large mother-load, or vein, of gold in the Rockies Terl plans together with his not too bright Psychol sidekick Kar,Forrest Whitaker, to get the gold mined and dug out by the captured human, or man-animals, and keep it for themselves without the Psychols big shots knowing a thing about it. Training Jonnie with this Psychol learning machine to mine the gold Terl doesn't realize that he's also teaching the illiterate human the history of freedom and democracy and the men and women who fought and died to attain it over the centuries. Jonnie is also thought how to fly USAF F-15's and F-16's combat planes and even detonate nuclear devices that in the end will do in both Terl and his fellow Psychols on earth as well as those on his home planet of Psychol.Outragous looking aliens with what looks like clothespins attached to their noses, as breathing aids, as they completely come apart from the determined attacks of the fearless and newly revived humans who almost overnight come alive with a fleet of fighter planes, that they got from the deserted US military base in Texas Ft Hood. The revolting humans also grab weapons from the fleeing Psychols as they not only defeat the hated and brutal aliens but, by teleporting a super nuclear device, knock out and totally destroy the aliens planet of Psychol as well.Both John Travolta and Forrest Whitaker look and act totally ridicules fighting and screwing with each other, like Cramdon & Norton in the TV comedy show the Honeymooners, over who'll end up as the big banana with the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. Travolta talks in such a strange and uncommon, for him, weird tone that I think that his voice was dubbed in by someone else. Whitaker is so blown up that he looks like he added, or filled himself up with, over 100 pounds for his role in the movie as as Ker.The battle scenes between the humans and Psychols are completely unbelievable with the humans lead by ace fighter pilot Robert the Fox, Richard Tyson, who just hours before didn't even know what a plane looked like much less being able to fly it. The Fox knocks out dozens of Psychol aircraft that are light years ahead, in combat ability, then his fleet of outdated flying jalopies that are over 1,000 old years old. Fox does all this without his fighter planes having being maintained during all that time, and yet somehow has their tanks filled up with jet fuel that hasn't been pumped out of the ground and refined for over ten centuries! The movie "Battlefield Earth" is only good for a few laughs and that's about all with nothing really making any sense and even the special effects, that were about the only things that could have possibly saved it, coming across as phony and primitive as if they were from a sci-fi flick made in the 1950's.

reviews.review_title: 'Robot Monster' for the new millennium: entertainingly awful
reviews.content: After a thousand years of suppression, a few remaining humans rebel against the Psychlos, evil entrepreneurs from outer-space. There is not much more I can add to the decades of derision that has been deservedly heaped on this canonical example of how not to make a big-budget science-fiction extravaganza. The plot is nonsensical, the script laughable, the cinematography vertiginous, and the acting borderline amateur at times. Star and Hollywood-powerhouse behind the film's creation John Travolta channels a rogue Vinnie Barbarino as the greedy hydrocephalic space-bully Terl and his snide, 'jocularly menacing' delivery is so clichéd as to be almost self-satirising. Forest Whittaker mugs it up as Terl's put upon deputy Ker and Berry Pepper is the paper-thin rebel leader Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (aka "Ratbrian"). The ludicrousness of the film's vision is apparent from the earliest frames, which see the ragged human survivors living like primordial savages in primitive villages, all with perfect teeth and most of whom look like they just stepped out of the make-up chair at a fashion show. Everything goes downhill from there until the show-stopping stupidity of the discovery of the seemingly everlasting cache of arms and jet fighters at what was Fort Hood (after a detour to Fort Knox, at which the last person to leave had forgotten to shut the vault). From this abyss, the film has nowhere to go but up, and the final battle and comeuppance to the miserably snide Psyclos is preposterous but fun to watch. Needless to say given the source material (a novel by Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard), the film's back-story is as interesting as the film itself. 'Battlefield Earth' is marginally more watchable than 1953's legendarily dumb 'Robot Monster', but at a cost: Travolta's salary was 625 times 'Robot Monster's' entire budget (100 times if corrected for inflation). Sometimes you don't get what you pay for but a least the more recent film's critical assassination didn't drive the director to attempt suicide.

reviews.review_title: Its so bad it made me laugh at points...
reviews.content: After seeing the Nostalgia Critic's 100th episode, in which he reviewed BattleField Earth, I didn't know what to think, and after a few months, curiosity got the better of me and I went in search of this film on the internet while I was home sick. And BOY oh BOY does this film suck. Everything about it sucks, the characters (who don't develop) the effects are crap, the story is confusing at points, the movie itself drags, the acting is a joke, and I kept finding myself pointing out stupid points as well as plot holes.I won't really talk about the story much but in a nutshell, earth has been ruled by an incredibly stupid race called Psychlos for one thousand years, and the humans (or Man animals as the psychlos call them) are in constant hiding from the psychlos and are on the verge of extinction, and the hero johnny tries to come up with a plan to take back earth. One of the psychlos called Terl is forced to stay on earth as chief of security for reasons unknown, and he wants to buy his way off earth by training the "man animals" to mine gold, because apparently gold is the rarest of all minerals.While the plot sounds simple, its hard to follow and full of plot holes.The psychlos are perhaps the DUMMBEST alien race known to man, they let the humans roam free to the point where they actually kill a couple of psychlos, Terl lets a machine teach Johnny all about the psychlos, all the psychlos underestimate the humans, and apparently the psychlos have so many health problems I keep asking myself how in the mother of God did these morons conquer ANY planet? Travolta (who plays Terl) I believe didn't try in the slightest to act in this movie, and he's the dumbass who's responsible for this movie! However, his role actually made me laugh at points, as well as a lot of the psychlos stupidity did. But the crappy trophy award for worst actor and character goes to Johnny (Pepper). This guy is easily the worst frigging actor I have ever seen! his character is unrealistic and psychotic and just unlikeable.Now The reason why I give this movie a star more than twilight or son of the mask is because this movie made me laugh and some of the action was some what enjoyable, but then again saying this movie is better than twilight or son of the mask is like saying it doesn't hurt being stabbed my this knife as much as it does with THIS knife. Bottom line, I WOULD say don't watch this movie, but I think in order to believe me you have to see it to believe it.

I suppose this was an attempt to turn an L Ron Humbug...I mean Hubbard novel into a science fiction movie. Besides the evil Scientologists, um, I mean Psyklos, being absurdly laughable (dreadlocks and moon boots), the entire film just didn't take itself seriously.There is so much potential in the story, but nothing was followed through, resulting in shallow, if any, plot, hollow characters who were merely caricatures, inept special effects and inane attempts at credibility.Every copy of this film should be returned to the studio where it should be burned and the ashes swept up and buried in a deep, abandoned salt mine.

reviews.review_title: This film has no scope. It can really only be enjoyed by hardcore science fiction fans.
reviews.content: The previews made this movie look so good! I guess most previews do, but Battlefield Earth was particularly disappointing. Most of the special effects and camera-work were fairly effective, and the character make-up was also very well-done, except for the tired concept of colored contact lenses. Those were getting old 1000 years before the film took place! You'd think a superior race such as the Psychlos would be able to come up with something a little more creative than that. Although the acting was all very good, it was a mistake to put John Travolta in this film. This is a complaint that I have about numerous films like this, John Travolta is just too well known to suddenly play such an intensely evil character as he did in this film. One of the main problems with this film comes mainly from discrepancies in the believability of the plot. (possible spoiler ahead!!) The one that jumps immediately to mind is the fact that the 'man-animals' managed to conquer a superior race like the Psychlos using primitive Harrier jets, which they learned to fly in a matter of days using a flight simulator which, along with the jets, they found to be in perfect working order after sitting for 1000 years!! The downfall of Battelfield Earth stems from this blatant disrespect for reality. True, this is characteristic of science fiction, but L. Ron Hubbard must realize that our current military is unable to build jets that could be left sitting until the year 3000 and still be made to work. You'd think at least the TIRES would have rotted away, if nothing else. Battlefield Earth is entertaining, but also ultimately disappointing.

reviews.review_title: I'm going to be nice and give it a 3 for trying.
reviews.content: ScreenJunkies threw this movie out there as one of the worst films ever made.. umm, maybe they're wrong? I mean, I am in no way a fan. But once the movie reached the halfway mark, I was zoning out. I can't even tell you the stupid plot devices the script had to come up with, all I remember is everything turning blue and then I started scrolling my phone. So yeah, the hype is real in that this movie is bad. These stupid aliens were so human acting, I can not understand why they didn't just make them human. It was a corny and goofy but ultimately nowhere near entertaining. Not much redeemable here.

I sometimes like bad films (The Avengers) I sometimes hate good films (Magnolia), but, in this case I hated a bad film. The film is inexcusable because any film with a good cast and large budget should at least be OK ,with both of these factors wasted and coupled with a appalling story and techinque and you have in short the worst film ever.

And to think I was excited about this movie coming out.When I left the theater, I was literally slackjawed by the ineptness I had witnessed. Then I went and read the book (yep, all 1100+ pages), and quite frankly I don't know how this colossus of sci-fi rambling got published. In the year 3000, humanity is on the brink of extinction by a race Bob Marley Klingons called Psychlos, who have come to Earth to economically exploit it. Our hero, Johnny Goodboy (Barry Pepper), leads a rebellion with still-operating Harriers and nuclear bombs. Go figure.John Travolta (Terl, the lead Psychlo) should be ashamed of himself for bringing this to the screen. And we should all be ashamed for watching it. Avoid like radiation-saturated breathe gas.1/10

Okay, so this movie isn't the greatest but I'm a scifi fan so it automatically leaps beyond other normal movies for me just because I think scifi/fantasy requires MORE imagination then most of your other types of movies..Pepper isn't awful and neither is Travolta/Whitaker but there not awesome either at the core I'd say this movie is missing most likely a creative script or just really good direction..This movie lacks some thing but I can't pinpoint exactly what it is.. words like excitement, caring for the characters etc. seems to narrow it down..A scan of the director's career shows nothing but bomb's since he first got started (big mistake choosing him then) the only redeeming movie he made based on IMDb was in 1982 called "The Sender" it's on my todo list to see as wellAny way let me point out what I like about this movie - Use of nuclear weapons (always peaks my interest) - Interesting some times technology like the transportation at the end and the device used to teach Johnny to be smart - A plot that likely could have been much better your typical Star Wars plot almost..I think my synopsis here is that the Director failed in the mission on this movie and since he has repeat failures here on record, (all the actors involved have proved there talent or a director has made them look good in other movies say Travolta/Whitaker in Phenomenon and Pepper in Snow Walker/Private Ryan etc.) I'd say he was a poor choice for the job.. Maybe the huge Budget on this movie went up the Director's nose

A cult classic before its time. Now match Battlefield Earth with the latest Disney corporate/Toys"R"Us sponsored regurgitated Star Wars 7-8-9-10-11 hairball and this sci-fi campy movie comes across as Gone with the Wind of space.Whatever it's not, its not forgettable, just sit back and enjoy the details & interesting back story . Travolta gives his smarmy best playing against Forest Whitaker as the dolt sidekick trying desperately to get off the boring apocalyptic planet Earth.First they must make enough profit to bribe the Psychlos home bureaucrats to issue a ticket home as a reward for enriching the oligarchy . Alien NWO capitalist mining Gold with human slave labor & despoiling the environment all at the same time. Picture the Psychlos as British Petroleum mining for oil in the Gulf of Mexico...that's a stretch but I understand where L. Ron Hubbard was coming from.Now the two are trying to do this without being issued a mining permit from the Psychlos home world and shipping the wealth home on the sly. To do this the two miscreants must use the human slaves as pawns(Iraq Wars) as mindless draft animals to pull of thus heist (Oil) but unbeknownst the human slaves will rebel with the help of hero Johnny Goodboy...campy but still interesting in the grand story that reflects are New World Order of today. Not many movies will tackle geopolitical scams & schemes of today wrapped around a campy Alien invasion Sci-fi story line, they usually go hardcore preachiness that defeats the message Only reason not to give this a Ten is the human hero is miscast, needed a stronger personality as Travolta & Whitaker carry the show . This movie should have been made in the 1980's by John Carpenter and it would have gone down as a classic. I think much of the hate is directed at Travolta , Scientology & parroted by the internet herd mentality and not the story. Everyone says it's bad so it must be so. Star Wars # must be great because everyone says so, no critic wants to say the whole franchise is garbage now because social/ media wont allow the honest truth without seeing the back-end of the unemployment line. Just as everyone has the cowardly Lion courage to troll Battlefield Earth ...it's an easy mark. A taste of junkfood Star Wars cinema leftovers is enough but you just might catch yourself watching B.E for the second or third time on antenna or Netflix for a late night snack.This is Mystery Science Theater 3000 material but in an odd way a enjoyable romp across time & space. A cross between Space Balls & Blade Runner .

reviews.review_title: This movie is unfairly rated...considering all Steven Segal movies rate higher
reviews.content: I saw this movie with no hope of seeing a decent flick considering all the tragic reviews I'd heard. I was very pleasantly surprised to find this movie is actually very entertaining as far as Hollywood action movies go. Good characters, good story and a fair dose of action. As per all Hollywood movies you just need to get your head around the unbelievable events that make the story work, usually things like people being in the right places at the right times and 1 in a billion coincidences etc that always seem to take place on the silver screen, in this movies case the adult primitive humans all seem to have a learning curve equal to Einstein to the power of 10. Lets face it, this movie is not reality but very very few action/sci-fi movies are if any. If you take into account that every single one of Steven Segals pathetic, predictable, nothing new, movies in this database rates higher than Battlefield Earth you must surely agree that this movie has been very unfairly rated.

reviews.review_title: OH MY GOSH!!!!!!!!! THIS MOVIE IS HORRIBLE!!!!!
reviews.content: This movie is AWFUL! If you want a good sci-fi movie, see Star Wars, or read the Battlefield Earth book. They could've checked the book before they made this movie! "Clinkos?" NO, CHINKOS! And Johnny just makes friends with the prisoners? No, they took out like half of the book when they made this. L. Ron Hubbard is probably spinning in his grave because of this movie!!!!!!! DO NOT WATCH THIS!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: THE WORST MOVIE OF ALL TIME!!!!!!!!!!!!
reviews.content: How does a movie like this even get made. The shots are all slanted at 45 degrees. the production design looks like crap, and the CGI is GOD AWFUL! John Travolta is WAY over the top in this movie. These aliens are supposed to be so advanced and smarter than us but they are all dumb ass'. One of the dumb scenes is the food scene. John Travolta wonders what food that human like the most. They assume that they like rats but the humans chose rats because they were starving. Honestly I could write so much for this but I want to keep it small. I do have to talk about the end where the aliens planet is blown up by one small bomb. Yeah the writing and story is that bad! Please stay away from this movie.

Just a few comments:The worst swear words that these outer space rastafarians can come up with is "craplousy?"Why is gold as precious on the planet "Psychlo" as on Earth?Why is Travolta's character so demeaning of the "man animals" that he cannot believe that they can learn to use a weapon, but when same "man animals" go and steal gold bars from Ft. Knox and present it as gold that they have smelted themselves, he believes it?How can Harrier jets run after 1,000 years of sitting and rusting, and how can they be flown by "man animals" who were illiterate days before, and managed to figure out how to fly a plane in two days?Even more important, what type of "yes" men did Travolta surround himself with who kept blowing sunshine up his rear, telling him that he was doing a good job?WHY AM I EVEN WASTING MY TIME WITH THIS DRIVEL? If you have HBO and are aspiring to get into the movie industry, watch this movie just to re-assure yourself that ANYONE can make a movie.

Directed by Roger Christian. Starring Barry Pepper, John Travolta, Forest Whitaker, Kim Coates, Sabine Karsenti, Richard Tyson, Michael MacRae, Kelly Preston. (PG-13)Bottom-of-the-barrel science fiction adventure catastrophe, based on the first half of L. Ron Hubbard's massive novel, is one of the more infamous failures in film history. Even the least discerning genre fans in the world could smell the stink coming off this one (and not just because everything looks so grungy and foul). Story about mankind fighting back against their enslaving alien overlords isn't an especially interesting one; required to sell it are well-utilized tropes, punchy dialogue and characterizations, visually exciting design and effects, and flashes of wit and excitement. Unfortunately, this film has none of those things (unless shooting about eighty-five percent of the movie at a Dutch angle is considered "visually exciting design"), with astounding lapses in logic and laughable performances to boot--either shapelessly generic (Pepper) or incalculably weird and over-the-top (Travolta). One of the worst-looking would-be blockbusters ever released, and not even that amusing to watch for purposes of ridicule because of how boring the whole thing is. Self-respecting man-animals should stay far, far away.5/100

reviews.review_title: I really Liked this Film. (This review contains Spoilers)
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is a film that cannot be taken seriously.  This film is one of my personal favorites.  I have fun whenever I watch the DVD.  Well the plot to this story is easy to follow.  The film takes place 1000 years into the future and we have been conquered by a race known as the Phyclos. The Phyclos reminded me of overgrown Ferengi from the Star Trek Spinoffs. They are only concerned with wealth and Power.  John Travolta does an excellent job as Teryl the Psyclo Chief of security, who hates being on Earth and desperately wants a transfer.  Well his superiors decide to leave him them permanently.  He then launches a plot to buy off his superiors by using humans (the lower species) to mine gold in a high radiation zone, which interferes with the Psyclos breathing gas.  Well he gives an earthling Psyclo knowledge so that he can operate complex Psyclo machinery which will have dire consequences in the end for the Psyclos.  Well This earthling named "Johnny" (portrayed by Barry Pepper) outsmarts the Psyclos by giving them gold from Fort Know (which still exits).  It was hilarious when Teryl finds the gold and wonders how these earthlings can smelt the gold into bricks.  During the time they are supposed to mine the gold they plan an attack from abandoned U.S bunkers.  Well enough with the plot.  I want to talk about how great this movie is.  First of all I loved the camera angles, there isn´t one straight shot in the whole film.  I also loved the effects and lighting.  Lastly I thought this film was highly amusing.  Watch Teryl and his assistant trying to get leverage over each other was quite amusing. I mean it was directed by Roger Christian, and designed by Patrick Tatopoulos who both worked on "Independence Day" and "Star Wars" Battlefield Earth shouldn't be taken seriously, though it isn´t my favorite Sci-Fi film I enjoyed this one very much, and I know I am in the minority. I can´t wait for the sequel.

I knew going into Battlefield Earth movie that it was going to be bad. I had read reviews comparing it to the worst of Ed Wood's science fiction. Reading this, I expected at least enough cheesy fun to sustain interest for roughly two hours. What I found instead was a nauseating, sleep inducing monument in the history of bad cinema. I can't help but feel pity for the poor ignorant fools who actually seemed to think they had a good movie on their hands. I have a hard time believing John Travolta will be able to regain a reputation after starring in a movie in which the logic behind characters' actions is even less balanced than the camera which is at a tilt on every shot. Mr. Travolta's character plans to find out what humans like to eat best by starving them to a point of desperation and seeing what they eat. Simply presenting this logic as something that anyone, especially someone who proves himself clever throughout the rest of the movie, would use is completely ridiculous. In their plan to save the world, the humans plan to collapse a dome made with glass and metal beams that covers the city, thereby letting in gas that is poisonous only to the Psychlos. What doesn't seem to pose any problems is the fact that huge steal beams will falls from the sky. But hey, it's the future. Steal beams fall only on bad guys and bad guys always belt out an evil cackle

reviews.review_title: Where is Mystery Science Theater 3000 when you need it?
reviews.content: This is without a doubt one of the worst movies I've ever seen, and I watch a lot of MST. John Travolta is an awesome actor, but none of his talent makes it on screen. The rest of the cast give forgettable and awful performances. And where's the plot? The whole movie is just one dull and pointless scene after the next. This movie was so poorly written. The special effects are the only entertaining thing in this movie and that's really not saying much. I can not believe the powers that be are considering a sequel and series. Didn't they see how badly this movie bombed at the box office?Don't ever see this movie and avoid it at all costs. Thumbs down.

As a published Science Fiction author, I went to this movie with some trepidation.  I loved the book, but could anybody turn it into a decent flick? You bet!  This was a terrific film and I enjoyed it tremendously.  All of the characters had backgrounds, and the aliens were here for an actual purpose, rather than the childish Star Wars nonsense of 'we're just doing this because we're evil. Ha-ha, so there.' The Special Effects were first rate, and the scriptwriter did a bang-up job of converting Hubbard's huge (1,100 page) novel to the silver screen.  With plenty of material in the novel left over for a sequel, or even two. Kudos to the cast and crew.  Well done!

I didn't think it was quite as bad as everyone who's bashing the film was making out. However, I definitely do not think that the film is as good as the Scientology cult shills are making out, either. If anything, I would describe this film as being hopeless in its mediocrity. It also makes me wonder how a man who wrote something this stupid could possibly have formed a new deathcult... oh wait, the Christian bible is even worse.Anyway, the plusses of the film are extremely simple. I went to this film wanting to be entertained, and apart from a few moments where the film drags, I was entertained. The leading lady was wonderful to look at. I'd repopulate the planet with her any time she asked me to, that's for certain. The special effects were nowhere near as bad as I was led to believe they were, either. Sure, they were patently unconvincing, but I didn't mind that at all.The bad points of this film? Well, the acting is attrocious, even from Travolta, which leads me to believe that the real problem was with the script rather than the actors. Instead of trying to verbatim copy a portion of the novel, it would have been more prudent to make an independent story of its own and, should that prove more successful, get a more talented writer to translate the actual novel to the screen. Then there's the Psychlos, who seemed to be about as menacing as a schoolteacher and about as frightening as a child abuser. No offence meant to other people who've been victims of either, but once you take away their weapons and technology, these guys would really have been as weak as a Catholic inquisitor without an army.Another low point of the film is that we are never given enough opportunity to form an attachment with any of the characters. Their dialogue is recited in a very contrite and false manner that prevents any connection, making it very hard to want to root for the cavemen. Firing at the week-long training in jump-jet flying is a bit weak... obviously they had to make some kind of shortcut like that in order to get the story moving ahead. Shooting at Terl's constant superiority pose is another weak move on the part of critics, as this is exactly what weak little bullies do in order to reassure themselves of their position. Trust me, I should know, having recently confronted one of the teachers of my boyhood and suddenly finding that I outweighed them by ninety pounds (not because I am fat, either). It's just a self-assuring pose, guys, it's actually a nice touch.All in all, I give this film two out of ten. It's entertaining both in spite of and because of its stupidity, and that's more than what I can say for such films as the Blair Witch Nazi Propaganda, which still makes me want to perpetrate violence upon the directors because I value my own freedom to think. Give it a shot expecting a patently stupid movie, and it might keep you laughing for a while.

reviews.review_title: Please read book before watching, genre movie
reviews.content: A classic sci-fi book made into film, the story is so multi-layered and long(around 1500 pages) it's impossible to have it make sense in an almost 2 hour film. If you enjoyed the book, it would definitely make way more sense. I gave it 8 stars as I really enjoyed it, it stayed true to the books storyline and included enough of the background to please fans of the book. I was actually surprised at how well done it was, despite all the negative reviews. A similar case would be "Dune" , I tried watching it without having read Frank Herberts classic book, and was quickly lost. Read the book and it and the film became among my all time favorites.

reviews.review_title: Lived up to my expectations...Bloody awful.
reviews.content: Any film that is based on a book written by someone who peddles religion (scientology) is on to a big loser from the start but i was determined to have an open mind about Battlefield Earth despite the reviews. There are many, many bad things about this film that i wont go into because i am sure the other reviews do that job but what what i will say is the first half hour is not that bad but from then on it rapidly descends into one of the most stupid films i have seen in a long ,long long.Just one example is that the humans attack the aliens by learning to fly Harrior Jump Jets!!!! John Travolta is interesting and irritating because he keeps using the same lines such as " This lousy planet" and "Rat brains". The only thing i can liken this movie to is a very poor episode of Babylon 5 or Star Trek but 3 times as long. Not the worst film i have ever seen but still it is still pants. 3 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: This movie doesn't deserve that low rating
reviews.content: Yes the story was kind of thin but a movie doesn't deserve that low rating because of that. The special effects are great and the acting was good too. I liked it, maybe because i love sci-fi movies, it wasn't the best sci-fi movie i have seen but its not the worst either. I gave it the rating 5 because i think it deserves that much, lower than that is just wrong. If you don't like sci-fi don't watch it.

reviews.review_title: The saga that could have been and was not
reviews.content: Crushed to the fullest by almost all the criticism existing on this planet, I have to make a song in favor of this movie and say that it is not even one of the worst films in history nor is it as bad as it looks.The film has no doubt that it has things that simply do not add up or are absurd or involuntarily comical, whether due to the "rasta" look of the aliens, a rather trite and unoriginal story, an excessive duration and a sometimes heavy rhythm or a very improvable soundtrack and many others.But on the other hand the film is quite curious and fun in its own way. The presence of John Travolta playing a stereotyped but charismatic villain who enjoys the best dialogues and moments of the film helps a lot to the quality of a film that is not so cumbersome and compares with many current "B or Z series jejitas. Asylum roll that populate so many video store shelves. This at least has some decent Fx, and I mean it, they are not as crappy as they say.The prota, Barry Peeper fulfills his role well. The typical sacrificed and noble hero who seeks the good and freedom of his race. It is not perfect but it is correct.And well, in what is already the direction, production design and such ... well, that is not a big deal but it is not the worst thing I have seen, it is a film that is entertaining and enjoyable if it is not It demands too much, and I don't know why a clearly commercial product should be demanded of anything that failed in large part because of the bad reputation of the Scientology Church, since the history of the film was written by its founder, Ron L Hubbard, and in large part because of the fierce specialized criticisms that circulated word of mouth that it was the worst film of the decade and that it was rubbish, these two factors greatly affected the film he intended, as he said in his advertising posters Become a saga.But I, who am neither a professional critic nor anything I say very clearly, is not the worst film in history, nor of the past decade.It is simply one more science fiction film, with its eccentricities, defects and also its good moments and peculiarities and that in my opinion, it does not deserve to be dilapidated more than other bodies that circulate around and that have even made it up to a film of worship.Thank you.

reviews.review_title: So many good names such a LOUSY movie
reviews.content: It is hard to remember a movie where there are so many well-known, talented actors and tech people have worked SO hard to produce such a major league piece of crud.  I guess Travolta and Whittaker must have needed a tax payment or some other MAJOR cash inflow. I like science fiction, I like to watch Travolta and Whittaker (who is fast becoming the true utility actor - throw any role at him and he'll do it well) but this "movie" could be a career stopper for lessor names.I can even enjoy BAD movies if they're at least consistent with the main script idea (Howard the Duck springs to mind - wonderful concept, silly execution, but a thoroughly enjoyable piece of fluff)  But THIS one, no way.But I hope the actors overcharged the producers - then at least SOMEONE would have gotten some enjoyment out of it.  I didn't.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as everyone thinks.
reviews.content: Before you believe all of the hype- give this movie a chance. It was never meant to be a serious Sci-Fi flick, nor was it filmed with any serious message or intent. It was mainly written as a fun, exciting, and sometimes humorous thrill-ride, and in that respect it is very appealing and delivers. Also, the special effects are terrific (look out for dizzying camera angles and overused scene fades.) Am I the only one who liked this movie?

reviews.review_title: This is a movie you ought to see.
reviews.content: This is an entertaining film. I have seen it three times and will buy it when it becomes available on DVD.I was an early critic of the film (before it was released) because I saw character names that were not in the book. A word about the book - I have read and reread this book a number of times over the last fifteen years and I think it is teriffic. So, when I saws character names, like Mara, that were not in the book, I got on my high horse and denounced the film, asserting that the producers were using the title and little else.So, let me ask you... How to you condense a book that is 1200 pages long to a two hour movie? Not very easily.I think they did a good job. John Travolta was great as Terl. I look forward to a sequel.Go see this movie - you will have a great time.

The titleline refers to the fact that I would rather spend the rest of my life in Colonel Kurtz's jungle camp, drinking my own pee every morning, than watch this movie ever again.START OF SPOILERS:It's stupid. No, it's beyond stupid. A "supreme race" called the "Psychlos" have conquered earth and are tyrannizing the last few human beings, who have fallen back into stone age culture. One of the humans is revolting. Therefore, Psychlo leader John Travolta (the horror! the horror!) puts him into his learning machine that teaches him all of Psychlo science and technology in a few minutes. (Bulls***, you say - that should make him even more dangerous, right? Wait till I'm finished).Travolta sends the cavemen to dig for gold in the mines. But instead they get the gold from Fort Knox, claiming they have molten it into bars(!) for the Psychlos' convenience. Instead of digging for gold, the cavemen break into an ancient military depot. After several thousand years, all the equipment is still working, all the aircraft is still fueled up, and the Psychlos are attacked with bombers and jets. Finally, one of the humans beams to their homeworld and blows it up with a nuclear bomb. Now, do you still think this learning machine thing was kind of stupid?:END OF SPOILERSExtremely moronic movies from Hollywood are nothing new (the indescribable "LXG" comes to mind), but normally they are not as expensive as "Battlefield Earth". There must have been some gross mismanagement here, because the movie looks decidedly low-budget, with really cheesy CGI effects that are clearly below the standard of TV shows like "Star Trek", let alone state-of-the-art sci-fi cinema. I could guess where all the money actually went, but I don't want to be sued by Scientology, so I won't do it. The cinematography is ridiculous: virtually every scene is shot from a tilted angle with a different color filter, and they keep changing the tilt of the camera from shot to shot. Must be nauseating when watched on a big screen, but perhaps less so than the mercilessly overacting John Travolta. There was an evil star shining on Forrest Whittaker when he agreed to appear in this impertinent mess.And how stupid must THEY think WE are?1/10

This sci-fi adventure based on L. Ron Hubbard's novel of the same name is bad, but not as abysmal as its reviews and the public backlash would lead one to believe.  Hubbard, of course, is the controversial author of `Dianetics' and the founder of the Church of Scientology of which John Travolta is a devotee.  The story is supposedly allegorical of the psychological imprisonment that human beings face.  The hero, Johnny Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper), is thought to be Hubbard as he saw himself, a savior of the human race from psychological bondage.  There is probably some truth to the charges that Travolta produced this film as a tribute to Hubbard to legitimize his name.  He reportedly staked $5 million of his own money to foot part of the $78 million budget.  Claims that it was intended to be a recruiting film for Scientology are probably overblown.  Though I have my own feelings about the danger of cults, I will confine my review to the film itself.The story started out with interesting possibilities.  An advanced alien race, with a preoccupation with accumulating wealth, invaded earth for its natural resources and pushed the human race to the brink of extinction. The humans were scattered and reverted to tribal behavior.  Their daily lives were guided by myth and religious superstition.  Humans that were found by the Psychlos were imprisoned and forced to work as slaves.  Johnny is a bright young man known as a `Greener' because he rejects accepted ways and is always looking for greener pastures.  He is captured by the Psychlos and he hatches a plot to defeat them to win the freedom of his newfound slave followers.To this point, the film is fairly solid.  It is tough to believe that established religions such as Christianity would have died out and that in 1000 years there would be no remnants of our technological advancement and no attempts to unite an underground resistance, but I'm always willing to give sci-fi a wider berth.  However, once inside the prison, each scene becomes less and less probable, until one is left rolling one's eyes in incredulity.  We have Stone Age mentality people learning to fly fighter jets in two weeks and flying gloriously into battle against an alien race that supposedly defeated the entire planet's defenses in nine minutes. Between flying lessons, they teach themselves how to rig a nuclear warhead, which they intend to transport to the Psychlos home planet to exterminate the entire race.  Not bad for a bunch of illiterates.The acting is the biggest minus in the film.  John Travolta is an inconsistent actor, who can often be brilliant, but is sometimes awful. His performance as Terl, the Pyschlo Chief of Security is probably the low point of his career.  It is as if he was trying to play Julius Caesar with Vinnie Barbarino's personality, turning the character into a pompous moron. Clearly, his passion for the project blinded him to how poor his performance was.  Barry Pepper proved that he is not ready for leading roles with a portrayal that could serve as a clinic on overacting.  Other than Forrest Whittaker, who provided the only thing even close to acting, the rest of the cast seemed to have been recruited from L.A. homeless shelters.Roger Christian, who has proven himself a talented Art Director, Set Director and Second Unit Director, took an enormous budget and made it look like a TV movie.  The best production credits go to the miniatures and special prop supervisors for the models of the ancient cities and the dome.This film was punished at the box office, grossing less than one-third of its enormous budget.  I rated this film a 4/10.  It had some interesting elements, a decent premise, and some good visual effects, but the acting was abominable and the screenplay was butchered.  For most, this is a film to avoid.

This is the epic movie of the year. Quality film making. I don't want to get ahead of myself but I think this is the movie of the millenium! Mind you, the millenium just started, but I have faith that film making will never surpass the greatness that is Travolta and his giant nose plugs.

reviews.review_title: This movie has bewildered me for another fifty cycles...with endless options for renewal!
reviews.content: I'm really confused as to how this movie came to be. It has a $44 million budget ($68 million in today's money) and major talent attached, but the mistakes are so amateur and in such high quantity, that this movie should be thrown in an incinerator and never be spoken of. But alas, it was released to theaters. This movie is really baffling more than anything because of the backstory. So, for that reason, I would recommend this movie ironically, but you should read about the production for this movie. It's really quite fascinating.

I thought the film was much worse than it turned out. It looked interesting. Why can't space travelling aliens be less sophisticated than the tech they use?I did like the effort clearly made to make everything about the aliens alien.It did take a lot of liberties what with cavemen using C20 weapons - from rifles to Harriers to some sort of atomic bomb used to destroy a planet - but as the whole film was very kids cartoonish anyway, why was it unreasonable not to expect these points to be taken with a pinch of salt.

This was the most fun I've had at the movies all year. Realize, this is not a totally serious movie. It's not the Matrix and it's not Star Wars. It's more like the Fifth Element.This movie captures the feel of the book quite well, including its blemishes. For example, there's no way that our civilization would be nearly so intact after 1000 years (but, as in the book, you shouldn't believe that 1000 years have really passed; try more like 200-250). There's no way a primitive "caveman" who is thrown into a fighter simulator can become a fighter ace in less than a week. Yeah, yeah. So what? Go with it.As for the stupidity / incompetence of the aliens... yes, realize that Earth is a backwater dumping ground for incompetents for the Psylocks. And yes, the actors use 20th century slang, but let that go, since we are hearing the "best translation" of their speech.To enjoy this movie you need massive suspension of disbelief, or the willingness to mock it. Since the movie laughs at itself, this shouldn't be as hard as it sounds. This movie succeeds on every level it was trying for, and ignores everything else, like realism. Just sit back and enjoy.

This Movie proves that some books are better left books and not big budget Hollywood Movies with big stars who's talents would be better left doing other things.To quote someone else "How did this stinkbomb ever get made"

I know a lot of viewers have found this movie bad, but frankly I find it much better than many of the latest Science Fiction movies - even those who have got rewards.Looking away from the obvious event, that makes no sense that you can find intact infrastructure, particular air craft after 1000, and a nuclear device that works!, then it is not too bad.What I like: Aliens here are not different from Humans. OK, they are bigger, stronger, breath some other kind of air and drink nasty stuff. BUT they do have the same nasty habits like humans, cheating, greed (gold, surprise!!), sex, and like to dominate others. Their political system seems to be as rotten as on earth.The Aliens laugh at each other when something goes bad, even when a human happen to kill one of the aliens. Hey, they are rotten inside, just like real bad people, so we do not have to feel sorry for them, when their planet is blown up.And I like that the greed make the responsible for the operation take a human to train him in their technology, to make more gold, which leads to his own downfall.IF the amount of years of repression had been less - and IF they had found a way to use the aliens aircraft's and tools to fight them, the scenes would be less hilarious.I have watched more times, and I always like when Aliens are as bad as human politicians :)

reviews.review_title: This movie was fantastic for a Travolta movie
reviews.content: This movie was a great Travolta movie. It had action, comedy, great special effects, and more comapred to other Travolta movies. It was entertaininf to watch for a Travolta movie. I gave this movie a great grade for a Travolta movie which was 1/10. Superb Travolta movie.

reviews.review_title: A Modern Day Classic: A True Pile of Awful
reviews.content: The movie is so stupid its almost offensive, but for some reason I can't stop bringing it up, even 7 years after its initial release.Where do I start? Well, I'll start with the obvious... The acting, dialog, story, and the cinematography is absolutely awful; some of the worse you'll see in a motion picture. The only good thing about Battlefield Earth are some of the ideas it explores (a new beginning for humanity after a great catastrophe), the special effects, sound effects, and some of the lighting.The director claimed he was going for a "comic book" feel in the DVD commentary, hence the massive plot holes and the 'drunk man leaning on a steep hill shooting style'. Sure... But even comic books have some degree of realism and story structure. Me thinks Roger Christian just sucks as a director.But even in the midst of this pile of awful I still find myself strangely drawn to this film. Maybe because I enjoy seeing car wrecks?

reviews.review_title: When Things Got Weird Again With Travolta
reviews.content: Franchise Pictures hit a major bump after relative success with the Bruce Willis vehicle The Whole Nine Yards with the wildly infamous Battlefield Earth, which was slammed by critics, went drastically over-budget due to the company's shady practises and marketing, and grossed only $29.7 million at the box office out of an overall $73 million budget. Franchise's later lawsuit, which would bankrupt them, were over accusations of purposely inflating this film's budget.Described by Travolta himself as the Schindler's List of science-fiction films, Battlefield Earth's long and outright hilarious production history basically boils down to despite what everyone thinks, most people in Hollywood considering Scientologists to be a bunch of freaks, and what's worse, not a viable intellectual property, and therefore no major studio, in their right mind, ever producing something akin to propaganda for the cult.Luckily for Travolta, who had just failed to convince Quentin Tarantino to direct the film, that Franchise pictures was neither a major studio or indeed in their right mind as they had possibly scammed some German investors with a package deal in order to finance what finally became the Roger Christian directed and the too many re-drafts to credit written Battlefield Earth for the new millennium.Now, given the Scientology rub and Travolta's fanatic zeal during the marketing campaign, it's easy to see why critics at the time saw this as a gross and highly ill advised vanity project, cause it is, and therefore see the film itself as a poorly produced, wonderfully acted, exceptionally cheap looking dumpster fire, cause it is.However, accusations of the film being dull are only warranted if you are looking for a serious film experience here, which twenty million memes later would be beyond expectation.The film can be only judged realistically in 2020 by how hilarious it is as that's where it's entertainment value has now been reported to lay.Well let's run it down. The CGI is cheap as balls, the matte paintings are twenty years out of date, the dutch angles and colour filters are really that awkward and the acting is the most genuinely entertaining aspect of the entire movie. Travolta was, and still is, a true believer in this production and that's wholly evident as he leaves everything on the frame and nothing for his self-respect. Combine his ridiculous makeup and graduate level, or Marlon Brando level, British accent and you have a truly absurd, truly camp presence that is a gift to us all.OK. screenplay. Terrible. Most novel adaptations run the risk of having dialogue sound overwrought and completely terrible and let me tell you boi about this L N***e Hubburd. Featured in Battlefield Earth is the distinctively American combination of bull**** pseudoscience and exceptionalism and such is born a British colony uprising framed within the post civil rights, Pre Reagan self-help mysticism of the late seventies. In short, it's truly special, and uninspired and i expected nothing more from the Hubbard.Battlefield Earth is camp as all hell. It is cheap, it is at times meandering and whilst meme worthy in short bursts, the overwhelming mediocrity of the special effects and the storytelling make it a near unwatchable film to sit through from bell to bell as it struggles hard to maintain your attention. Maybe not for a solo watching. But I'm guarandamnnteed certain that at the right party with the right people, this **** be lit.

It's ironic that after MST3K was cancelled, two movies that would be perfect for classic episodes came out - "Mission To Mars" and "Battlefield Earth", which is bad on a "Manos: The Hands of Fate" level.  I'm not kidding - this is the kind of bad movie that made me laugh harder than any movie since "South Park".First, you have John Travolta.  He looks like a refugee from GWAR, Beavis and Butthead's favorite band, and his intelligence in this film remind me less of a rapacious corporate raider, like I suppose Hubbard intended, and more like Torgo, the disgusting "monster" in "Manos".  After this movie, I wouldn't be surprised if John Travolta were drummed out of Scientology.Forrest Whittaker needs to fire his agent.  He's a great actor who is completely out of place in this movie.  Maybe he owed Travolta a favor, I don't know...As for the plot... embarrassingly enough, I actually read the whole book back in 3rd grade, in my devouring-anything-remotely-sci-fi phase.  Even then, I thought Hubbard wasn't a great writer.  After thumbing through it recently, it struck me that it read like William Gibson crossed with William S. Burroughs... of course, this would be after both had received  lobotomies and lost all language ability.  Having said that, the movie is far, far worse.  What was the deal with the camera angles and editing?  My God, it reminded me of a unholy mating of "Batman and Robin" and "Plan 9 from Outer Space".The plot was laugh-out-loud ridiculous, and more than a few moviegoers did just that - laugh out loud through the whole film.  Okay, now, explain this - these morons (the Psychlos - yeah, I laughed too when I heard the name.) conquer the entire planet in 9 minutes.  Now, some unhygenic cavemen from Colorado learn how to fly Harrier jets (Harrier?  even knowing as little as I do about military aviation, I know that they're basically just ground-attack jets, and not exactly cream-of-the-crop in reliability) and destroy not only the vastly superior aliens on earth, but their entire planet????  Huh?  And let's not even mention the morality of that - basically, we're expected to cheer that these cavemen just committed a horrible act of mass murder against billions of sentient beings.  Whoopee.... but I only thought about that after the movie.  I was too busy playing Mystery Science Theater 3000 with some people during it.Ed Wood must be smiling down from heaven when he sees the horror that John Travolta has unleashed upon the world...

reviews.review_title: Same kind of disaster as Dune.
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth - the book - is the same kind of literary masterpiece as Dune.Battlefield Earth - the movie - is the same kind of cinematic disaster as Dune.I honestly think that as good a job was done as COULD be done, but I feel the same way about Dune.  Even limiting the movie to the 1/2 half of he book, there's just too much story, too much character development, too much of everything to fit into a single movie.  It could have made a great mini-series, I suppose, but who knows?

reviews.review_title: Barry Pepper vs. the Bob Marley-monsters
reviews.content: Well, "Battlefield Earth" is not the worst movie ever made as it is often said - what it doesn´t make a good film! It seems as John Travolta´s guru L. Ron Hubbard had crossed the stories of "Planet of the Apes" and "Independence Day". The set decoration of this film is sometimes frightening cheap (although the budget was about 100 million dollar(?)) and the plot has more holes than a Swiss cheese. The only enjoyable moments come from a few quite well directed dramatic parts the same as good performances of John Travolta as villain, Forest Whitaker as his dumb odd-job man and Barry Pepper as rebel, looking like a heavy metal-freak. "Battlefield Earth" is a totally overhyped movie, but it´s not worth to be mentioned. Together with some friends I watched this film and Ed Wood´s "Plan 9 from outer space" as a double feature. "Plan 9" was better...3/10

reviews.review_title: I am still trying to find the words to tell how bad this movie was...
reviews.content: We went to see this movie with an open mind,wanting to be entertained and but what a bad film it was!!  My husband slept after about 45 minutes.  How could John Travolta do such a pitiful movie? It must be the Scientology connection... I did find a review that I heartily agree with: "Rita Kempley of the Washington Post pushes the envelope in denouncing the film: 'A million monkeys with a million crayons would be hard-pressed in a million years to create anything as cretinous as Battlefield Earth,' she writes."

reviews.review_title: An endless barrage of Dutch angles and plot holes
reviews.content: Don't let my rating fool you, battlefield earth is must see classic as it is one of the greatest comedies ever made, unintentionally so. This film is now so infamously terrible that it has since become a classic of the bad movie landscape. Where to begin with this, well first off John Travolta redefines "acting" with one of the most bizarrely awful performances caught on camera. Imagine Tim Currys Dr Frank n further only 10 times as camp and actually meant to be taken seriously. His awkwardly forced evil laugh and constantly flailing of the arms will leave you rolling in the aisles. None of the other performances fair any better, Barry Pepper is as wooden as tree and Forest Whitaker mumbles in a confused fashion as he wonders how his career stooped to this low. Cap this off with an incomprehensible plot, tacky sets and costumes, camera work so bad you'll get a cramp in the neck and surreal editing and bam! Battlefield Earth a masterpiece of schlock.

reviews.review_title: AV-8B Harriers with Cro Magnon pilots
reviews.content: (spoiler included)I've seen a lot worse films than this one, so the criticism has been somewhat unfair - but it is still a terribly bad movie. It is badly shot, over ambitious, symbolic to the point of breaking and has a story that is incoherent, inconsequential and weak. Not even the special effects were anything out of the ordinary, it just looked a lot like Independence Day but fuzzier, dimmer and harder to follow. Near the end, two really weird logic leaps are taken: the humans have degenerated to Cro Magnon (with first and last names!), but it takes them just a week to go from wooden spears to AV-8B Harrier jets (that function perfectly after a thousand years of unuse). When the dome is finally destroyed and falls down, it's enough for the humans to lie down on the ground to survive - but the debris hits all the psychlos standing up. Hmmm... Several other questions arise: if gold is valuable to psychlos as well, isn't it strange that they haven't scavenged the Earth for this precious metal once they learned that humans also favored gold? It wouldn't be too great an effort to realize that there must be gold deposits here and there, and from there to assume that Fort Knox and such places would be empty before long isn't too difficult. And what of the nuclear weapons (that can blow up an entire planet) that are still lying around waiting for someone to use. If Jonnie took all his knowledge from the psychlo learning machine, it's safe to assume that the psychlos know about the effects of nuclear weapons and would at some point taken a detailed look at the human arsenal (because Jonnie suddenly knows how to arm a device). They just left it at that? I don't get it.But there's another, a lot more serious hole in this story: Travolta's evil psychlo character, Terl, states that it took the psychlos 9 minutes to conquer Earth, and that all the knowledge the human race had couldn't help them - so Jonnie Tyler can't expect to beat the psychlos. And yet he and a band of degenerated cavemen topple the psychlo reign in just a week, using almost exclusively human technology. They learn to fly Harriers so well that not only do they not crash - they actually gain air superiority over a species that conquered the fairly advanced human race in 9 minutes. Whoa! That's really something.Another question that pops in to my head is this: if the psychlos were to conquer the Earth in 9 minutes, that would mean that they are a helluva lot more advanced than us - I mean, taking over a planet in nine minutes is basically landing and just claiming it. But I see nothing that points to the fact that they should have been thousands of years ahead of us - ray guns and the giant dome doesn't impress me, and spacecraft that can be downed with a sidewinder missile - pfft! Naahhh... to make a positive impression on me, this film would have had to be reworked so fundamentally, there would be no point in it having the same title as L. Ron Hubbard's novel in the first place. I expect a reasonable amount of logic, even in a movie such as this. As it is, "Waterworld" is more intelligent - and infinitely more entertaining.

It's not the best movie in the world, but the sphere is alright in this stylish science-fiction. Just a bit of fighting spirit, freaky human-like aliens, dark good-looking surroundings, few bad scenes though, but a good movie for renting. I gave it a 6.5!

reviews.review_title: NOT a scientology movie... Just a great sci-fi movie.
reviews.content: This was a great sci-fi movie. Terl and Johnny's characters were as close to their book counterparts as possible.  Terl was just as arrogant and evil as he was in the book, which was superb fun to see onscreen.  Sure.. The book was better, but books are always better.  There were some parts of this movie that you REALLY had to suspend disbelief for (like the whole Harrier jet stuff), but hey... It's a movie.  As for the tilted camera angles, I liked them. Also, the lighting was extremely well done.  When the movie was showing an area that had breathe gas in the atmosphere there was a blue-ish hue all around, but when there was air in the atmosphere the movie used orange-ish hues. There were also many other things that made this movie stand out.  I give this movie a 9 out of 10.  (I minus one for the Harrier jet stuff.)By the way, I'm NOT a scientologist... I'm just a big fan of Sci-Fi movies.

This movie was *slated*.Travolta's reputation took a pounding and it was regarded as an overblown flop in the mould of Waterworld.But having viewed it myself it's not actually all that bad at all. By no means is it great, but it's certainly no worse than the 'mainstream' high budget popcorn munchers such as Jurassic Park and Independence Day that Hollywood throws out.It's based on an epic novel which is seen as one of the great sci-fi novels. Now I have not read this book so I can only judge this movie on its own merits rather than as an adaptation, but it really is quite watchable.It's not the best movie I've ever seen, but by no means is it as dire as the critics would have you believe.I stuck the video on thinking it was going to be laugheably bad and that I'd want to kill it half-way through, but, no, it warranted watching.The performances are fairly staple, and some of the dialogue less than inspiring, but if you ignore the bad press and just watch it on its own merits you may get a kick out of it. I did.

And if I was Travolta I'd hope the dog would bury it. The movie was boring, lifeless and needed someone to turn up the contrast.  Come on guys, throwing the down-trodden humans into one week of simulator training and suddenly they master piloting Harrier jump jets?  If the aliens kicked earths collective militaries butt's in 9 hours where these super effective Harriers hiding?  Maybe I missed something when I went to the lobby to look at ads for upcoming movies.  What  keeps powering all the equipment?  Must be something to do with scientology.  Thank heavens the popcorn was above average the day this movie stood still.

reviews.review_title: Can I have my two hours back?
reviews.content: I sneaked into this film after watching U-571.  I'm glad I didn't pay to see it.  In fact, if it were possible to ask for my lost time to be cheerfully refunded, I would.  It plays like a dumbed-down version of a Battlestar Galactica episode, except with better modelmaking, less plot and character development, and a lot more violence, most of it gratuitous.  Travolta's character feels like someone lifted a cackling villain from the very worst of the Roger Moore period James Bond films, gave him a ray gun and a Klingon costume, and told him to play for laughs.  I suppose we have him to blame for this - without his name on the credits, this would have gone directly to video, which is still a waste of tape, but at least not a waste of $8 for the average moviegoer.  On a scale of one to five, or on ANY scale, really, the needle doesn't even twitch.

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the worst movie ever....
reviews.content: I'll be straightforward. This movie was horrible. The plot was weak and overused. The writing was like that of a mentally damaged 3 year old. The camera was tilted at an angle, and it was almost all in blue and black or green and black, reminding one even more of seasickness than the movie itself. The psychlos are terrible, sort of a homeless (dirty)-rostafarian (dreadlocks)-conehead (coneheaded)-Klingon (take a guess, stupid)-kiss costume wearing (stage platform boots about 3 feet high)-Rob Zombie impersonator(they really do look like Rob)- with a HUGE package (I mean, seriously, they must have modeled them after horse penises, they're the only intimidating thing about the aliens).  There are more plot holes than actual plot, and they're usually pretty obvious. These aliens are supposed to rule the universe, but they aren't quite as smart as  a below-average rock. Also, there were blatant, badly done, rip-off's of scenes in other movies, noticably, the 'lobby scene' in "the Matrix", and the 'death star trench scene' from "Star Wars". This made the whole movie ludicrous and just plain stupid.However, this movie did have several good points. One, the end. This was probably the best part of the movie. Not that the ending to the movie was any better filmed/acted/written, but that it was good when the movie ended. Also, though it was unintentional, the movie was hilarious. If it had been billed as a comedy, it would have been somewhere approaching first-rate. I rarely stopped laughing, except to point out what NEW idiocy was on screen. Well, that's about it for the good.Finally, I recommend seeing it once, and on the big screen, but preferably not in theaters. Wait until it's on video, then show it on one of those small projectors. After all, we don't want to give these morons the idea we actually liked it.

Im a huge fan of this movie. Its really fun to watch, and i say that as an intelligent person having scored a really high IQ, speaking 8 languages, having a PhD in medicine.Critics hate this movie for some reason. Sure i understand that some part are truly badly executed, like the scene where group is taken out for mining tests, where some cavemen attack, and like in 20 seconds after a short speech, the pledge their life to a man, a leader that the just met and they will obey everything he wants. Also its really fun when they find a nuclear bomb and open it up after 1000 years and its operational and they fiddle with the trigger and the bomb is making all kinds of warning noises. Really nukes do that didn't you know. Also amazing that they had electricity after 1000 years in that building, and of course the Harriers, a marvel of human engeneering, lasting a 1000years with filled tanks.Yes some loopholes in the plot but the acting from Mr Travolta is amazing, and of course his co-partner in crime Mr Whitaker, one of my absolutely favorite black actors does an superamazing job in this movie.The aliens are surely somewhat Klingon-looking but i think there are quite drastic differences. They are much smarter than Klingons and highly profitminded, and much funnier walking. I truly enjoy their hunt for profit since it very much resembles human hunt for profit. My own observations of todays world is that profit nowadays conquers altruism and true philanthrophy.One really fun plothole that i think everyone else has missed it that leader is taught maths from a completely different extraterrestial life form but the math is having earth symbols and number format from 1 to 10. Fun. And B. But i have watched this movie several times and loving it every time.

I honestly don't understand how so many thing could go wrong with one movie. The lackluster cast could have put on a decent film, especially with the help of the experienced and under-recognized supporting actor Barry Pepper. After a triumph in a supporting role in Saving Private Ryan, he takes on a goofy character in this film. Travolta is just too old and recognizable to be an alien. He should just stick to playing the shallow villain in budget action movies.As for the actual content of the film, it would have been better had they made it less Sci-Fi and more like a dark action-drama. Deeper meaning would have been nice here. As for the special effects, they were just unnecessary. Maybe they should have taken that money and put some into hiring a capable director and a competent cinematographer.As it stands now, this is just a weak film to be re-run every once in a while for those geeks who just can't get enough of looking at things flying about with little purpose.

better stay away from this movie. I went to see it because of John Travolta and I've never seen a bad Travolta film... until now.  Improbable, bleak and basically bad.  The plot didn't make sense - the make-up was so unimpressive... I was very disappointed that I'd spent the $6.50 and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

reviews.review_title: It is so bad that it is almost good
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is one of the most infamous films of all time. Battlefield Earth was intended to be a big box office blockbuster for the summer of 2000. Obviously, it was not. Battlefield Earth was PANNED by literally everyone and is often considered one of the worst films of all time. Do I think so? Well..... more on that later. Battlefield Earth is based off of the novel of the same name which was written by L. Ron Hubbard who is the founder of scientology. Even I don't even know what scientoloy is and personally I could care less. After the book was released, the author wanted a film adaptation to be made. Well, John Travolta was a scientologist and for years and years has been wanting to do this film. So this film was a passion project. The film had lots of merchandise and was really hyped up but upon release, failed. The film is directed by Roger Christian who has not directed anything really notable (besides this film) but has worked as Set Director for the Star Wars films. The film stars John Travolta (who also produced this film), Barry Pepper (Saving Private Ryan and The Green Mile), and Forest Whittaker.The evil aliens known as the Psychlos invaded Earth 1000 years ago and now in the year 3000, humans are endangered. Basically, human hero gets captured and eventually makes an attempt in defeating the Psychlos who are looking for gold on Earth and whatnot.For years I have avoided this film because why would I want to torture myself and watch a film with this much negative reception? When it came to watching this film, I decided to just turn my brain off for once and not view this film under a critical lense. I will admit that it was hard to do (with the obvious flaws being very....well.....obvious). With that being said, I do not think that Battlefield Earth is the worst film of all time. Yes, it is a bad film but not a bad enough film to make me wish that I have never watched it. It is bad in an interesting sort of way. I am entertained by how bad it is. So, the obvious negatives. The camera work is really really bad. Everything (or a very very large majority) of the shots are shot at an angle. Why? No clue. It is just very very strange. The story and script are just as equally bad with plot holes and what not. There is no build up to anything in this film and stuff just kind of happens. The Psychlos are very dumb in this film and the whole plot is just really dumb and in itself. Now, that is where most of my negativity ends. Everything else about this film, while does not make for a really good film, makes for an entertaining sort of film. Well, somewhat entertaining. The acting is not great overall and would not typically be classified as good. John Travolta gives a really over the top performance but I am somewhat entertained by it. Barry Pepper as our hero, while not a good hero due to not being written very well, appears to be trying really hard with what he has been given. The special effects themselves range from mediocre to well...... that did not age well. The practical makeup effects are pretty neat despite the Psychlos looking butt ugly. The whole color scheme of blue and gray does not really bother me whatsoever. The music for the film is not bad which is strange because I do personally think that everyone who watched this film decided that this is the worst film ever and critiqued everything like the music without giving it a listen. Sure, it is pretty standard but if I am to think of anything in this film that is not terrible, this would be it.Battlefield Earth is not the worst film of all time. Far from it. Sure, for a big budget film it really blows. When it comes to the big flaws, it is really bad. Had it had a better script and story, I think the film would have been much better.

reviews.review_title: Except for the script I'd probably have enjoyed this movie...
reviews.content: The acting was good.  The special effects were well done, worth seeing. The plot was OK (not very original).  The dialogue was AWFUL.I never read the novel but after seeing the movie and hearing the awful lines I DO want to read it--only because I can't believe that this dialogue was in a best selling novel.I believe that with a more intelligent script this movie would have been enjoyable.  I gave it 2/10.

What's the point?  But I must.Everyone else who has ripped on this movie has already done so eloquently. I just wanted to add my voice.This movie sucks on deep, deep levels; on every level of film-making possible.  It's not even fun to laugh at. (But that's mainly because the Scientologists were watching me in the theater and they were scribbling my name in their files so they could either convert me or crush me.)But seriously, people who hated this movie, are you with me? Do you ever wonder if people who are making movies like this, the really bad ones, like Leonard Pt. 6 or The Haunting (although I think this is the worst of the bunch), have moments on the set where they look around and think 'Oh my God, I'm involved in a huge bomb!'Do you think Travolta ever went home and said 'I don't know, honey, when I'm on the set and I'm in those KISS boots I'm feeling pretty good, but then I look over at Forest Whitaker and I think 'He looks like a cute, fluffy dog. He doesn't look like a bad alien', and then I get kind of scared.  But at least he's fatter than me.'Really, it's pointless to mention, but the F/X in this movie are soooooooo bad. The laser blasts look like they're right out of a late seventies/early eighties television show.  Except it's 2000, so it's not kitschy.
Yawn. Weep.

reviews.review_title: Where are Mike and the Bots?
reviews.content: MST3K ended too soon this turkey just may knock "Manos the Hands of Fate" out of the running for the worst movie of the century a true Turkey of Turkeys.This movie may someday become mildly amusing for making wisecracks at but only if you do not pay to see it. Avoid at all Costs!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: aw come on guys, I mean it IS terrible but... it's funny!
reviews.content: And what makes it funnier is they're trying to be serious. Ham acting, bad makeup, 1999 goth boots, dreadlocked aliens *or are they really klingons(tm)? I liked it. I kept watching it hoping it was going to get better but it just got crazier and funnier as it went. It would have probably rocked the box office in 1979. Please do watch it. There are worse films, e.g. Attack of the killer tomatos.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, saw the movie, both stunk.
reviews.content: The only fanatics who would vote this a "10" must be scientologists.  Of course, being members of the L. Ron Hubbard(tm) Cult of Greed and Hate is already enough reason to doubt their thinking.It was bad, it was really bad, and it was never meant to be "camp" like some folks claim.  It simply stunk.Not many books which are turned into movies survive the process or even come close to being as good as the original book.  I have never seen a book "Improved" when it became a movie with very few exceptions.  It takes exceptional books, exceptional actors, and exceptional directors.  This example lacks all three.  In this case, the movie is far worse than the book.Maybe the single worst movie of the last 100 years.

reviews.review_title: So awful it descends into hilarity - a great comedy!
reviews.content: I honestly expected to see "Comedy" listed as one of this movie's genres. Surely, after seeing this, I wasn't meant to take the movie seriously? Apparently I was. Which is the final chuckle!At 2.3/10, this movie is ranked somewhat low...And, as a movie, it deserves lower. It's dreadful! Plot? Well, I'm used to Hollywood driving around plot holes, but this movie is so full of them it resembles a sieve that's been riddled with bullets. There's no point in even trying to justify the many many flaws of the story without descending into the realm of headaches. Suffice to say the plot is about liberating man from aliens, who've repressed them for years. Blah. Who cares really? It makes no sense. The script also comes with some fine one liners, so full of cheese and ham you could feed a country. They're so mind numbingly awful - they even have evil laughs - that they border on the right-out hilarious. You think they *have* to be taking the mickey, they can't possibly expect us to swallow that.The acting? It's nice to see that the two leads - John Travolta and Barry Pepper - had their dreadful work recognised here with Golden Razzie awards. Travolta again provides laughs as he camps it up as the evil overlord Terl. Pepper races around the place trying to look stern, as the earthman hero, and commanding but looks, instead, constipated half the time. It's awful all round, but again so bad you can't help but laugh.However it's the direction by Roger Christian which really makes "Battlefield Earth" a classic. I'm not quite sure where they got him from, but they should send him back to class...there's an incredible over-use of cameras tilted at 45 degree angles - for NO reason. Action shots are done in laughably weak slow motion or incredibly confusing cuts - does Christian even know the concept of where to place your camera? Lighting is generally cranked up to become annoyingly monochrome at times - is there a need for this?! It's done so poorly you would think a 12 year old was the helm. There is not one iota of goodness about the dreadful direction - and again it's so awful that I spent a fair amount of the movie laughing at Christian and wondering how he got the job. I eventually had to persuade myself that he's making an ironic statement about directing or something....Bad in every single area, "Battlefield Earth" should be watched once to see how bloody awful a movie can be. From a camp, hilarity point of view you may gain something from it, and it's certainly a great precursor to any other movie because that movie will, in comparison, be inevitably all that much better. For the sheer gall of this flick being made, I'd give it 3/10, but as it's utter tripe I'd give it 0.5/10 (the .5 because I got to laugh at it).
This is such a bad movie that it's actually amusing to watch.The French word 'navet' is perfectly adequate here.

Wow, I honestly must say nothing was goood about this film. Not only did it not make any sence, but the camera angles and direction in general blew. It is a disaster in every single way.
