The movie seems as if it were made with the old I Movie 1. I think all this film needed to make it worse was a star wipe.Somebody told me it took $40,000,000 to make this, I doubt it. They probably spent $1.75 on the actual film and the remaining $39,999,998.25 on hookers.Not even good for a "funny bad" movie. If you want to see one of those, see "The Thing With Two Heads".

I've heard all those bad critics about this movie but I decided to take a look and see for myself. Now, I believe to all those who don't love this movie. It is so obvious why.We've got director Roger Christian who won Oscar and we also have here two great actors: John Travolta and Forest Whitaker (Travolta nominated and Whitaker won Oscar). No one can't say that they aren't stars cause they are. I'm really disappointed with Whitaker's performance. He is so bad that I have no words. Travolta, on other hand never really cared about this role. He did his part as professional and took his money. Maybe he realized too that there is no reason to act good in such a lousy movie. Barry Pepper is in range with Whitaker. Equally bad. But in Pepper's case I had no real expectations.Special effects. What special effects? Whole movie was made so bad on that and on all other fields. Probably all the money went for securing Travolta's name in this project. But even without special effects it is possible to make a good movie. This isn't that case cause it hasn't got good story. From potentially OK script this turned to a disaster. Disaster on all levels. Red lights. Don't watch this movie. Or watch it and smile.But maybe we should all look at brighter side of this project. So many nominations and wins for this one. Of course, Razzie Awards dominate. In this case I agree with them. Fully deserved.

reviews.review_title: A black hole could not suck more than this film.
reviews.content: I can't really add anything new here that others haven't already said. Heard all the negative reviews of it, but saw it out of curiosity anyway. How bad could it possibly be, right?Oh...the horror....

reviews.review_title: John Travolta liked the book and wanted to make a movie.
reviews.content: Gone with the wind, The Exorcist, Saving Private Ryan, Schindler's List...Battlefield Earth. A brief summary of some of my favorite movies.I admit when I saw this movie on opening day I thought some of the elements in the films story were a little ridiculous. The flight simulator, the fact that the humans were a little slow on what the function of things really were, but the idea of taking back the planet wasn't so terrible and neither was the carrying out of that idea.The acting was fine. The SFX and the Art direction are not as bad as some say, with sixty million dollars how could anything look cheap. I read a criticism on the dialogue, what do we know about how aliens talk anyway? Aliens have personalities and attitudes and they have to put them to use, they're in a business to make money and rule the universe, treachery is a way of life.I recently started reading the book and it cleared up a few things in the film, it's disappointing that the producers wanted a 2hr action-SiFi movie instead of what L. Ron Hubbard wrote in his book, but it doesn't take away too much of the story and is still worth your time.For the bored at heart and those who thought is was stupid, go back to watching made for TV movies that the have brains, acting, directing and the same moral point and cliched story line(at least THIS was original), with a box of tissues. For those who aren't so quick to insult a group of well established film makers who made what they KNOW to be a good movie(or else they wouldn't have wasted they're time making it, do you think John Travolta needs another twenty million dollars to waste a year of his life to make a crappy movie?) see it. It doesn't play so well on the small screen but it's still not a waste of your time.

Someone passed some rumor that battlefield earth was so violent that scientists complained that it demeaned humanity. Sure it demeaned humanity but it is not violent at all. It treats humans like animals. 'Man' animal to be precise. I would be lying if I said that an average human was anymore than the animal portrayed in this movie but still, this movie is not so subtle. It seems to be created solely for the purpose of displaying that idea. But the good news is that humans do end up winning. Battlefield earth may not be one of the worst films ever made but it is still pretty bad. You can watch it if you have nothing better to do at all.

I do wonder if John Travolta and Forest Whittaker ever catch up and discuss the travesty that is this science fiction film. It's so unbelievable given how supremely great these veteran actors have become.The set design, special effects and costumes are pretty laughable, even for their time. The writing, direction and acting are overall poor resulting in a very mediocre narrative. The only thing keeping you going during the film is this "waiting" for something of meaning to happen while simultaneously being dumbfounded by how such a high budget film could have been made with so little forethought.

reviews.review_title: It's not Thanksgiving but here's a fat turkey.
reviews.content: It's really hard to picture John Travolta sitting with his fellow producers and loving this movie.  I'll warn you right now, this one is the most pathetic movies I have ever wasted two hours of time on.  There is no feature that isn't a rip off from elsewhere, the special effects are very subpar, and the plot is so terrible that it is hard to bring myself to even remember it.  It's the "Little Caveman That Could" set in the future.  It wouldn't have been half as bad if the movie hadn't taken itself so darn seriously.It's too late for me, but save yourself the ticket price and stare at a wall for two hours.  You'll thank yourself.

OK this was not by any means a great film but to see people comparing this to something like "Leonard 6" or "Caddyshack 2" is a bit of a stretch. The plot was thin, but the effects were very very good and I liked the green/blue aura of the film. I sure didn't care about Barry Pepper's character and he had no charisma but Travolta was so over-the-top, that is what made this film somewhat fun. And people, when you ask why Cavemen learn to fly jets, as silly as it is, it's called a movie. Fantasy. Look into it.

reviews.review_title: a "1" is not a low enough rating!
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is modern-day Ed Wood with a larger budget, plain and simple. It is truly amazing to think that anyone involved in the production could have ever thought it would be a good, even watchable, film. The story gives new meaning to the word "inane." The acting is laughable. And the production design is basically throwing a lot of dust all over the place. But the worst offender is the direction. Roger Christian uses different angles, close-ups, and slow-motion to emphasize his "drama." All it does is make everything on screen look completely pathetic. Battlefield Earth is only fun to watch if you like watching bad movies to laugh at them. Even then, you can probably find something more worth your time. This movie isn't so bad it's good. It's just plain awful.

I have to admit I somewhat enjoyed this movie. There are some movies that are so BAD, they're GOOD, and I guess I would put this movie in that category ("Cobra" with Sylvester Stallone is another good example). I can enjoy how creatively BAD it is. The bit about the humans teaching themselves to fly sophisticated jet aircraft in a short span of time...well...yeah, that is a bit out there, but there are tons of movies that require you to suspend your disbelief in order to enjoy them. I suppose I see this movie in that vein. Put aside the clear departures from reality, and enjoy it for what it is. It's a bizarre, strange tale, but it held my interest. Obviously, it got produced and distributed, so SOMEONE thought it was worth putting out there. If you're in the mood for a goofy, creatively bad movie, you could certainly do a lot worse. I'd give it a 5.

Come on people. You can say this movie is a pure example of a Hollywood FIASCO. But can all of the people involved in the making of this film be that brainless? If you decide to see it, watch is as you wood Commando. This has to be slapstick. Most of, or all of the characters in this movie are caricatures. The script is a collection of black humor skits. It acts serious, but I was hyperventilating, i.e., gasping for air. It was non-stop laughter. Can anyone believe this story to be plausible? Does anybody think that the scriptwriter was using any authentic, creditable sources in the world of science? I can see how this movie might upset some people, but that's only if it's taken seriously. Then it would be straight up trash! Otherwise, enjoy the satire, the absurdities, this absolute preposterous farce of a movie. I am a bit curious about what the genuine followers of Scientology really think...?....

reviews.review_title: Special effects are only a disguise for this boring film.*
reviews.content: "Battlefield Earth" had everything that I liked for a science fiction film.Great set designs,good alien makeup,and alot of special effects.Now comes the acting,direction and storyline.Well,the film doesn't have any."Battlefield Earth" happens to be one of those boring sci-fi films that has to hide it's true mark by adding alot of visual effects and happens to be one of those films that had me leaving the theater asking myself if the eight dollars I spent was well worth.According to this review,it was not.Based on the novel by L.Ron Hubbard,the film concerns a bunch of humans in a futuristic 3,000A.D. These humans are enslaved by aliens that resemble the klingons from the Star Trek films.John Travolta plays Terl.A villain in the film that seemed to bore me rather than intersest me.I am not even going to mention the other actors or characters because from what I figured,what's the point?"Battlefield Earth" is a boring film with alot of corniness that I did not care for.

I love sci-fi, fantasy and, generally, odd movies. What's odd about this is that it was ever made, John Travolta or no. A little humor might've helped, though I doubt it. A sterling example that an overly expensive film need not be any good .. at all. Train of thought; Travolta, a video camera, a few actors and a _real_ script would most likely be infinitely more rewarding. But, Travolta really wanted to make this film, as well as the upcoming sequel, so all hope probably _is_ lost. It is disturbing to watch otherwise formidable actors become trapped in semi-religious rubbish such as this L. Ron Hubbard "script".

One of the best black comedies I've seen. An exquisite satire on the human condition. This film is surely up there with Dr. Strangelove. Funny, funny, stuff.Travolta and Whitaker, simply superb as two iconic doofuses of the ruling class. Barry Pepper's disciplined dead-pan approach as the "man animals" (humans) visionary revolutionary leader contrasted and complemented the other two main leads performances, and the camp of his human followers.I've seen this film several times now over the years since its release and never tire of it. Definitely a 10. Surprised that other reviewers think this is somehow meant to be in any sense a "serious" tale. Anyway, either Travolta is a genius or despite his best efforts, he managed to Forrest Gump his way to a classic of major proportions.

This is one of the most pathetic things I have ever seen. I almost want to take pity on Battlefield Earth, but then I remember how much time I spent watching it. For one, John Travolta could not act worse in this film if he tried. He prances and cavorts about like an intergalactic fairy, overdoing every single one of his lines. "Oooh, Mr. Chairman! I just luuuv your new ma-ooon boots! Ooh-hoo-hoo!" That's basically it. As for our hero, whose name isn't given until about 45 minutes in, this guy can't act either. There were about 9 instances where 'Jonnie' gets choked by one alien or another, and he makes these exaggerated gasping noises that sound like they belong in a Looney Tunes short. Then we have the makeup. Sorry, but in this day and age when we have The Lord of the Rings, the rubber and plastic of Battlefield looks ancient. Anyone who plays an alien must walk around in a dreadlock wig, stilt boots and clawed hands that look like something you would buy out of a novelty catalog. Honestly, how could anyone involved with this project not be embarrassed to see themselves like this? Now for the huge plot holes and idiotic ideas that appear every few seconds. It boggles my mind how bad the script is. The whole Let's See What A Human's Favorite Food Is bit was laughably bad, as well as the fact that the aliens put cameras in the buttons of shirts to spy on people. Yeah, and these are the same guys that took over the planets in 9 MINUTES? Please. Unless you need a good addition to your Bad Movie Collection or want to torture your friends, you might as well run from this one. It's the biggest turkey to come out of America in years. 0/4 stars

Was i the only person, in this world who enjoyed this movie ?! I really don´t understand why so many people attack Battlefield Earth, when we have lots of pretty good examples of plenty of movies wich are a million times worse than this one and yet they were big box office smashes. And i´m talking about cinematic empty plotwise trash like Stargate, Independence Day... the list goes on and on.What many people fail to compreend, is that Battelfield Earth is a 50´s space-opera, writen more than 40 years ago, and by that time this kind of plot would look pretty good and very exciting to watch. Maybe the filmakers of this movie should had tried to update the content in the story more up to date instead of just updating the special effects attached to this story, but in my opinion if this had been done, the whole original atmosphere of the original novel would have been lost. What i realy liked in Battlefield Earth the movie, was that among all those special effects, it still kept the original spirit and inocence of the original Battlefield Earth the novel. And that is a thing we don´t get much this days ,when a sci-fi novel is addapted to the big screen. For this i think this movie should be praised and not putted down.As novels adaptations go, this is one of the best i´ve seen so far, and altough it loosed a big chunk of the plot in the middle, the original story is very well stitched between the begining and the last act, altough during the second half everything happens to fast, wich  is a shame, because the best parts in the book begin by the middle of the story, and some of them simply disappeared from the film. For example the idea that "caveman" would learn so fast to fly combat planes. This doesn´t happens in such a fast way in the novel, and many other details tha make the movie look like it´s filled with stupid details when in fact the original story kept its "slow" pace and had time to introduce us to every bit in the plot. But because this is the movies, i can understand things had to be accelerated, and this is what makes the second half of this movie feel a bit idiotic, to someone who hadn´t read the book. For example the movie ends up giving the idea, that were the americans only who saved the world, when in fact the book tells us that all was a battle fough around the world at the same time. There are to much fragments of plot lost in the second act of the movie like some great  scenes in Scotland for example.But despite all this the film still kept the spirit of the novel, particulary in the characters of the Psyclos wich are perfectly depicted, and everything is exactly like in the book. I can´t understand why John Travolta is so attacked for doing this movie as he plays the character of the book exactly as it should have been done, and Forest Withaker is also perfect in his role creating a great duo of characters wich end up being very funny to watch altough they say no jokes at all. And this is a compliment, not a bad critic. The treatchery funny feling present in the original novel is all there.I couldn´t care less about Cientology, if it´s a rip-off or not, that´s not my problem, but i can´t help feeling that this movie is being attacked more for its connection to cientology than everything else, because otherwise, with so much successfull movie trash out there how come Battlefield Earth is being so put down ?...Because it doesn´t look cool in a time when sci-fi seems more about cool heros, cool styles and coolness that you can hook the teens with ?... And i bet most of the people who now attack this movie now, are the same who think that Matrix has a very original plot just because it looks cool and are the same who thought that a movie like The 13th Floor for example who deals with the same concept of Matrix was boring just because it was done in a simple style and it wasn´t MTV style cool all the way. I´m not attacking Matrix, because i like it a lot also, i´m just saying that i don´t think there´s much diference between that and Battlefield Earth at the core. Both are great entertainment movies. And both are as good or as bad.Battelfield Earth, is an old style movie, one with good guys, invasions and ugly bad aliens classic style all the way and this is how it should be viewed. This is a classic 50´s sci-fi story. And a good one, simple as that. Why people go to watch this expecting some serious sci-fi concept ? This is just a good old fashioned adventure movie, based on a story that was one of the first to deal in a large eopic scale with this type of plot in a time when no one had dared to write something in this style. And to my knowledge it´s a very good story. Simple in our days, but still fun and effective. And this is why i think the movie of this book is a good movie,I wish all the sci-fi book were all this well adappted to the big sceen as this one is and i only reggret this wasn´t a three hour movie, because if it would have been, all the things in the book could have been done, and perhaps, people now would be looking at this story diferently.In reality the only things that disapointed me were some of the little bit "rip-offs" in design, from Blade Runner, to Star Trek, to Dune, to Matrix, there was always something on screen that we had already seen before, but with so many stuff being created nowadays i guess it´s tough to be original this days. One good thing that i liked was that the special effects were always used to serve the movie plot and not just to look cool.Not the best sci-fi movie i ever saw, not even in my favorites list, but definetely a very, very good sci-fi adventure, and a million times better than 90% of the crap wich comes out of Hollywood this days. The filmakers of this should be proud of their work and not disapointed by the reviews.Good old sci-fi fun. Recomended to everyone who goes watch it with an open mind.

reviews.review_title: I laughed (when I shouldn't), I cried (for sitting through it); it moved me (to the bathroom)
reviews.content: I recently saw this film for the second time.  I have to say that there was great potential in the story but this one flopped flat on its face.  By sticking to the overdramatic wordage of the penny-a-page hack Hubbard, it destroyed any possibility of connecting with a general audience.  I was fortunate enough to watch with a former Scientologist who got some great laughs for the apparent propoganda in the film.  Besides the horrible overacting and that crap-lousy faux British accent of Travolta's, I couldn't get past the major plot holes to get into the film.  Some of the ones I noticed that haven't been discussed much on here: 1)  Johnny uses a learning machine that teaches him Psychlo language and culture.  Yet he discusses "Euclidian Geometry".  Why is Euclid, an Earthling, discussed on the machine? 2)  The "man-animals" seem to have no written language (evidenced by the lack of writing, other than primitive cave drawings) yet, by studying Psychlo culture, he can suddenly read books in English in the Denver Library and understand a complicated manual for a nuclear device. 3)  Even getting past finding a WORKING flight simulator, these machines do not instruct those who have never flown.  Understanding the hover systems, as well as weaponry, of a Harrier in a few days is inconceivable. 4)  The Psychlos have been searching for and mining gold for 1000 years. Apparantly in that time, they did no research on the subject.  Magically, in his short time in the Denver library, Johnny picks a book which discusses the huge gold reserves at Ft. Knox. 5)  Travolta's character (like I ever worried about remembering his name) questions why the gold has been put into bars yet never questions how!And there are so many more.  Put this movie up there with "Look Who's Talking Too" as painful to watch a fairly talented actor sinking like a stone.

reviews.review_title: Seventy million for a B movie.
reviews.content: One of the great unwritten rules of B movies, SciFi in particular, is that the villains are usually more entertaining than the heroes. I suppose this is because being evil takes acting talent, and being 'good' only requires stiffness and noble sacrifice. That said, the best part of BE is Travolta as Terl. His performance is the only thing keeping this movie remotely watchable.And I mean the *only* thing. Having never read the book, I can't comment on how faithful an adaptation it is, or how much the story had to be accelerated, but the movie's plot has big enough holes to drive a Star Cruiser through. The 'good guy' humans are so boring and annoying you start to wish the invaders would get rid of them *now*. Basically, the only people to whom I would recommend this movie are fans of the classic SF bad-guy, because it's a real treat seeing Terl rub a dead rat in the hero's face while shouting "DO YOU WANT LUNCH?"

reviews.review_title: How can you have plot holes with no PLOT!?!
reviews.content: Being subject to this film should be a crime.This movie is real garbage. Like, not "oh it's not great" but I mean actually garbage.You shouldn't watch this mess of a movie. If you can call it anything more than a high school film project.I felt physically ill and angry towards every scene. From the first hour of Barry pepper running. To John Travolta's hand prosthetic. How cringe was that.I have to pop a few tums before I'll be able to get to sleep after viewing this movie that breaks several internation laws and the Geneva convention.

I can honesty say that I have never experienced anything quite like this. It was an unforgettable experience. Unfortunately. I could only watch half the movie, let me explain why.Imagine being stuck in a tiny lift with morbidly obese man who has eaten lots of eggs and suffers from extreme flatulence. Imagine that he has neither showered nor changed his clothes for the past decade. Now imagine having to give him a bath, in the lift, with your tongue.Not nice is it. Well I can honestly say I would prefer that to having to see Battlefield Earth. I have never had the misfortune to experience such an insult, not just to cinema, but to the world of entertainment and humanity. This film was a complete load of cretinous Scientologist rubbish; I could have made a far superior movie from the change in my pocket.Whatever you do, do not watch this film. In fact don't even go near it, don't look at the website, don't consider it in the video store, don't download or buy it. Trust me if you do the horror of having to watch it will haunt you for the rest of your days.

reviews.review_title: Cheesy, silly, weird, fantastic. bad. GREAT!
reviews.content: People expected a lot more from the support cast and Barry Pepper doesn't have the screen presence to role. He's a sexless, emotionless figure and so is his love interest int he film - who everyone takes orders from late in the film apparently because she is Barry Pepper's squeeze.It's a Scientology film starring one of Hollywood's big scientologist actors.It has Ray Bradbury Theatre level effects and sub-Ray Bradbury story/dialogue. Basically expect some perfectly adequate effects for television but ofr a blockbuster sci-fi (which this, despite its aspiration NEVER was) don't get your hopes up.The plot holes are legion, but the narrative keeps moving along at a steady pace. The final battle is fairly trite with some of the worst models/effects effects giving the film the aesthetic quality of a 1970's disaster movie.*IF* you can make it past these glaring flaws and enjoy *CHEESE* and silly science fiction this film definitely has the ability to provide a great deal of pleasure.Travolta is as good as Travolta ever was... Forest Whittaker is walking, or limping, through his performance but still provides a good deal of comic relief. The heavily shoed Psychlos are quite delicious as they back stab and torture each other mercilessly.

reviews.review_title: Rather than talk about the movie, here's a recipe for a peach cobbler
reviews.content:
Method
STEP 1
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a baking dish with a little butter, then lay the drained peach slices in the base. Sprinkle with 2 tbsp of the sugar and the ground ginger and set aside.STEP 2
Tip the flour, remaining sugar, baking powder, cinnamon and a pinch of salt into a food processor. Whizz until combined, then add the cubes of butter, pulse until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs, then add the egg and continue to blitz until it comes together to make a thick dough.STEP 3
Spoon the dough in dollops on top of the peaches, creating a good covering, but leave some gaps for the dough to spread into. Sprinkle with a little caster sugar then bake for 40 mins, until golden. Serve with scoops of vanilla ice cream.

Very simple:  you see, while I am taking up the valuable seconds of your life, you are essentially spending the time in a more fulfilling way than you would be if you saw this film.Why are you still reading? reviews.review_title: I wish people would develop their own opinions.
reviews.content: I don't really think that most of the people that tore this movie apart really watched the film.  They were immediately impressed how it has been declared the worst film ever, and just saw a pretty picture on their televisions while claiming how terrible it was.I also think that anyone who connects this film with Scientology should be smacked really hard with a copy of Dianetics.  I am no Scientology advocate, but the book was just another of L. Ron Hubbard's novels.  That's it. Travolta made this movie as a homage to his mentor, not to promote his religion.And of course the movie is rife with plot holes.  Unfortunately, the story is too deep and complex to make a 3 hour movie complete, let alone a 90 minute one.  The universe in the book in far more expansive, and Johnny's plan of taking back the planet is far more in depth.  The difference between books being made into film, and original screenplays, is that the screenplay is written with such time limitations in mind.  Every book that has been made into film has had plot holes and missing elements.All of that said, the only truly bad part of Battlefield Earth is the cinematography, but really only one aspect of such.  Too often the camera seemed tilted for no other reason than to depict a chaotic scene, and this just did not come across well.The acting was done very well, the sets and special effects were for the most part done well.  The costumes were not perfect, but I am sure it is not easy to make a 6 foot man appear to be an 8 foot alien.I understand there are going to be some people that truly don't like this movie.  But for the rest of you, please watch it for yourself, and don't listen to other people.

reviews.review_title: The most loose direct book adaptation I've ever seen..
reviews.content: Well, this is an ok movie.  It's not great, I don't regret spending $4.50 to see it at a matinee time, but I would of regretted $8.  Of course, I'm not HAPPY I spent it either..  I recently finished the book (3 days ago as of 5/12/00), and saw it mostly because of that (or vice-versa, take your pic). Needless to say, the cliche works: "The book was better".  The characters are more limited, of course.  They rushed things a lot, making it far less realistic.  Just about everything is worse here, and less entertaining.  In fact, the action scenes are even worse!  How's that: a book beating a movie in action scenes.  Perhaps the sequel will redeem it in this department (this is only about 1/3 of the book), since the best action sequence, the fight with the Brigantes, is in that chunk.

Yes, the tilted camera angles are annoying but not enough to ruin the film. Likewise, the sub-par special effects are laughable but hardly enough to make it a bad movie. There is enough going on to keep me from getting bored and the school play level acting doesn't put me off. All of these are problems but together they wouldn't be enough to put this film on the bottom 100 films of all time. The one, all-encompassing thing that really kills Battlefield Earth is the enormous amount of stupidity that is omnipresent through all of the 118 minutes. A few examples of said stupidity (SPOILER ALERT): According to the film all the well trained soldiers of earth lasted a total of 9 minutes against the Psyclos but ragtag team of cavemen beat them with our technology.The Psyclos know about the level of technology humans had before the invasion but still think humans are only good for manual labour.They have lived on earth for 1000 years and still have not bothered to learn our language or teach us theirs.Twentyeth century weapons have been lying around in a bunker for 1000 years without becoming even slightly rustyThe humans don't know math such as what a triangle is, but have still managed to build a complicated gate for the wall around the villageThe list goes on but I don't want to write down the entire movie. That's it, if the plot was less stupid, this could have been an OK film.

reviews.review_title: One of the best S/F comedies since Spaceballs
reviews.content: WARNING   *****THIS IS A S/F COMEDY***** If you try and take it seriously you have missed the point. It is a comic book transferred to the big screen. NO GORE, violence is implied and there are no car chases but a lot of dry humour and great puns are evident.The movie is filled with bits from other previous S/F films presented in a comedic fashion. See how many you can spot.Don't believe the low rating, that resulted in the general public expecting a "serious film" like a Star Wars or one of the many Star Treks.    You know, a realistic S/F  ;-)

I watched this crap on HBO the other night, and I swear had I spent a few bucks to see it at a theatre instead, I would have sent the producers an invoice to cover the time I wasted watching it.However, on to a more positive mindset, it is reassuring to know that 1000 years from now Harriers (I think that's what those fighter jets were) will start at the first turn of the key and will look factory-fresh. reviews.review_title: Thank God I waited for cable
reviews.content: Anyone who actually paid their own hard earned money to see this film must certainly feel-- on several levels-- violated.  And not specifically because it is horrible, but that it is horribly mediocre.  At several points I found myself muttering aloud, wondering what had gone wrong, or simply asking of no one in particular, "Why??"Travolta seemed to speak lines through a haze of confusion and or insensibility, while Barry Pepper's part could have been as convincingly played by one of the old animatronic presidents from the revolving Learn-o-Matic they used to have at Disneyland.The plot is far too silly and convoluted to even try to explain-- just know this:  You may feel nauseated, confused, or a combination of the two after finishing the film.  That is to assume that you will finish it.Bottom line?  Senseless plot, lifeless acting, idiotic story twists, no sense of humor whatever, B+ special effects.  The effects-- not the makeup.  Oh,  wait until you see the alien shoes.  A standout.  The rest is dreck.

All the Scientology aside, L. Ron Hubbard wrote a couple of decent SciFi novels. "Battlefield Earth" (the book) is a decent space opera, a little naive, but quite humorous and a good enough way to while away quite a few hours (the book is long but the story flows nicely to be tied up with quite a good ending).A shame that the same cannot be said for the film. First of all, the acting is simply atrocious - no-one, repeat, no-one is believable. Adding to this is that in shortening the book to fit in the obligatory 90 minutes, almost all of the important/exciting/interesting bits of the story were ignored or, at best, changed beyond recognition.I'd still recommend the book, but as for the film, avoid enriching the church's coffers! Really, really not worth it!

reviews.review_title: Why does everyone bash this movie?
reviews.content: I can't understand why so many people bash this movie. I understand that it's not the greatest science-fiction movie ever made, but myself and many people I know find this movie great fun. Some of the acting may be corny, but I find it has great action, good effects, and a good plot. Also, it has local boy Barry Pepper, who is becoming a very good actor, and a pretty good job by John Travolta. So in saying, I don't care what any lousy critic or the general public think of this movie. I find it a great watch.

reviews.review_title: I wish it was possible to give this movie a NEGATIVE number
reviews.content: A movie must be Truly bad to deserve a 1 rating from me. Battlefield Earh is one that qualifies.I am a fan of Travolta. He is excellent in Pulp Fiction. He is good in Face Off. His really early success was Saturday Night Fever, and he was brilliant in that movie. I even rather enjoyed him in Broken Arrow. However Battlefield Earth shows that Travolta is capable of making a piece of crap too.The script was lame, the acting was Awful, the special effects were not much better but they were the "highlight" of the "film." I am sure that everybody stank too even though we couldn't smell them (at least they LOOK like they stink).Anyway, do yourselves a favor and avoid this turd like the plague.BTW, about this being a great book, I am sure it is a pretty good one. But, L. Ron Hubbard to me is just as nuts as all those other Scientology nuts (including Mr. Travolta).

I have seen a lot of movies in my time.  I have liked a lot of movies in my time.  But I have also been searching for the worst movie ever for a long time, this fits the bill perfectly.  Without breaking a sweat or batting an eye, I can say that this is by far the worst serious movie ever made.  See it once, I highly recommend the experience to all the masochistic moviegoers out there.

reviews.review_title: Served as the inspiration for The Force Awakens
reviews.content: This turkey spoke jive to Jar Jar Abrams and inspired The Farce Awakens. Here humans find a jet that is a millennium old, find that it still flies and learn to command it in under five minutes (screw YOU Top Gun!). In The Farce Awakens a homeless dumpster diving girl finds the millennium falcon languishing in the desert and takes it into the galaxy fuel maneuvering and charting and all.!

reviews.review_title: The very worst movie I have ever seen!
reviews.content: While searching for a movie that I could rent.  I came across this movie that I never heard of before.  Figuring that Travolta was in it, i assumed that it would definitely be worth watching.  Boy was I wrong.  I cannot believe that Travolta would allow himself to be in a movie like this after he read the script.  The whole movie did not make any sense what-so-ever. Not only that, but I could not figure out what the plot of this movie was about.  It just never made sense right from the beginning.  Half way through the movie I was praying that miraculously, it would become interesting. My prayers were not answered.  Please save your $3.50 and buy popcorn with it, or rent another movie.

reviews.review_title: For once, I actually agree with the critics on this one
reviews.content: This is one of the very few movies that I agreed with the critics on. This movie did suck. I admit, I wanted to see this movie when it came out because it looked good, the effects looked great and the story sound interesting. However I didn't get to see it during it's theatrical run at the movies, but I did see it when it debuted on HBO. What I thought was gonna to be a rip-roaring sci-fi adventure turned out to be a sci-fi dud. John Travolta was totally wrong for this movie, he shouldn't have acted in it but he should have only produced it an nothing more. Thank God they haven't tried to make a sequel out of this one because this definitely does not need a sequel.

The movie was unbearable, I would have rather been stuck with a 1,000 needles than sit through that movie again.  Battlefield Earth was a mistake a glitch you could say.  The movie was so excruciatingly painful that I felt like throwing up.  About halfway through the movie I asked myself if this was suppose to be a comedy or not.  I found myself asking the questions, Did they really mean to make this movie?  Are they joking?  As the movie finished I cheered and clapped out of utter celebration that it was done. I do wish two things though, that I could have given this movie a lower rating, 1 does not even justify how bad this movie was. Also if I could have got my money back.

reviews.review_title: I believe it was suppose to be a comedy.
reviews.content: My dad and I loved this movie ! John Travolta and Forest Whitaker were hilarious as the evil, mean, and stupid aliens! When I saw it on DVD, it was the first time I had ever heard of it. The photo on the front had Travolta smiling slightly evilly. I wasn't disappointed because I thought it was a sci-fi comedy. I got it and then I had to bring it over to my dad for him to watch. I always thought John Travolta was great in comedy. I know others loved him in Pulp Fiction (and he was great in that also). I think John Travolta really did mean for his and Forest and the rest of the aliens to come across as more comedic than evil characters. They gave Barry Pepper an award for worst actor I think. Maybe because he kind of whisper/yelled out his dialogue which was suppose to inspire his comrades to fight. But soon after I saw Barry Pepper in a movie called,"The Snow Walker". Barry played a lead character and I was amazed by his performance!!!! He was awesome in The Snow Walker !

reviews.review_title: It has to be the worst idea someone could come up with.
reviews.content: This is the greatest compilation of elements of a horrible movie put together. We can start with the cast that, with the exception of Travolta and Whitaker, has no acting abilities whatsoever. The acting for this movie was exceptionally bad, with actors that have no emotion at all.The screenplay author wrote simply the poorest lines ever. It is unbelievable that Travolta agreed to say such empty and childish lines in a movie. The extremely predictable plot is also something that shows how poorly this film was made. People this century should know better than to have shallow plots such as this one. The movie drags for two hours. Very boring. The special effects certainly did NOT reflect the huge budget of this film. Take for instance, the part that Terl, character of Travolta, throws the "man-animal" down an abyss. I found it incredible the obviousness of the screen on the scene. (Don't forget to notice the bad acting in that scene, too.) To topple it up, the names, places, histories were extremely unbelievable. Yes, it is a fiction, but Artificial Intelligence and even Lord of the Rings are more believable than this! In every aspect, this is one of the worst displays of human talent yet. But hey, life goes on. Let the Matrixes and Godfathers come. Why waste time with the sadness of Hollywood, when the spectacles of image and sound are right there, at Blockbuster, right next to the Battlefield Earth tape, which, by the way, needs some dusting.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst Movies I've ever sat through.
reviews.content: I'm not one to walk out of a movie once I've started watching it, but in retrospect, if I could pick 2 hours of my life I could have back...I would have preferred to never see this movie. Biggest load of garbage I've seen produced in mainstream theatre. This is below a "B" movie. Ugh. Makes me sick just thinking about it.

reviews.review_title: Good movie. render the book well
reviews.content:
The film stick mostly to the book except for the timeline witch was shorter in the movie. All of the important event where there. Some changes have been made to ease the production and to allow easy editing of the story.
I think the actors where good and credible. Some characters weren't deep enough but this is the same in the book.  No character evolved or changed, except for Ker and that isn't obvious.The special effects where good, but nothing new there. It reminds me of ID4. The futurist landscape is looking good. The aliens weren't alien enough for my taste. It's as if they wanted us to see who were the actors.
The music wasn't intrusive but rendered the tension of the situations well.Overall, I enjoyed the film. The story was entertaining and we could easily relate to the characters. Most of the time, if I see a movie made from a book I have read before, I'm disappointed. This wasn't the case. In my book, they made a movie worth seeing

I'm not quite sure why this movie is despised by so many, perhaps because of Hubbard's Scientology stuff.   Battlefield Earth, of course, has nothing to do with Scientology, it is what it is.    The novel and the movie are both, in all honesty, simply a 50s style space opera.  It's not supposed to be deep, it's not supposed to be realistic even, it's just supposed to be fun.  And it is.

reviews.review_title: Taken in context, a decently fun movie
reviews.content: I went into the theater to watch Battlefield Earth with TWO things in mind: don't expect it to follow the novel (which I'd read in the early 1980s), and suspend disbelief.  And guess what?  I enjoyed it.  The basic spirit of the book was followed... that mankind could unite and fight against insurmountable odds for the freedom of their world.  The acting was quite good, though I admit the script could have been better.  John Travolta seems to excel at playing fun, exciting villains. Mind you... the Suspension of Disbelief is important... if you hated Independence Day simply because you couldn't handle civilians learning to fly F/A-18s in 2 days and the world's most incompatible computer, the Macintosh, being able to interact with an alien system, then you won't be able to handle certain things in Battlefield Earth.  But if your mind is that closed, why are you a sci-fi fan to begin with? :) Simply put, taken in context, Battlefield Earth is a fun film.
In the vein of a cult classic. Don't take every movie so seriously, sit back and enjoy. John Travolta is great.

reviews.review_title: If you're a sucker for post-apocalypse and camp...
reviews.content: So, I'll get it out of the way and say it right now: Scientology is at the very least "problematic," and at its worst downright dangerous. So, please take this as a review of the *film,* and not the backers.So, here's the thing. This film? It's hilarious. It's often unintentionally so, but come on, folks.* 9 foot tall alien John Travolta, with dreadlocks * 1000 year old jets (which failed to stop the alien invasion when brand new) used by mostly untrained humans to kill all the aliens * Aliens with a "learning machine" voiced by a depressed "all my other fellow aliens are extinct, sigh" character * Purple everywhere * Ruins!It's actually kinda great. Most of the premise is ridiculous, but the costumes and set-pieces are great, and a lot of the acting is actually dead on, at least for the film this IS (and not the one it meant to be).And say what you want about John Travolta, but he's actually totally great in this film, as an absolute #^%@head arrogant alien, and his lackey is equally well played.So yeah, conceptually? Totally ridiculous. And the lead "human" actor? Not fantastic. But this is actually a totally enjoyable post-apocalyptic, campy-as-hell film.Now, I'm a huge sucker for post-apocalyptic settings, and when I tell people *how* much of a sucker I am for them, I use this film as an example. "I like post apocalyptic films so much that I like BATTLEFIELD EARTH!"If you go into this film looking for a compelling, serious science fiction film addressing deep philosophical issues, you're going to come away very disappointed.But if you're looking for drinking-game fuel, or a lovely combination of post-apocalypse and unintentional hilarity? Yeah, this is a great film for you.

My God! This movie... It's indescribable! There are no words to tell the sheer awfulness you will find when watching this movie. It boggles the mind! Your head will explode trying to figure out what on Earth possessed them to make such a God-awful film. From the outstandingly terrible performance of John Travolta to the script that seems like it has PAGES ripped out, this movie is the picture-perfect image of what should NOT be done during the making of a movie. The creation of this train-wreck should be put into one of those "Don't Do What Donnie Don't Does" books and shown to every film student and potential film student in the world. I don't know what's more pathetic, the fact that they MADE this monstrosity or that it cost somewhere around $70,000,000 US. I'm wondering how much of that was spent on the drugs I'm SURE they were on to be able to create such a thing as this. Oh, and don't mistake it for one of those "It's so bad it's good" films. It goes beyond good and right back to bad again. In fact, my head is starting to hurt just thinking about it so I'll leave you with one word: **BEWARE**

reviews.review_title: The failure of religion on the screen
reviews.content: One thing that seems missing from the deserved derision this movie was subjected to on this site, was the recognition that Travolta made it because of his religious zeal.  Of course, it didn't help that the acting was awful, the direction absent, and the special effects well off the state of the art. But religion, almost without exception makes lousey film - remember the Greatest Story Ever Told?  The reason is that realism goes out of the window, but is not replaced by humour, or horror, or even the avant garde. Its replaced by homage.  Battlefield Earth was a hymn of praise to L. Ron Hubbard.  And it was quite the most ghastly film I have seen.

Very Disappointed movie, I would have thought that they at least try to follow the original storyline a bit closer. I am not looking forward to the 2nd movie (but I will probably watch it). ps The book is superb (read it several times)

reviews.review_title: man oh man, where to begin....
reviews.content: OK, let's get this turd out in the open:Mankind had been enslaved for 1000 years by aliens, & humans have reverted back to basically stone-age mentalities (although some people speak like they live in the middle ages while others sound like they live in modern day L.A.) & yet... 1. in 1000 years, electricity & computers (like flight simulators & overhead projectors) still work somehow, & fighter jets still have jet fuel in them. Also, books & paper are slightly dusty, but perfectly preserved (in Denver no less, which I'm pretty sure gets a lot of damp weather.) 2. these stone-age humans who live in caves & have never seen any technology can master in one week advanced weapons & flight simulations enough to defeat the "superior" (dumb-ass) alien race at dogfights & combat. (also, how did they learn modern-day combat lingo???) Apparently, in the year 2000 when the aliens showed up, they conquered earth in 9 minutes. 1000 years later, !cavemen! can beat them & destroy their home planet, with only like 3 people dying. 3. why do the aliens make Barry Pepper so smart & then give him access to all of their records & passwords & equipment, etc? They just want him to mine gold, so why not just teach him only to swing a pick ax, which the human slaves are already doing? 4. why is the dialog so stupid? I read an earlier review that said he watched the movie on cable, so he wondered if he missed anything. Let me tell you buddy, you didn't. At one point Forrest Whitaker said something like "crap-head" & they seem to think "rat-brain" is a hard-core insult. 5. the best the production design team could come up with for alien alcohol is... glowing green liquid with a straw in it? Seriously, this movie was made in the year 2000, & that's the best you could do? 6. the same goes for the special effects. They're terrible! This movie cost $70 million. It also looks like it was shot on video. & what's with all the dutch angles? There's only 1 or 2 straight shots in the whole movie. & the extreme shots of humans getting sprayed with water? I've seen episodes of Xena: Warrior Princess that look better than this. 7. The acting is disgusting. John Travolta & Forrest Whitaker ought to be ashamed of themselves. How can they deliver lines that sound like they were written by 12 year old kids? I'm not kidding. 12 year old children. Why do the aliens call humans "man animals?" If they think of people as animals, why not just call them "man?" They don't say "rat animals" or "dog animals." 8. The plot is just plain stupid. Why does John Travolta take Barry Pepper to a library for a half hour or so, where he finds... the constitution??? Why? Seriously, I want to know why. 9. Oh yeah, that reminds me... when Barry Pepper is in the prison, he draws a sketch of his girlfriend on a piece of old leather, & somehow... some... how... he's such a good artist that the aliens recognize her when she's out in the wild on her horse, so they can hold her hostage & get him to behave. I mean come on! To sum it up, this movie is more or less a Scientology sci-fi story (sort of) written by LA dick-heads who think they are being deep when they come up with ideas like "if civilization was destroyed for 1000 years, humans would think mannequins were once people who had disobeyed the gods... dude, that's freaking smart!" Anyway, that's only about .000001% of what's bad about this movie. I've always liked post-apocalyptic movies, no matter how bad, but this one is just an absolute turd, no matter how you slice it. There is no way anyone could reasonably say this is not one of the worst movies ever made. It sucks. But, I recommend it if you like seeing cave men flying jets (which I kind of do.)

This movie is true to L Ron Hubbard's novel. It not only conveys the book's atmosphere, but also its satire. John Travolta is brilliant as Terl, with his fixation on "leverage", status and rats. It's a study in the fantastic and yes, it IS meant to be funny in many places. You just have to look closely to see parallels between the Psychlos, and some of the sadder specimens in modern human society...The special effects are also convincing: Travolta and Whitaker really do manage to be eight foot aliens for a couple of hours!Battlefield Earth is a very fast-paced film, and even though it only reached the halfway mark in the book (wait for the sequel), there's a great deal of action and data to assimilate: keep up or be left behind. An extra half hour would have left us less breathless - particularly if we haven't read the book - and we could have savoured Terl's plottings for just a little longer.
Battlefield Earth may be in a similar SF genre to Soylent Green, the Planet of the Apes series, or THX 1138 -and probably more of a classic.  It illustrates a pretty dystopian future for Earth and the galaxy, so despite Johnny Goodboy's heroism it may best lie alongside that 'blacker' class of film, rather than the good clean-shaven futuristic swashbuckling of Star Wars or Independence Day. Watch out for the satire, follow the outrageous intrigues, and be entertained.

Anybody who has ever dreamed of a decent post-apocalyptic movie, this is it. I can see how so many people can dislike this movie, I don't recommend it unless you are open and love SciFi. This is a cult classic, or it will be. I can also see how they spent 70 million dollars, the special effects are seamless and the sets are huge. This movie is about human perseverance and amazing ability to adapt. There is also a scene where rock is being blown up and there are a million particles everywhere like that lobby scene from the Matrix. Only, this movie came before the Matrix. This movie has no good acting, no plot, almost no writing but it is very interesting and I think it triggers imagination, if you have one that is.

When I saw the commercials for this movie, a traitorous thought crept into my mind: "This can't possibly be as bad as has been said". As it happened, it was worse. Now, I can watch nearly any kind of film and have a good time at it, but watching this felt like crawling through solidified tar with jagged pieces of glass in it. Slow plodding, with the only exciting bits being worse than the boredom. I think everyone should see this once, so they can appreciate other movies more. The only positive thing in all this was the hilariously huge codpieces in the aliens' suits, but since Hubbard loathed psychiatrists, I will not mention the word "overcompensating"...I can see how this was made to resemble Star Wars with the visuals and the main plot outline: the cosmic Rastafarian bad guy wearing all-black and having some devices implanted to make him resemble Darth. All we'd need is the good guy in white pajamas, some headgear on Travolta and a bunch of irritating 'funny' aliens to bring in the younger kids.Some reference to how bad this really is is the fact, that I loaned this on VHS from a friend who never throws anything away. When I had seen through to the end of the film I went to take it back to her, just to be told that she didn't want it back and I was free to take it to the woods and burn it for all she cared. I complied.

I really gave this the fairest try I could despite knowing about its horrible reputation. I wasn't even in a position to be let down. I went into this film skeptical about the claims made about it by so many. Yet here I am, 2/10.The best part of this film is whenever John Travolta is on screen. His overacting is the only aspect of the film I have any amount of fun with because- while I'm laughing at the film- at least it's getting something out of me.My biggest issue with this film is its pacing. I'e seen this film a few times and every time I come out of this film exhausted, feeling as if I sat through a film that was 3 hours long or so. I guessed that it was probably 2 1/2 hours long only to find out that it doesn't even reach the 2 hour mark. This film progresses in such a slow way and so little happens in it. If a proper film was made from the material covered in this film, it would probably be closer to 80 minutes. It's such a slog and there's no real payoff in the end.The action scenes are extremely slow-paced and boring. It almost feels like all of the action scenes are in slow motion. My memory is a little foggy, but none of the action is interesting and the bland cinematography doesn't help either.The visual effects used in this film have aged badly. A lot of them now look like they were rendered on video game hardware. Of course the use of visual effects to this extent was still pretty ambitious at the time and the only contemporary of this film that really holds up at all is Star Wars Episode I but...I wish I could say more positive things but everything I could possibly ask for in a science fiction film or science fiction action film is barely present in this film and, even then, not executed well at all. John Travolta is the only thing I liked and that was because I love it when he overacts. I was not invested in his character and I was, instead, looking forward to his over-the-top line delivery and physical acting. This is a film which manages to be only 117 minutes long yet feel longer than films significantly longer than this. It's inept, and that's unfortunate. My only hypothesis is that, maybe, the source material wasn't very strong to begin with? Who knows, though...

This movie was terrible. The worst I've ever seen, on so many different levels, from basic storytelling principles, writing, special effects, makeup, acting, believability, & pretty much everything in it. I can't believe I've seen a few positive reviews on here. One person loved the idea that our caveman-like relatives in the future would worship everyday items from the year 2000. Of course they would, but that doesn't make for a good movie. For a movie to be good you need to actually care about the characters. These cavemen are leaderless mongrels until Barry Pepper's character shows up & gives them a 30 second speech, & then all is well. There is no depth to it at all. The same positive review said it had a good message about how we treat those weaker than ourselves. Again, it was totally on the surface, no depth whatsoever. If you want to see a futuristic movie that actually conveys some universal truths about humans, watch "Children of Men." "Battlefield Earth" had about as much depth & truth as a Hannah Montana song.

reviews.review_title: THE WORST MOVIE OF ALL TIME! ---25%
reviews.content:
FIRST IMPRESSIONAs soon as the movie, Battlefield Earth: A Saga of blah blah blah, ended, I jumped out of my seat and applauded.  Because right there, before me, was the movie I have been searching for my entire life; a movie in which a long stream of endless jokes could be accumulated.SUMMARY
The story takes place on Earth, of course, and a group of goofy looking aliens take control, and ultimately put every human into slavery.  Then, one day, a puny human (played by Barry Pepper) decides to fight back, and once again reserve control of the Earth for the human race.  Armed with basically pitch forks and grade-school brains, the humans prepare a final assault against none other than.......John Travolta.  The movie is also based on a well-known book explaining about Scientology.First off, Battlefield is the worst movie I have seen EVER.  Lets look at the different components that make up a movie:ACTING: 35%Terrible acting.  I admit John Travolta and Barry Pepper are decent.  You can tell John enjoyed playing this alien guy and his energy on the screen allowed us to hate his character more and more.  Still, just about every other character is terribly one-sided and unrealistic.
STORY: 10%Now I'm not bashing on Scientology.  I think its an interesting topic. But the movie doesnt even touch the topic.  The film has the background story, but doesnt bother to explain ANYTHING about the history of Scientology. This is how the movie is structered: an interesting premise in the beginning.......then...........ACTION...and more ACTION.  And I mean mindless action.  Oh, and one part quickly comes to mind, that greatly portrays the filthy nature of this piece of garbage film.  Towards the end of the film (dont worry, I'm not spoiling anything), a group of humans stumble upon an old air base, with fighter jets still intact.  So, after a few practices in the simulator, they're off and flying around in the jets and successfully blowing up strategic targets.  This just shows that the writers just didnt spend much time in writing the story.
DIRECTION: 0%There just isnt any direction.  Nothing.  No style, just rubbish.  But, who knows.  Even the mastery of Steven Spielberg probably couldnt save this film.
MEANING: 10%I guess theres a theme some where in there.  Most likely the theme is minorities breaking out of bondage and taking control of their lives and stuff like that.  But anyway, the theme is so not-original and well yeah, just so overused.  Tough luck for making this movie so late.  I'm sure that if this movie was released in the 60s, it would become a cult classic. Still, the only things going through my mind after the movie were evil, evil jokes.  Pure and simple: NO SUBSTANCE.F.F. (a little something I call "fun factor") 60%Yes, this movie is moderately fun.....and funny.  If you just want to see a movie for the pure excitement of action, or if you and and your friends are just too drunk to watch "Aliens," then Battlefield is your movie.
FINAL IMPRESSION  ---25%-Terrible, unrealistic, and one-sided acting across the board.-A script that seemed to be conceived by 4th graders.-Absolutely no direction or style in this movie, just a mess to watch!-Without the crucial Scientology topic in, absolutely no point to the film.-Kinda of fun to watch if you're drunk or dead.Well, to sum up: Worst movie in history, and that inlcudes Dumb and Dumberer.

I just can't imagine how this movie was released.  It is that bad.  Not bad in an Ed Wood, Mystery Science sense.  Just plain unwatchable.
I understand the bankrolling and politics behind it, but it still took some cooperation by people who had to understand that it was a turkey and an instant demerit, and wouldn't want to be associated with such a mess.From story to special effects to acting, it's a wretched piece.  There is good bad, and bad bad -- White Castle hamburgers are good bad, but hospital cafeteria food is just bad bad.  This movie is just plain bad bad.

Word is that the DVD will fill in some holes between the movie and the book. The book was an unparalleled page-turner that kept me up all night. The DVD will apparently contain more continuity and be smoother than the movie. Some critics really "grokked" what the sense and plot of the movie was all about, its irony and satires. As for the other critics, well, they also didn't like Rambo or Clint Eastwood's movies (till he turned 50).I go for clever turns of plot, action, the occasional laugh, and memorable lines. I personally think that Battlefield Earth has them all. (But too bad we didn't see more of Terl's paramour!)

reviews.review_title: One of the worst directed movies ever
reviews.content: I'm blaming Roger Christian for many of the failings of Battlefield Earth. But truly he's hardly the most responsible party. I could blame L.Ron Hubbard for writing an insipid book. Or John Travolta's ego for making the insipid book into the insipid movie now available. I could blame Giles Nuttgens for some truly ugly cinematography. Or the entirely special effects crew could be blamed for seemingly spending 75 million dollars to create cheesy "afterburner" effects on cardboard looking space crafts. But ultimately there's just too much blame to go around. All that can be said is that Battlefield Earth is possibly even worse than you may have heard. And that's impressive.The plot is a mishmash of science fiction clichés, the kind of things a Phillip K. Dick or Robert Heinlein would be embarrassed to even think, much less write. Battlefield Earth takes place a thousand years in the future. Now, we're told on at least two occasions, Man is an Endangered Creature. The planet Earth is ruled by tall, ugly aliens called Psychlos. The Psychlos don't really like the Man-Animals and, for no good reason, keep them locked in cages. But it isn't as if Man is doing so well even without the Psychlos. We're living in caves again and nobody has developed proper grooming standards. That's the premise. There isn't really a plot beyond the fact that Johnny Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper) wants to lead a rebellion and Terl (Travolta), the Psychlo Security guru, wants to stop him. Things blow up, people say stupid things, and there's a stupid subplot involving Ker, another Psychlo played by Forrest Whitaker, who must have desperately needed this paycheck.There isn't a single piece of the alien technology that looks cool, or even interesting. That's a flaw for a science fiction film. Similarly, none of the images of destroyed humanity (like the shell of the Denver Public Library, or an old mini-golf course) are the least bit evocative. That's a flaw for a post-apocalyptic drama. And none of the action scenes achieve any kind of pacing or momentum. And that's a problem for any film.For some strange reason virtually every shot in the film is at a jarring angle. If Christian's point is that this is a world askew, he probably could have made it was one slightly tilted camera angle. Instead, the artistic pretension just seems silly. Ditto the lengths Christian has to go to to make us believe that the Psychlos are really tall. He'd have been better off using actors in stilts rather than the low angle shots and other tricks he uses. Also, is there any reason why the film keeps going back to slow motion over and over? Slow motion, even used in moderation, is kinda tacky, but it just pulls me out of an action sequence when you add that level of contrievance.While Barry Pepper's performance is just awful, I have no way of telling what the blazes John Travolta is doing. He speaks with a strange stilted accent (British, not Psychlo), his hand gestures are wooden, befitting the silly suit he's wearing, and it all just smells like a bad Saturday Night Live skit performance. Remember the skit where he played a potentially gay vampire? Imagine that gay vampire in an alien suit in a really horrible movie and that's what you have here. My point is that Travolta is funny. Sometimes the humor is intentional (the scene where the Psychlo discover the Man-Animals' food of choice is a hoot), but why does he keep using the word leverage? I kept waiting for Inigo Montoya to arrive from the Princess Bride saying, "I do not think that world means what you think it means." It's all just a mess.I watched the movie with a friend who has extensive experience with film editing and he insists that Battlefield Earth was fairly well edited because it looked like the cutting covered up a lot of even worse work. So with that in mind, congrats to Robin Russell for her excellent work on a 1/10 mess.

reviews.review_title: An epic sci-fi story gone wrong
reviews.content: As a science fiction story it has an interesting premise, but the film captures it in a rather poor way. It takes certain elements of Scientology such as using the Psychlos as allegories of psychologists who, according to Scientology, only seek to control the human mind and without forgetting to mention alien life as the true creator of humanity. It's a simple story of a future dominated by aliens and humanity's struggle to reclaim their world. It's a pretty good story for a sci-fi epic, but sadly despite the budget, this movie failed to materialize this story in the way it should have been. Most of the characters are very basic and generic without much depth. Travolta's character is seriously a cartoon character to the point where he becomes inept and is funny instead of intimidating. Only the character of Forest Whitaker shows some common sense. The directing and editing are so rampant to the point where you can get lost and have to use your imagination to figure out what's going on. It is as if the film were trying to make the viewer dizzy. The slow-motion sequences are really good, but you have to keep up or they seem eternal. The digital effects are basic and simple which makes this movie made only for home format. The script is seriously quite mediocre since there are certain inconsistencies, holes and some errors that make one wonder how such a thing could happen. There are even things that become meaningless. Battlefield Earth is a movie that you either have to watch with your brain turned off and let yourself be carried away by the action it has or you have to use your imagination to understand things that it doesn't fully explain. It is not the worst movie that has ever existed since at least the story is good, but it has so many flaws in its development that it ends up being a mediocre movie that few can like. Even so, it is a rather rare and bizarre tape that turns out to be entertaining and more so because of Travolta's overperformance that sadly ended his career, but at least he left a villain so cartoonish and funny that it is not easy to forget. My final rating for this movie is 6/10.

OK, I've read a few positive reviews on here, people saying "it's not that bad" & "you only hate it because you expected it to be great" etc. Let me just say, I didn't expect anything one way or the other from it. I didn't know anything about it, & rented it on a whim. It is terrible. It is so bad, there are few words that can describe it. To anyone who liked this movie, even moderately, I say this: this movie is filled with plot holes & shoddy film making, to an unbelievable extent. Please think about what you are watching. This movie cost over $70,000,000 & it grossed $21,000,000. I know box office results are petty & a poor indicator of a good movie, because some of the best movies ever made have been unsuccessful in their own times, but this movie was unsuccessful because it just plain sucks! This is one instance when the mass movie going public is correct. It didn't make much money because it is a very poorly made movie. If you haven't seen it, go watch it, & actually think about what you are watching. There are a lot of terrible movies out there, & many of them cost a lot of money, but this movie fails on every single principle of film making. The acting, the writing, the directing, the sfx, the camera work, you name it. I'm all for movies that are mindless & entertaining, even stupid at times. But this movie is bad because it was pretending to actually be smart. It was a vanity project that was trying to make a point, but instead just makes a mess of itself.

Filming a shoe for an hour and a half would earn a 1 out of 10, so I'll give it a 2 for that. It DID have entertainment value, but...I found myself so confused at times, and not just confused, but completely lost, struggling, for long periods of time, trying to make SENSE of what was actually taking place.Often during the movie I amused myself pretending it was an adventurous role playing computer game, and that i was watching someone play, and those cheesy dialogs unfold.Yes, I can honestly say that it was very amusing to watch, I laughed a lot actually, and I'm glad I took the time to watch it!The movie should definitely come with a warning though, something in the lines of danger of damage to the mind itself. Some of the scenes were so confusing you see, so confusing... made no sense... no sense... did I mention that?But whatever, some kid's shows are more confusing and definitely worse in general, and you've seen them, so go ahead, watch the movie just for the RUSH!

This is the movie you can't miss. I've always felt like I don't belong and sad and stuff. This movie makes you feel good and shows you the way. I now base the way I do my hair after the way Terl does his. The plot is very exciting and all, but it's the messages about life that will keep you coming back again and again. I don't want to ruin the plot for those who haven't seen the movie yet (you'll thank me later) but this was the role that put John Travolta back on top after he almost ruined his career starring in that flop, Pulp Fiction. This movie is wall to wall excitement and perfect for anyone with an open mind and an open brain. I invite anyone and everyone who doesn't agree with my review to e-mail me telling me why I'm wrong. That's what I thought.
It is not bad movie. I'm so surprised by the low rating. It doesn't deserve to be this low on the list. I really like the movie. It interesting, fun, and not boring at all, I enjoy watching it.

reviews.review_title: I only had to pay 50 cents to see this ha ha ha
reviews.content: Because I only paid 50 cents to see this piece of garbage I will be more generous than the other unfortunates who saw this movie.  I gave it a 5 based on the fact that I loved the way this movie looked. I also love the guy who played the hero and my hormones made me give it a 5 based on that. Am I a movie critic? No....Am I switchboard operator with too much time on my hands....yes.  I wouldn't suggest seeing this movie unless you can see it for the low low price of 50 cents. Even then I'd suggest not wasting your time.

Interest in the start is pretty high, the way they talk about the gods and Jonnie's character is Ok too, he comes across the hunters and then they get captured. Travolta still has that excruciatingly annoying 'dependable cool' thing going only with twice his body weight's load of makeup on. It is utterly ridiculous that the species managed to destroy the human race or most of it and let alone in 9 minutes. And if Terl/Travolta graduated the top of his class it baffles me to think what the low acheivers are like.Jonnie starts off Ok and remains pretty Ok throughout 80% of the flick but the ending is where this thing really de-rails.WARNING: SPOILERS PATROL BEYOND THIS POINTHow the hell could a species who had never before worn anything more than animal coverings or used a gun learn how to fly harrier jump jets, let alone in 7 days, and how did power stay, where was it coming from and how did the global leveling have no effect on the condition of the craft or the instructing machine. If the movie took two hours to get to that point how boring must the 1000+ page novel be. By the way, a previous reviewer named Star Wars EI and The Matrix as writing creditors, way too recent to be named, this movie would have taken two years to make, these books came out in the 80's but if the movie is anything to go by they are a splicing of Star Wars E4 and Planet Of The Apes, they borrowed much of the human-psychlo situation and relationship from POTA and the climax and humans fighting back is lifted straight from Star Wars.This page must currently hold a record. The fifth comment down is the most recent one to speak for the negative. You'll find a crowd rebel on every page looking to make a statement against the rest not supply truth about the flick, but it's funny I don't think I have heard the "too inteligent to be appreciated" line used seriously before. One major plus however is the quality and scope of it's effects, they really are something special and I am surprised this was not nominated for them. This flick has only them to recommend it however.4.5/10.

This has got to be the worst movie of all time. Even Ed Wood's films are better. Taking out the plot, the actors, the director, the screenwriter, the novelist, the producers, the special effects, and anyone else involved in conceiving this, it was a great movie. WARNING: If you see this movie, your IQ may be lowered to hideous averages.

reviews.review_title: Wow--I found it to be totally entertaining, great story!!!
reviews.content: This was an exciting film about human efforts to survive against all odds. I particularly enjoyed the visuals in the movie including the costumes of the aliens.  This movie presents to us the actual possibility of conditions man would face should earth be overrun by a more technologically advanced race.  The acting was excellent by Travolta, Whitaker, and Pepper.  Their roles must have been a real challenge given the uniqueness of the characters.  I enjoyed every minute of this movie and highly recommend it to others--it is fast paced, humorous, and thought stimulating.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as it seemed.
reviews.content: Ok, it's not among the best movies I have seen but it's far away from the worst ones. I both read and heard some terrifying stuff about this movie before I decided to rent it on video and see it and then decide if it really was that bad. After seeing Armageddon I braced my self!As you see I had no high expectations about this move, I had read the book many years ago I thought it was really great book despite it was written by L. Ron Hubbard and I imagined it would be hard to make a movie about the story. Maybe it was good that I read the book so many years ago so I lost the imaginary image I had about the characters in the book but I remember that the Psychlos was supposed to look really grotesque! But in the movie they only acted bad, they didn't look repelling enough to be believable and that is pretty fundamental for the story.I was pleased to discover that the move wasn't half as bad as the earlier mentioned Armageddon and despite some over exaggerated scenes the movie was quite enjoyable and the story pretty engaging. The story was however very compressed and I can see that considering the move was 'only' about 2h long.I was expecting a B movie style special effects but even the special FX was better then I had expected. Some of the actors was not so good but what movie doesn't have it's share of them?Summary: If you like SciFi and have a couple of hours to spend I can recommend this movie.

Friggin' halarious review! thanks.Now that this clunker is gone from the theaters and has made only $22 Mill out of its $100 Mill budget, the director is currently trying to backpedal, stating that its cost was only about $50 Mill....either way, after foriegn markets and home video, BFE MAY just break even...then again, maybe not.

reviews.review_title: a new place in the classics
reviews.content: This is another classical movie. (Sorry, if it spoils your idea of a good movie) But it does exist, and is good stuff in its way.I'don't know why, but I like it!Perhaps it is the book. Could we take it seriously?It is just fun.Please, enjoy it. Don't analyze it! It is not for thinking.It is like "The Return of the Living Dead" they originally made it for fun. Don't take it personal!I believe that art is appreciated in a relaxed state. Some films are more artistic than others, so what?Perhaps, they should put this film in the Type B quality. So what?It might be a matter of taste. I like it! (sorry buy I had to reach the 10 lines limit to get this posted)

reviews.review_title: A Film That Was More Of A Battlefield When Making It
reviews.content: Never, in the history of motion pictures, have I seen a film that is as bad as it is slated, until now. This piece of cinematic tripe is one of the worst films I have ever seen with my own two eyes, and the fact that is only at number 44 in The Internet Movie Database's 100 worst films list makes me wonder what on earth the other top 43 films are like.I have no sympathy for anyone making, or related to anyone involved, in this battlefield of a project. First of all, the script is a right and honourable flawed, with some of the most irritating insults I have ever hear, and one of the most annoying and poor insult in the history of cinema on a repeatable basis. I was fed up by the number of times I heard "rat brain" from Travolta's screen-hogging character, that I lost faith in listening to another line of dialogue ever again in this film with tolerance.And you thought slating the script was going to be my main argument for this appalling film. Well, you will be wrong. That is only the tip of the iceberg of such rubbish! The imagery made things so bland and flat, that if failed to make me understand what is going on throughout the whole film, which is has not been helped in the least by some of the most shoddy slow-motion effects I have ever seen, especially when it comes to seeing those long-hair humans getting hunted down by an alien is extremely dull.
