Even a fly landing on the TV screen would have been more entertaining to watch then that sequence, and, while I am still slating it, for the rest of the bland sci-fi action.The effects don't do justice either, as I have seen more better effects in films made 40-50 years ago then watching the attempt of some poor blue-screen work making some scenes in it almost unbelievable. Moreover, if anyone finds this effects believable should seek therapy immediately for the sake of humankind! Well, that's it! I am even fed up of writing a review of this film, so I want to conclude as quickly this film grabbed my attention, which was not that long! This film is an insult to sci-fi film-making, I will never trust John Travolta as a respectable actor after a performance so poor as that, and I advise anyone that really wants to watch it, to view something else, with effects that are more effective (The Day the Earth Stood Still, anyone?), a film with better imagery (like 2001:A Space Odyssey), or has a script with sharper dialogue (may I suggest Aliens for this one, for its much better insults to the aliens.) And, have I mentioned that it is definitely the worst film I have ever seen? I have? Good. I shall leave you to watch this film at your own risk.

reviews.review_title: Deeply flawed and illogical, but free of Star Trek soap-operatics.
reviews.content: The general concensus is that this is a terrible film - and the general concensus is right. Imagine Independence Day (a slice of crud livened up by several charismatic actors) without the occasional wit and operatic drama. Imagine the TV show Falcon's Crest, with aliens. Imagine if Ray Liotta's character in HANNIBAL, after having his brains fed to him by Doctor Lecter, decided to adapt a generic sci-fi novel for the screen. This is the sort of dross he'd probably have created.Let's start with the plot, because it's a real hoot. Aliens have taken over the earth, and enslaved mankind. Originally they enslave dogs, but are surprised to find out that they are ill-suited to manual labour. Uh-huh. Despite their awesome technology, the aliens are about as intelligent as - hey, whose idea was it to adapt an L Ron Hubbard novel again?The film is deeply illogical. We humans (called "man animals" by the aliens, which in itself is both stupid and illogical) made a last stand, using fighter jets and tanks, before the Psychlos conquered our puny armies. However, the aliens are baffled when a human gets hold of one of their weapons and manages to work out how to use it against them. Hello! We had tanks and planes, remember? It's not rocket science to pull a trigger.The one thing worth praising about this film is that it is free from Star Trek TNG hokum. There are no proton torpedos that can be reconfigured to solve any possible problem, no matter how absurd, nor are there any cringe-worthy nosedives into soap-opera territory that so plague the Star Trek spin-offs. However, this is a small blessing. Battlefield Earth is certainly not the saviour of contemporary sci-fi. It is a stupid film, riddled with rubbish that should have been abandoned in the rough-draft stages.Shame on you, Johnny T. Here's one film that certainly won't stay alive.

reviews.review_title: Only the special effects are good
reviews.content: Stinks on ice. Made only for the affection some had/have for the author of the book which is a terrible book.Derivative, with an agenda that appeals only to a minority of opinions. Produced, I suspect, only because of energetic arm-twisting and outright dis-information.Fortunately the book reads quickly since no deep thinking is needed. Sitting through this film might be done on fast-scan but why bother.This was a task of love for some honoring an eccentric whose other more philosophical works are also derivative.Devotees and victims of inbreeding could enjoy this but I suspect that few of the former would find this interesting. Well, die-hard Travolta fans might. This man is a sometimes superb actor and some of his efforts are on my favorites list -- NOT this one.

I consider this movie to be a hyped-up television series. These types of movies should go straight to video. Don't get me wrong, the movie was enjoyable, yet not at all good. I had too many unanswered questions; situations were undeveloped and left for assumptions. No part of this movie impressed me. 'Battlefield Earth'... wrong title for this movie. A good-old Star-Trek episode will do.

reviews.review_title: Two hours of my life that I'll never get back - wasted
reviews.content: We've all seen films that are so bad that we've sat back and enjoyed them for their badness. This isn't one of those films - it's just mind-numbingly awful. The acting is uniformly terrible and the script is ludicrous: it brings to mind a bad Saturday Night Live sketch stretched out to two hours. The cinematography is downright poor - the whole film is drab and much of the time you can't tell who's doing what to whom. The sound is so loud that it gave me a headache - but at least it drowned out some of the inane dialogue. When a Turkey like this is served up, can Thanksgiving be very far away?

The combination of creative camera angles, sets, sound track, among other elements make this movie unique.  I can see how some would not be comfortable with the atmosphere created by it's director but I found it edgy. Forget the critics and their carping, see it for yourself.

reviews.review_title: The long lost brother of "Manos, Hands of Fate"
reviews.content: I'm a pretty huge sci-fi fan, so I'll try any sci-fi movie at least once.  So, when I was stalking around the video store on a Friday night, I thought that "Battlefield Earth," would be a good thriller to keep me awake. I mean, how bad could it be?I've decided to stop renting movies.Not really, but I have decided to stop assuming that all sci-fi movies have something good about them.  The cover of this particular video falsely hints at a film with plenty of clever action to cover up a most-likely thin plot. Well, I was right about one thing.Yes, the movie does have action; in fact, the last half hour of the movie is crammed with large-scale battle scenes, including an eye-appealing dogfight between alien ships and harrier fighters (I'm not even going to ask what BRITISH-MADE harriers are doing in the UNITED STATES).  But, as so many movies have shown us before, expensive special effects cannot always cover up a really, truly, AWFUL movie.  Believe me, no film to date can attest to this as much as "Battlefield Earth."  The story isn't the problem; as a matter of fact, L. Ron Hubbard's idea of an alien-controlled Earth in the next millennium is quite intriguing for a sci-fi audience.  It's just the horrible way the film was made that makes it, shall I say, Mystery Science Theater material.First, the movie plows right into an already underdeveloped plot, giving virtually no background for the main character (an achingly bad actor with whom one finds it very hard to sympathize).  Then it continues on, boring its audience with unbelievable plot twists and annoying scenes transitions, each one with a screen wipe.  What's with that?Anyway, I am essentially trying to tell those of you out there who find some of these bad movies intriguing, beware.  It is rarely, if ever, worth it.

reviews.review_title: read the book(s) before you watch this one...
reviews.content: Have you read L. Ron Hubbard's 'Battlefield Earth'? Do even know who this man was? Ever heard about the Church Of Scientology? Well, Hubbard was the man who created that church. I suggest you read the book and then watch the movie...Now, about this film. It's not bad. I loved the book and I loved the movie. The only thing that bothered me was that the movie was too short. Over 1500 pages of a great sci-fi novel in a 117 minute-movie. All other - the acting, cam work, effects, R. Christian vision of the novel - was great.I have to admit that I like b-class sci-fi movies, but knowing the backgrounds of this film, one thing is sure - it's not worth 2 out of 10. I'll give it a fair 8.And to all of you out there. Read the book before you vote!

This movie is so bad, it defies description.The experience starts with the back of the movie box which extols the virtues of Battlefield Earth. These include, but are not limited to, "An entirely new style of science fiction film-making", "Good scene transitions", and (my personal favorite), action that will leave you "exhausted". Sadly, the box said nothing about inane dialogue, ineffably awful acting, and a plot that has so many holes in it, it could be used to strain spaghetti. In my opinion, before watching this movie, you must check the logic centre of your brain at the door, lest it shut down permanently from the strain of trying to make sense of the fact that a highly technologically advanced alien species was still unable to discover Fort Knox.If you want a fun drinking game (and I firmly believe that generous quantities of alcohol can only improve the viewing experience) take a drink/shot every time a Psychlon says the phrase "Man-Animals", and every time you catch a glimpse of John Travolta's and Forrest Whitakker's grotesquely over-sized...uh...packages.Speaking of Forrest Whitakker, the man is an Oscar winner. Did he not know what he was getting himself into? Why did he stay once he realized what was going on around him. Some of his dialogue seems like a cry for help. It's unfortunate that his career had to suffer through this movie, although maybe it's just as well that he got it out of the way early. Unlike John Travolta.Improbably, Travolta is worse in Battlefield Earth than he was in Broken Arrow. The man puts in the performance of a lifetime, an awful performance in what he must have known was an awful movie.I have run out of words. If you really must watch this movie, watch it with a group of people with whom you can mercilessly tear it to shreds. At least you'll get some enjoyment out of it that way. I still have not mentioned the forgettable score, bad editing, and terrible cinematography which seems to live in mortal fear of any shots that occur at a completely vertical angle. Now I have. Don't say I didn't warn you.

reviews.review_title: Battlefield Earth great, fun action movie. Highly recommend.
reviews.content: I really enjoyed Battlefield Earth. I was quite literally on the edge of my seat much of the time. The story and action moved very well. It was a great story of overcoming seemingly impossible odds. I Thoroughly enjoyed it and will see it again. I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: A lot of great action. Enjoyed it thoroughly.
reviews.content: I completely enjoyed this movie. The action moved very well and I wasn't bored for a moment. It was so well put  together technically that I definitely want to see it again. I liked the story line. It showed how intention to do something wins out over all odds. I recommend it to any free-thinking individual who wants to have a great time at the movies!!!

reviews.review_title: Did they even bother to READ the book?
reviews.content: I have been Robbed... Battlefield Earth is one of the very few books, that I faithfully read every year. It's one book, that could keep you glued to your chair, page after page after page. The movie does not only take liberties with the plot and subplots, but totally invents new characters and devices. Changes the whole meaning of the story. I feel SICK, sick at the thought that so many people will see this crap.. and think that it could be based upon the book. I waited for twenty-five years for the Movie.  Now I hope to live long enough for a remake..       Save Your Money. READ THE BOOK...

I didn't find the film to be as bad as I expected but this may simply be because I had lowered my expectations so much as a result of the bad reviews that anything would be an improvement. I felt that the film made a promising start indicating an interesting, although not original, plot about a defeated humanity fighting back against alien invaders. It then seemed to lose its way.The Psychlos look like derivatives of the klingons and John Travolta seems to overact. The manner in which the humans gain knowledge, the utter stupidity of the Psychlos in giving them that knowledge and the amazing way in which ancient aircraft were still airworthy (among other things) raises questions about the film.Having said all of this, I repeat that I didn't find it quiet as bad as I was led to expect. I still however, regard it as one of the misses of the year.

reviews.review_title: Costner should thank Travolta b/c the Postman is no longer the worst Sci-Fi film ever!!
reviews.content:
I came back from this "film" a couple of hours ago, and I have been trying to find words to explain this film.  I had read all of the reviews beforehand saying how awfully horrible it was, and I went in with that mindset.  I was planning on treating it like Plan 9 from Outer Space or The Rocky Horror Picture Show, or Showgirls, movies that were supposed to be serious, but were so bad were funny.  I couldn't even do that.There is not a single redeeming element in this film.Travolta has been saying ad nauseum that this film has nothing to do with Scientology.  However, it is inconceivable how anyone who was not brainwashed by a cult would make this thing.  If this was a Heinlin or Phillip K. Dick book, Travolta wouldn't have been fighting to make it.
Look Who's Talking 6 would have been a better career move.

"Battlefield Earth" was probably one of the worst sci-fi movies I've ever seen in my life.  After the first hour of the film, people in the cinema walked out in disgust that they wasted their $10.50 to see this garbage.  I admit, the special effects were one of the best effects I've seen in a long time, but what so good about the special effects if there's no storyline to back it up? Take "Star Trek", "Star Wars", and "Independence Day" and you get "Battlefield Earth", nothings original.  My advice to you people out there is, save your hard earned money, and go see "Gladiator." If you want to see a classic, then watch "Independence Day" and any of the "Star Wars" sequels.  oh, did I forget to mention that the acting was even worse than the movie? Come on "John", you can do better than that!

...this has to be THE number one worst movie ever. I mean, they had a budget, they had a few actors, they had a funny neo-religious sect... I was expecting at least a good laugh but I wouldn't even recommend this crap to ... Ron Hubbard.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as I heard, but I still walked out.
reviews.content: Poor John Travolta, his directing ability will be listed with names like Ed Wood and William Shatner. I really wanted to like this movie, hoping against hope that the critics were wrong. Turns out they weren't that far off. As I feared, this movie is more disappointing than "The Postman". After seeing this, I have come to two possible conclusions: 1) John Travolta, talented actor he may be, cannot direct worth a dime.2) L. Ron Hubbards' brilliant science fiction writing cannot be simply translated into another "Independence Day". If Travolta had bothered to throw in a scene or two of how Johnny and his band managed to get those harrier jets working, electricity restored, etc., I would have sat through it. I also find it hard to believe that some uneducated tribe members can learn to fly harrier jets better than air force pilots in a week. If it was Travolta's intent to dumb down the translation from book to film, he overdid it. Travolta manages to insult his audience by leaving gaping holes in logic and storyline, laughable scripts and dialogue. Don't worry about any subliminal Scientology messages, the film isn't that sophisticated. If you read the book, don't see the  movie. Save yourself the disappointment and retain the good memories you have of the book.

If you've read the book you'll be extremely disappointed in this movie, If you havent read the book not only will you be disappointed but you'll be confused as well. Basic plot lines from the book were completely skipped over in order to speed through the movie, in doing so they've made it so confusing to follow that without reading the book you may miss have the movie. They've left it wide open for a sequel that, hopefully wont be done.

I enjoy a lot of movies, I generally see something worthwhile in most films I watch through to the end. But there are some films I switch off prior to ending (like the recent Tom Hanks film The Ladykillers), and for the most part I cannot be bothered even rating those films. I quite liked the book Battlefield Earth. So I thought I'd give this film another chance, (I fell asleep during the first attempt) but it really is a waste of time. Watch Hudson Hawk instead - that, at least, does not take itself seriously. Even with a recent re-read of the book I found it difficult to follow the story. Battlefield Earth is a confused, incoherent movie that deserves to be given a wide-berth.

reviews.review_title: Fun Flick, fast paced, gotta love those psychlos!
reviews.content:
I read a number of the other reviews here and thought, are these guys for real!?! Maybe I wandered into "Frustrated film critics school," whatever! Its a science fiction film and no doubt will become a cult classic. Terl and Ker are "Moe and Shemp" I was wondering what happened to "Larry." (I loved them, they were worth the price of admission alone.)So down to the film. I read Battlefield Earth when it came out. I felt that Travolta and crew were wise to break the book into two parts and cut the story at the correct point.The book itself runs as the movie does. Lots of action, the movie is basically one long action sequence. The movie presents Hubbard's satircal humor well and if you have not read B'Earth (as most of those commenting here) and are into fiiillmmm (as it seems most commenting here are) then you will be too busy trying to figure out "why the film angle?" or looking for "subliminals" that some idiot claimed were in the movie. So what is the movie? A huge fun rollercoaster ride! Loud explosive alien idiocy, killer effects and of course...good triumphs over evil!
Sci-Fi as it should be!

If you can only afford one big-buck spectacular this week, then take my advice and go to see GLADIATOR instead. The makers of this mess (and John Travolta has to shoulder a large part of the blame here) seem to lack an original idea between them. Some of the special effects are poorly executed, the plot (such as it is) has more holes in it than a Swiss cheese, and the dialogue is cliched and laughable throughout. Travolta spends most of his time slapping around the other actors and his performance is light-years away from the finely judged delivery of THE GENERAL'S DAUGHTER,or GET SHORTY. But then his mis-understanding of good science fiction is already well-known from his public comments about Hubbard's novel being one of the keystones of modern SF. Oh yeah? Roger Christian's sole contribution to this mess seems to involve shooting everything in slow-motion. There's no feeling for character development, or respect for the audience's intelligence. Seeing this movie took over two hours of my life that I will never get back. Don't you make the same mistake.

This movie never should have been made. Travolta has tarnished his image as a box office big hitter with this dud. The movie doesn't make sense. The aliens come to earth and wipe us out in a matter of days and now a band of cavemen who can barely speak learn how to fly harrier jets in 9 hours and take back the earth and blow up the aliens home planet. The story (if you can call it one) takes you nowhere and it seems like there are scenes missing from the story. Go see Gladiator for a second or third time instead of seeing this movie

reviews.review_title: Most one-liners have a better story then this movie
reviews.content: The acting in this movie is not bad neither are the special effects or the camera work. The story on the other hand is one of the worst I have ever seen. I myself am a fan of sci-fi movies and books and although not every sci-fi writer is known here I have never seen a book for L Ron Hubbard in the book stores in the sci-fi department. I wonder why? Well after seeing the movie you will know why. This movie could be seen as the perfect example of how to use good actors and good special effects and end up with one of the worst movies ever. A must see if you are in to that kind of movies.

I'd heard so much how this movie was bad and just had to see how awful it could be. In retrospect I don't think that this movie should have been made. Not because it's contains an unworthy plot, but simply because an hour and a half cannot possibly do a story this complex justice.Ultimately, it's obvious that the original story takes place over a much larger timespan than depicted here. Basically, stories this large, for example 'Dune' cannot be told in the amount of detail necessary to do them justice.Another problem with this format is that the 'bad guys' always come over comic-book style. I've read all the great science-fiction authors, and characters are almost never written like this. I guess it's just one more example of Hollywood's dumbing down of America.

I am a huge sci-fi fan, and there are times that I love to watch really bad sci-fi movies and TV shows, but Battlefield Earth goes far far beyond just being bad. This movie is so unwatchable, it gives bad movies a really really bad name. Yes, the special effect are great, but the story and the dialoge and just about everything else about it is, well, how do I say this: horrid, a waste of film, about as much fun as a root-canal without novicane. While watching this excrement, I think that one can actually hear their brain cells dying. This movie makes Plan 9 From Outer Space look like Hamlet. Truly, the absolute worst of the worst. (and I'm a sci-fi fan)

This is the one and only movie I've ever seen that I would say is "so bad it's good". Usually the novelty of these movies wear off really fast . This movie was so stupid that i couldn't help but be entertained by it

No words can describe how terrible this movie was.  The effects were poor, the acting was bad, the story was terrible, and the physics were horrific. There were scenes stolen directly out of Braveheart and the Matrix.  Under no circumstances should anyone ever be forced to see this movie.  John Travolta put his heart and soul into this film and it is nothing more than a joke.  Very, very sad.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, skip the movie
reviews.content: OK so I bought the book at Barnes & Noble for a buck because well, it was a buck. I did a little online research about it and found that a lot of people liked the book and pretty much everyone hated the movie so I decided to go into the reading of the book with an open mind. I'm so glad I did! The book is awesome! It's a damn good read and I would and have recommended to my friends. So then I decided today that maybe the movie isn't as bad as everyone says, especially for someone who's read the book... uh wrong. The movie strays so far off from the book that it's at times unrecognizable as the same story. The scenes look like they were set up by a high school student that is studying to be in film and the acting is well, atrocious.My advice is read the book and enjoy. Don't waste your time on the movie.

What I can't figure out is how such an amazing Si-if book could be so badly turned into a screen play. This book needed the Peet Jackson treatment, but instead got mutated into some weird Frankenstein of a re-write. L.Ron Hubbard would roll in his grave if he was forced to watch his masterpiece be mutilated in such a poor fashion. The screen writer (Corey Mandell) and ultimately John Travolta, who produced the film, departed from the script so often, that any fan of the original book is bound to be disgusted. Often times in screen play adaptation, it is necessary to change portions of the original book to better suit the film going audience. However, in this case, they might as well have renamed the film and not credited the original author. There are so many bad choices in the form of cuts and additions, that the film in no way resembles the original piece which inspired it. In fact if Hubbard was alive today, I would wager he would disassociate himself from the film work entirely. I personally loved the book and disagree with screen writer Corey Mandell, who stated that the original book was "clunky and the dialog awkward." In fact his adaptation, coupled by the worst direction of any big budget Si-Fi movie ever, is the only "clunky" thing in the room.For example, The idea of Phyclos looking exactly like humans on stilts in 70's lift shoes, is a total embarrassment to all costume designers everywhere. In fact the awful costuming, dismal set design, and off kilter cinematography, totally killed any real fear that Hubbard intended to create when he wrote the world of Phyclos into existence. In addition, the use of 1000 year old Earth tech to overcome the Pyclo's is ridiculously unbelievable. In what reality would 1000 year old fighter jets fire up and destroy a Psyclo compound? Finally, the movie starts with green letters flashing across the screen. They say,"Man is an endangered species". The weird thing is that the idea never comes up again. In the book Hubbard dances on that string as a steady dis-tonic note of fear throughout the story line. Mandell totally fails the audience, by not keeping the essence of that tension in the film. Truth be told. The only way to really recreate Hubbard's work on the big screen, would be by breaking it up into 3 full length movies. Conveniently, Hubbard writes the book in 3 distinct sections. He starts with a fractured picture of humanity hanging by a thread. Moves into a section where a thousand years of lost knowledge is recovered and fragmented society is reconnected. Then finishes with a twist when Humanity crushes Phyclo, but then has to fight to stay afloat in galaxy filled with alien races out to fill the void left by the fall of Phyclo. It all ends with a huge political grand finally, where Earth emerges as a universal leader, and humanity is saved.In truth, one real criticism of the book is that it starts out a touch slow. But, after chapter 1 goes into high gear for 1,000 amazing pages. However, the first chapter info is very important to the plot. A creative way to have handled that issue would have been to filter that info into the first and second movie via flash backs. In that way the movie could have started off at a strong pace that would grab a film audiences attention, but still kept the integrity of the story. Any way you slice it up, there is no possibility of packing an Epic novel like Battlefield Earth into a 120 minute quick flick.To boil it all down to the lowest common denominator. The only thing Epic about this movie is how epically it fails all film goers. Whether you are a fan of the book or not, this film was so badly made it fails us all. I highly recommend the book if you are a Si-Fi reader. You will love it! For years it has wowed new and old readers alike. If all you have seen regarding Battlefield Earth is this film, you are missing out. If you haven't yet seen the film, skip it and go to the source. You will be happy you did.

reviews.review_title: I've no idea how many times I have read the book
reviews.content: I've no idea how many times I've read the book that this movie is supposed to be based on.  But I've read it enough times to be rather familiar with it.  As such I was *very* disappointed with the movie.  Sure, it had some of the same characters (but only some - where was Brown Limper?  I was quite looking forward to see who got picked for that part), it was set in about the right area, and the bare basic story was about right (but only the absolute basics - humans trying to retake their world from aliens. Practically *all* of the subplots from the book were missing).However, right at the very beginning the movie starts deviating from the book.  And it goes downhill from there.  Most of the happenings in the movie bore absolutely *no* resemblance to *anything* in the book.  How Terl captured Johnny, the vehicles used, where all the other "man-animals" came from, the layout of the company complex, the size of the Psychlos, the relation between Terl and Ker, how Johnny got the bomb to Psychlo, where the humans got the gold - none of these happenings in the movie bore any resemblance to the book.  They weren't even close.When viewed as just a movie, it wasn't too bad.  I'd say about a 7 out of 10.  The FX were pretty good, and (as much as I hate to admit this) Travolta did quite a good job as Terl.  But when viewed as a movie adaptation of the book, it was a miserable flop - 2 out of 10.  The only thing saving it from a 1 was, again, the FX and Travolta's portrayal of Terl.  This was such a bad adaptation it was almost unrecognizable as such.

I'm not one to talk about things like continuity or editing or plot holes. After all... I live off of the hi-gloss, Jerry Bruckheimer, Hollywood varnished, roller coaster movies as much as any true MOVIEgoer, but really... I could've had a V8  This was SOOOO bad!  I was AMAZED at how bad this movie was.  I literally looked at my girlfriend and almost apologized for having paid full price for it.I WANT MY MONEY BACK.

Although the movie did not follow the book as it could have, it still had some great Sci-Fi effects.  That is what should be discussed regarding this movie.  Any true Sci-Fi fan would love the sets, costumes, and special effects.  And - any true Sci-Fi fan would know that the book is one of the best in its genre!

reviews.review_title: A rating of 1 is too high.
reviews.content: This is clearly the worst film ever put in a can. It had no chance from the start. When you have an idiot for the original writer and then you have a screenwriter that hasn't produced a screenplay for nineteen years, bad things are bound to happen. This doesn't even take into account that several actors produced their career worst performances, and you have this pile of poop!I would warn you that I am about to issue a spoiler but there is nothing to spoil. Travolta is his normal lame self in front of the camera but both Pepper and Whitaker shocked me with how little they did with their characters. I don't hold them to blame as this script is so bad, they had little to nothing to work with.

reviews.review_title: Get a life - it's not that bad!
reviews.content: Yes it's a shame the talented Mr Travolta and his occasionally respectable cast were allowed to spend quite so much time and money on this sporadically fun and occasionally visually impressive film.  But if you want to talk wasted time, didn't anyone else see "Eyes Wide Shut"?  And what about the months and millions of dollars ploughed into "End of Days"?  The second worst thing about "Battlefield Earth" is really just how mediocre it is. The worst is the huge pile of cash I'm sure the star took home regardless, but Mel Gibson costs more and often delivers equally average goods.  Did you all miss the over-rated, over-wrought and lamentably over-here historical fantasy "The Patriot"?Don't be led like sheep by movie snobs whose cleverer friends have told them about holes in the plot.  Most of the worst parts are lifted straight from the book, and they've been a standing joke in the science-fiction world for years.  This is just a very old-fashioned no-brainer science fiction movie, a direct descendant of "Logan's Run".  Nothing here is any dumber than Will Smith learning to fly a UFO in half an hour or the galactically stupid "plug my laptop into the mothership and download a computer virus" climax in "Independence Day".  Its weaknesses are mainly laziness, but how does that make it different from most other studio product these days?  It's a bit of a laugh, it's certainly not the worst film ever made, and it makes more sense than Three Colours Blue.  Or Les Aimants de Pont Neuf.  Or The Patriot.

I wish I could have put a 0 down for the score of this piece of bile. I feel sorry for anyone else who actually paid to see this in the theatre or rental. I rented it and demanded my money back. John Travolta should really kill himself for making a steaming pile like this. I have never been more disgusted in my life. To think that man has survived for thousands of years only to revert back to wearing loin cloths and being slaves of an alien race far to stupid to even figure out space travel. It just proves a point that scientologists really need to rethink their belief system. Not only that but they should just follow suit and kill themselves with Travolta. If you really need something to base a religion around and worship or whatever you do...realize that religion and science will never go together. IT JUST DOESN'T FIT.

This is, safe to say, the worst movie I have seen.  Filled with cliche lines by stars I once respected (John Travolta and Forest Whitaker) and incredibly cheesy scenes that were supposed to be dramatic, this movie made me (along with rest of the audience) laugh out loud at how amazingly terrible it was and thank our lucky stars when it finally ended.

Other than a plot full of ridiculous, laughable scientific blunders, characters you don't even know the name of by the end of the film, terrible acting, pointless and offensively melodrama dressed up as painful poignance, massive logical holes in the premise, bad special effects despite a seemingly massive budget, the worst dialogue i've ever seen, badly strung together directing and editing that doesn't allow you to follow the plot and a ridiculous political pseudo-religious subtext, this movie is actually quite good.L Ron Hubbard; "I know. I'm going to set a film in the future, where man are cavemen living in the hills behind stockades made of wood while aliens rape their planet for gold for no real reason. Then, they'll rebel, steal a load of harrier jump jets, nukes, guns and stuff, learn to use them, and take back Earth from the aliens, even though the original battle to take earth took nine minutes to wipe out most of humankind..."

reviews.review_title: What's up with this? Not everyone has to be a critic.
reviews.content: What's up with this? Of course the critics would hate Battlefield Earth -- it has too many moral lessons in it for them to comprehend. And then I guess all the little black sheep have to follow suit.Personally, I liked the movie, I went and saw it twice to try and understand what the critics were going on about.  It had great special affects and I can see this movie appealed to the kids, so if they get one positive message out of it, it is worth it.The movie got completely canned by the critics and in my books that proves it must have had some goodness to it.  I would check out what other movies those so called "experts" said something bad about.  I think you'll be surprised.  I have even seen bad reviews on Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings, only 2 of the best movies ever made.  So who should we listen to??John Travolta, as everyone knows, seems to be just a great, caring sort of a guy.  He too gets attacked for this, however, take a look folks - seems to me he is a huge success I don't think anyone has the right to knock him. At least he has the integrity to say and do what he sees is the greatest good for all concerned.Anyway, my final word is, base your decision on the actual message of the movie.Not everyone has to be a critic!  Fellow Travolta fans unite.

And I thought the book was a fun read. The movie, though was not fun. It was incoherent. If I hadn't read the book I'd have no idea what was going on. Information is thrown at the viewer at a pace that is so fast that your brain kind of gives up trying to make sense of it, and the result is boredom. I wanted to leave after the 1st 45 minutes. Imagine a 3 minute rock video extended to over 2 hours. Or, try a 2.5 hr sprite commercial. I'll tell you what though, my 8 yr. old adhd son, (who processes data at a much higher bps than I do)sat silently for the whole movie and thought this was the best movie he ever saw. So, if you are adhd or have a child that is, this may be an improvement on ritalin. Otherwise save your money. (and your venom - this movie is too meaningless to hate)

reviews.review_title: Are we all seeing the same movie?
reviews.content:
I can't believe what i am reading in these comments.This was absolutely the worst "Blockbuster" movie I have ever seen.  I would rather watch Waterworld three times.  The holes in the plot are plenty. For example, the cavemen dogfighting with the alien pilots.  The special effects have a rush job feel to them.  For example, the shot at night of the alien homeworld, with the teleportation pads and the little lights flashing behind them.  The badguy was submoronic.  Why let the slaves fly around with a spaceship that doesnt have a homeing device on it to track them with.
The plot is terrible.  The badguy aliens are here to strip mine the earth of its valuables.  Why not look in all the banks and national reserves before you start mining?  Why not build a cost effective robot to do your digging for you?  Your technology obviously could support it. At least the robots wouldnt need guards to watch over them.Thats right.  It all has something to do with radioactive zones.  Ones that humans live in? and procreate in?This movie, with its obvious 50's anti-violence motif(they pan to reaction shots during the true brutality), shows me that we might be soon taking backward steps in our media future.What i don't understand is why this film rates 3 out of 10, but a majority of the comments are glowing?So you people who want to waste your money on poor films, go see this one. Twice if you want to,  I will never watch this film again.  I will shut off the T.V. before I watch this.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I have ever paid money to see
reviews.content: This movie is a dog, suitable only for a big group seeing it at the dollar theatre or the cheapest matinee you can get. Take a big group, because afterwards, you will all have convenient access to one another for group therapy.1000 year old machines working perfectly; cavemen (who think the lights in the sky are gods) learning to fly harriers in a couple of days (with a working year 2000 flight simulator); stupid aliens whose elite members are unbelievably dumb over and over; evil aliens who dont blink when cavemen give them gold smelted into bars with the stamp of the USA on them (as opposed to the raw ore they were supposed to mine); one small atomic bomb that blows up an entire planet in a chain reaction; aliens that have inter-galactic teleport technology but who dont have either robot technology or autopilot programs (forcing them to teach one human the entirety of psychlo technology so he can learn to fly an enemy ship into irradiated areas that hurt the psychlo); cavemen who pick up fighter pilot lines like "I'm on his tail" it goes on and on folks ... this movie never lets up.....The horror. Our group of 6, along with the rest of the theatre, well, we were raving with insane and nervous laughter throughout the film. At the end, we stood around for 30 minutes, just standing there, trying to get over it together ... we finally had to go back in and see Gladiator again to re-gain our self respect as people.I still ache from the humiliation today .....
John Travolta as a 7 foot tall alien - what more do you need. Absolute bonkers and worth seeking out if you like trash.

reviews.review_title: Like Going From Foreplay to the Cigarette
reviews.content: While a wonderful piece of eye candy, there is not much else working for this movie.  From having to adapt from classic sci-fi, to having ten producers, everything about this movie spelled doom.  The end result, however, wasn't that good.  This goes beyond doom in the way that constant build-up and let-down can only do so well.  Everything from beginning to end would show great promise and then suddenly deflate in a paragon of the anti-climax.  If you're looking to torture yourself, then please enjoy, otherwise keep away from it like the Bubonic plague.

reviews.review_title: Not so bad as others say
reviews.content: I only write reviews of movies with low rating, which actually are not that bad. Give them a chance!I heard and read a lot about this movie, usually bad things. I don't know why it has such a bad rating, when it's not really that bad at all. It is not good, it is bad, bud not THAT bad. I enjoyed watching it. I love post-apocalyptic movies and I have had a doubt if I should watch it or not, but now when I finished watching it I can say that I am satisfied.Acting is bad, but not by everybody. I can't believe this is the same Travolta as in Pulp Fiction or From Paris With Love. He produced this movie and did't even try acting! That is really not understandable to me. Camera angles, too much slow motion, weird sound design... These things are really bad. But...The story is good! Costumes are funny, but original. Scenic Design is great, I love the way they created post-apocalyptic Earth. I can not tell if the CGI is good or bad, but on DVD it was good. Maybe it is not the same on BluRay or TV... I don't know that. It is not top quality, but it was made in 2000 or even 1999. We can't compare it to today's CGI. Sure, some other films from the same year had way too much better animation, but that is not something to judge the whole movie.I read somewhere that Travolta wanted to make a sequel, but the negative critics made him to change his mind. Well, John, if you are reading this, maybe now is a good time to do it! Or maybe remake, the story is really good! Think about it...Overall, this is not a bad film, it is not a great one neither, but something in between, I would say. Watch it if you like post- apocalyptic theme. It does not deserve 2.4 rating and Bottom 100 #89 . It should be two times bigger.5/10

reviews.review_title: {walks slowly, eyes glazed}... I am NOT a Scientologist...I am NOT a Scientologist...
reviews.content:
I have to say that I was really paranoid about going to see this film. Especially after what happened with the book in 1990, and the Church of Scientology got busted for paying their members to buy 6 and 7 copies of the novel in order to boost sales and keep it on the bestseller list.  All I thought was that the theatre was going to be filled to capacity with boatloads of Scientologists just waiting for their crack at convincing me and my family to join them in their quest to *Clear* this planet.  And then my brother tells me that I fit the profile since I almost went to an "est" training seminar 20 years ago to impress a guy I was dating who had way more looks than brains. But that's another story. It's time to
Prepare for BattleBattlefield Earth  (Roger Christian) I don't know where to start.  First of all, I would like to say that this must qualify as the most awful film I think it has been my utter displeasure to have attended in my entire life.  So many questions kept mulling in my very busy mind as I succumbed to the ravages of the writers' non-imaginations.  From the novel by L. Ron Hubbard (Church of Scientology founder accused of many bad things) and screenplay by Corey Mandell  (no other screenplays to his credit) and JD Shapiro (Robin Hood - Men in Tights), there is just no way to sit through this film and even try to suspend your disbelief when there are just way too many holes, horrible acting (John, Forrest, please, tell me, WHAT WERE YOU THINKING?) and other stuff that bothered me (like, why did their hands look like they bought them at Spencer Gifts after-Halloween sale bins??)  John Travolta, Forrest Whitaker and some other  greedy alien overlords are using what is left of the human race in the year 3000 as a means to their own ends, teaching them to speak their language, fly ships and mine for resources with the intention of exterminating them after they were done. Of course, the slightly evolved neanderthals not only learn these things, they learn to fly Harriers in flight simulators that are over 1000 years old that function with magic electricity and learn to fly like pros in a revolt against the aliens.Then... oh never mind. There is no then.  That's it.  It's a piece of garbage. And I can't BELIEVE they're working on a sequel.   Of course, if you studied your L. Ron Hubbard books and know about the hatred he had for Psychologists and Psychiatrists, it would make sense why the aliens were called "Psychlos" and the other bad people were called "ciatrists".. hmmmmmm I was wondering if there were more examples of find the Scientology reference in this film, but frankly, I couldn't be interrupted from my yawning marathon. There is so much rip-off in this movie from other films that it's quite offensive.  And what IS it with camera tilting? I don't see the point. The theatres I called were sold out and this one was almost sold out, but when it started, more than half the theatre was empty. hmmmmmm Makes you wonder, doesn't it? In the end, the only thing I liked were the special effects, and the cool, old hologram language teacher and his five minutes of coolness, but they would not be the saving grace of this blunder that won't even be crucified by the now cancelled Mystery Science Theatre and too bad,  because they would have had a field day with this one.Remember.  You heard it here. Stay away.Chris Fata North American Ambassador Trash City Magazine

This movie is so bad that my browser crashed after just two minutes of action. Just as well, but still I managed to observe some very poor dialogue and additional acting, incredibly bad filming and even worse editing.How on earth or in space did they manage to spend 73 million dollars on this? I'm just happy I never had to watch Travolta. If anything positive, this is another level of very bad publicity for his and Cruise's religion. Shocked and sad to see that Forest Whitaker has been sucked into this rubbish cult.

reviews.review_title: I could not have imagined a more terrible film.
reviews.content: I went to a preview of this film with fairly low expectations. Apparently, they were not low enough.  I could not have imagined a more terrible film. Not only was this movie cheesy, contrived, predictable and boring but the special effects (a major draw for a science fiction film) were completely lame.  The audience was laughing out loud at the sappy sentimentality and hokey ethnocentric patriotism throughout the film. I felt incredibly embarrassed for both John Travolta and Forrest Whitaker.  What a waste of time and money!

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies ever, but funny.
reviews.content: Don't get me wrong, the movie sucked all the way. But still I had a lot of fun watching it, because it was so bad it became funny.The effects are simply hilarious, the fading effects even more. I had some good laughs with this movie.However, from a technical viewpoint really nothing about the movie is even coming close to acceptable. The make-up is ridiculous, the special effects are really fake and the acting is not exactly Oscar material. And the complete lack of humor in this film makes it almost unbearable to watch.Get together with friends, watch this "how not to make a movie"-example and laugh. Only then it is worth watching.

reviews.review_title: worse adaptation of a great novel
reviews.content: This was the worse adaptation of a novel i have ever seen. The book by L.Ron Hubbard is excellent. I have read it counting the time i am now reading, at least 15 times. To make a awful movie like this one is a disgrace to the million's of fans and to the Late L.Ron. The man who wrote this screen play should never be allowed to pen another work in Hollywood again. There are plenty of film makers in other countries who don't care about quality of what's in the can. The special effects were sub par, the acting was terrible, All in all it was a terrible waste of 80 million dollars. What needs to happen is that someone who loves the book must come forward to write an actual screen play. and a competent director must be found who will take this movie to heart and do it justice. I would say the director in mind is Peter Jackson. I know he would do it right.

reviews.review_title: I have read the book and seen the movie...
reviews.content: Save yourself the money, buy the book.  The characters are richer, the storyline is more believable, and the movie only tells half of the story. Like DUNE, this novel should never have been created for the big screen and hacked to make the two hour viewing time.  It would have been better represented as a eight hour mini-series!

All right, to be honest, I haven't even seen this movie, though I plan to for "scientific research" purposes.  I just wanted to make a comment on the "critical acclaim" comment on the movie box. It reads something like this: "Excellent scene transitions and some of the better special effects we've seen this year. All in all, a good ol' time at the movie theater." --Joblo's Movie EmporiumSeriously, it actually is something like that. I've never screamed "I want 2 hours of my life back" after a movie, but there's probably a first time for everything. . .

A lot of people say that this is one of the worst movies ever made. Why? Because it is too deep and some elements are hard to take in. For one, it's bleak, critics don't like those kind of movies. After reading a few reviews about this movie I saw it and realized why no one liked it. It's different. Those who have read the book will understand it but those who haven't read the book may want to watch another movie.

Well, you may ask yourself how it can be impressive and piece of crap in the same time ? The answer is: 95% of the movie is pure crap and 5% is, let's say, impressive (or better: spectacular). First, let me explain "crappy" part: I never seen more stupid script than this one, used for making this "movie". Really, so lame events that you can see here can't be described unless you see it by yourself - first, stupid nonsenses like "human animals" that does not know how to read and then, at the end of the movie, driving combat, supersonic planes and operating nuclear bomb without problem. Then, training for flying (!) in a flight simulator (?!?) without explanation how they manage to get power-supply (?!!) Then, total strange occurrence of snow in one scene (freezing cold and city covered with snow) while in the other scene, everybody wears short sleeves on warm sun. Also, incredible crappy acting (especially of main character who make such incredible stupid faces all the time that is so irritating)... And finally, really annoying and "over the top" usage of slow motions in almost every action scene (what the hell was director Christian thinking ? He is not John Woo or Sam Peckinpah , for God sake!)Well, the rest is impressive - and that is last 15 minutes of stunning battle - I mean, battle itself is stupid as the rest of the movie (almost lame as airplane battles from ID4 etc.) but FX made here is simply amazing - especially landscapes and final destruction of Dome, explosions etc. are pretty spectacular.So, because of that last 15 minutes, I will give it 2/10. Only because of that!

I think I'm gonna have to go agaisnt grain here and say that this movie was a piece of crap. For two main reasons:  First: What happened to the story? This was an excellent book, full of twists  and turns, fascinating characters. Are ANY of them in the movie? NO! Although one character is allegedgly named "Robert the Fox," but he is never mentioned by name, and he is hardly a highlander.granted, it's a long book, and I am no producer, but I really think that they should have been more faithful, especially with Travolta calling it a tribute to Hubbard. He's probably turning in his grave. Second: People are calling this visually wonderful. Cuttign edge. Bah! The scene changes were repetetive and boring, taken right out of Return of the Jedi. And then, during a massivly inconsequential scene, he runs past pillars ewxploding, straight from the Matrix. PLease, i beg of you: Skip this movie. read the book. it's long, but it's rally fascoinating.

This movie is probably the most insulting piece of celluloid ever made - next to showgirls. But, whereas Mr Verhoeven's film was at least something to laugh at, this one is just ridiculous - in a non-funny way. The story line - if there was something like a screenplay at all- is so incredibly stupid that the movie is even more trashy than the book. I cannot believe that any studio ever would allow Travolta, the resurrected disco dancer of the seventies, to ruin his reputation by doing such a piece of **** and calling it a movie. Sorry John, I am very grateful for Pulp Fiction, Face Off and Broken Arrow, but this was an attack on every human being's intelligence (apparently except of your's). See you in Saturday Night Fever 5.

John Travolta has said in interviews that "Battlefield Earth" (written by L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of Scientology, of which  the actor is a follower) is, in his opinion, the greatest science fiction novel of all time.  That it may be; I've never read it.  But if it is, you wouldn't know it from watching this dingy, plotless, frenetic-but-deadly-dull mess of a movie. Travolta's comeback was a long time in coming, but this film may kill it outright.The film takes place in the year 3000, a millennium after the planet has been invaded by the Psychlos, a tall, claw-handed gang of stupid space pirates who killed off as many humans as possible and turned the survivors into prisoners (apparently, Whoopi Goldberg's hairstylist was kept alive, as all the aliens sport elaborate dreadlock hairdos).  Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper) is part of a survivor commune hidden in the mountains, but while out foraging, he too is captured by the aliens.  Terl (Travolta), the Psychlos' greedy head of security, has found a vein of gold in the mountains, and sends a detail of "man-animals" led by Jonnie (who he has schooled in all things Psychlo) to mine it.  However, Jonnie has plans, and with his newly acquired alien knowledge, engineers a revolt to overthrow the alien oppressors and take back the earth.Standard sci-fi stuff, except for the fact that it's done much, much worse than usual.  Director Roger Christian has no distinguished feature credits (most notably, he was a second-unit man on "The Phantom Menace"), and judging by his work here, he STILL has no distinguished credits.  This picture is a mishmash of dankly lit, choppily edited action sequences intercut with weakly emoted cliche dialogue.  Apparently, cinematographer Giles Nuttgens was suffering from a crick in his neck during shooting; virtually every shot in the picture is an unmotivated tilt.  Also, someone got a good deal on center-screen wipes when they bought the editing software for this turkey, as about nine thousand scene transitions use this outdated '60s-style device.The characters in this film are so poorly drawn it's almost an effort to come up with something to say about them.  We are given no real reason to root for Jonnie aside from the fact that he's not a Psychlo, and Pepper's colorless performance does little to help his case.  I wouldn't follow him into a buffet restaurant, much less a battle to the death (especially if he'd expect me to eat raw dead rats, which he does in perhaps the film's most disgusting scene).  The rest of the "man-animals" don't really register, except for Sabine Karsenti, who plays the single most colorless and pointless romantic interest in cinematic history (and if that's how she was told to play the role, kudos to her; she nailed it).
The Psychlos, for all their elaborate gear and weirdo makeup, are a pretty colorless lot.  Travolta apparently forgot everything he learned about playing a bad guy from his "Face/Off" sparring partner Nicolas Cage, and instead gives us a bland, one-note cackling evil goon, complete with phony pseudo-British accent and veddy scaaaaarry leer.  Forest Whitaker unremarkably plays his henchman, and Kelly Preston, Travolta's wife, has a rather revolting cameo as a Psychlo temptress.The film's biggest failing is that the screenplay (by first-timers Corey Mandell and JD Shapiro) gives the Psychlos nothing interesting to do. Their motivation for invading  Earth is never really explained; indeed, they just seem to be rapacious destruction-mongers like the aliens in the far-from-great-but-ten-times-better-than-this "Independence Day".  They are stupid, greedy, and self-serving, constantly double-crossing one another and devising ill-planned get-rich-quick schemes.  The film almost seems to be playing them as a bizarre parody of sleazy American corporations that gobble up everything in their path.  Still, if American businesses were run as badly as this outfit, there would be even less left of Earth than what the Psychlos failed to destroy.Though it's got the requisite effects and big-time battle sequences, "Battlefield Earth" has a chintzy, cheap feel to it that just makes the threadbare script and meager characterizations even more grating.  Can I think of anything positive to say about this film?  Well, it certainly was...loud.  The soundtrack is full of bombastic music and thrumming sound effects that actually shook the speakers in the theatre.  Of course, that may not be such a good thing.  After all, it kept me awake."Battlefield Earth" was Travolta's passion project, and he nursed it for years before inflicting it upon us.  It's ironic, because passion is just what this soulless, sad mess of a picture could use more than anything.

This movie is a complete waste of time and brain cells.  Not only is it ridiculous and insulting, it contains nothing original/entertaining/credible in the way of art direction, plot, etc.  Also, the editing is the worst I have seen (aside from "Manos, the Hands of Fate" which really is the worst movie ever made, but Battlefield Earth comes in as a close second).

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the most ridiculous piece of tripe ever produced!
reviews.content: This has to be one of the worst films ever made. Although I have never read the novel (who knows, maybe they had nothing to work with), I can honestly say this is a horrific piece of film making. From the uninspiring, overused scene fade (just the one fade effect, a la curtains opening, used every 3 minutes or so), to the director's compulsion with breaking glass (in the first 10 minutes we see a poor imitation of the plate glass run from Blade Runner). But the blame can't be all placed with the director, John Travolta has sunk to a new level of shame. In the scant 2 hours of this movie he has undone all the hard work of Pulp Fiction and Tarantino. What a waste! How can such a good actor do such an awful job?! Personally I think he needs to avoid villain roles all together. Then there's the story itself, full of holes and idiocies too numerous to mention (because even a caveman can learn to fly a Harrier in 7 days). Please, if you value two hours of your life, avoid this film at all costs!!!

reviews.review_title: I bought this for £7.99 at Blockbuster Video, now I would like my £15 back please.
reviews.content: How can I begin? Well let's start with the price I paid for this err film. £7.99 was "On Special Offer", unfortunately Blockbuster sold me this on special offer with the disk still inside.If John Travolta would like to maintain his fan-base, he needs to steer clear of film which incorporate his bazaar religious beliefs. OK, it's an interesting theory, but complete crap to be fair. I can't even bring myself to say the word because of it now being a recognised "religion".However, when you start making films based on Scientology and one of L Ron Hubbard's insane novels, you are crying out for a mauling form the critics and anyone who just loves to make a mock of crap films.Remnants of a Semi-developed human race, throw-backs from several centuries of Alien subjugation, OK this is a good idea, but not a new one in fairness.However, the rot starts not with the 45 degree angle shots where the director appears to be wearing an orthopaedic shoe, no, it's with the unexplained imminent self-destruction of the Psyclo planet and the miraculous crash-course these throw back humans take (and complete) in learning how to fly and attack in Harrier Jump Jets.The special effects aren't too bad, good cast includes John Travolta (I don't mind him), Forest Whitaker (should be in better films with his calibre), and Barry Pepper, but the thin story development and ridiculous finale leads me to conclude that the £7.99 I invested in this will ultimately only pay for one viewing of this joke.Severe constipation is far more tolerable.

reviews.review_title: L. Ron Hubbard's Career Kerflush f. Jon Travolta
reviews.content: Travolta's career will never be able to recover from this trash. Bad book.Bad film.Bad casting.Bad stumping for the film.I remember seeing Travolta on TV telling everyone how great the movie was going to be. He even said that the people that had commented how terrible the movie was were wrong. Barry Pepper wouldn't even talk about it the same night. The movie tour of Europe consisted of the director telling people "It's not as bad as everyone in America says it is"The movie is terrible. The book was terrible. Travolta's career is forever tainted by this bomb. The real shame is that Barry Pepper may never recover from this, and he has serious potential as an actor.What is this film like? Imagine a solid gold statue of a retarded person. Imagine Michaelangelo's David carved out of human feces. All the Scientologists that have come here and said "read the book" are only fooling themselves. The book is amateurish crap that's little more than a series of sci-fi cliché's joined with an illogical storyline. Analog magazine tanked the book, and after trudging through it, I see why.

This film was based on a novel by L Ron Hubbard novelist and founder of Scientology, was Travolta's labor of love for his faith. It was bad on many levels. People feared that this film would have sublimal messages which lead people to scientology. Never fear, people ran from this film in droves.My Fellow humans all critized the effects and cinematography, aside from the bad camera angles. I found the sets and effects to be little above average. besides from Travola and Whitaker in embarrasing Psychlo cosumes I have seen worse effects.Still this film could of ahd knock out costumes and effects and it would of still did not matter. All films depend on the same foundation, Plot. This film's Plot and story was just bad. Poor Dialogue, and a bad story.Blame the writer of the book, Battlefield Earth, The book it was written by L Ron Hubbard. This was the man who wrote many non-fiction "Scientology" books. In "All about Radiation" he claims gamma radiation is water soluble and the sacred Operation Thetan III level of Dianetics auditing, Scientologists learn humans are descendants of "thetans" who were blasted apart by XENU the Galactic Federation warlord.Good Science Fiction is based on science fact, L Ron was not the one for science fact or any method of reason. This film's plot has faults of mythic porportions which many are going to go down in history.Lets review the mythic disaster that is the story.This film takes place in the year 3000. But Denver only looks like it was vacant for 75 years. Put it in perspective The Roman coloseum is over 1,000 is it looks like hell. How come the city did not get overtaken by plant growth. After 30 years of negelct the coloseum was covered in vines and weeds. The streets are clean, sure parts were under the Psychlo fun-dome, even the uncovered areas looked untouched. How are building in Denver still standing after Earth in conquered in 9 minutes, and 1,000 years of Psychlo domination?Then there is Fort Hood, ignorant cavemen find an army base which is still standing and has a bunker with pristine M16 rifles and working harrier jets and a running simulator. USMC pilots spend over 100 hours of flight time to learn the harrier jet. These illiterates are flying like Top Guns in 10 days. According to one cave-idiot, flying a harrier is like breaking in a wild horse.The Psychlos are defeated by these humans because they are mentally handicapped. Terl(played by Travolta) takes the most dangerous and rebellous human Johnny Goodboy Tyler, and teaches him all he needs to know for revolution, H een taken him to the denver library, where paper has lasted for 1,000 years. Yet my dads old playboy's from the 70's started to wither and fall apart after 10 years.When handed bars form Fort Knox Terl totally buy's Johnny's line "We smelted then in bars in your honor."With all these screw-ups, it appears the screenwriter was comatose at the keyboard. With all these inconsistencies, I'm suprised I did not see a scene where Johnny find a pristine 7-11 with electricty, working slurpee machines, fresh milk and hot dogs still revolving on the warmer. That would still be more believable since we know 7-11 Hot Dogs and pizza sticks have shelf life of 1,000 years.This film is the second worst Sci-fi I have ever seen, #1 is Theodore Rex. This film was created to push an insane religon, Theodore Rex was just plain stupid.

reviews.review_title: The Psychlos don't turn out to be so smart, after all....
reviews.content: It's the year 3,000 and, for a millenium, earth has been ruled by a race called the Psychlos who, by their own testimony, wiped out all resistance "in nine minutes." They are ten feet tall, scientifically advanced, and given to ham-acting. In what was once the United States, what's left of humanity struggles along in primitive, remote, hidden communities in the Rockies. The Psychlos are intent on stripping the planet of its minerals. The plot concerns the eventual resistance of subjugated humanity. I won't give anything else away. Amazingly, there's little blood or real violence. Those who judge movies by their body count will be disappointed until the end. If there was any propaganda from the so-called Church of $cientology, it sailed right past me. The movie also goes on a bit too long but, though no masterpiece, it is undeserving of the brutal reviews it has received. It's just a typically silly Hollywood sci-fi film, more intelligent and interesting than witless junk like, say, Starship Troopers, but Star Wars, it's not.

reviews.review_title: I had no idea that a movie could be so bad.
reviews.content: I will admit it. I paid nothing to see this movie, and I got my passes through a local radio station. But I was not alone. This preview crowd was enormous, as evidenced by the square yardage the whole flock of us took up in the food court outside the theatre. Believe me, this was a huge gaggle of folks. And they all seemed excited to be there. Why was I there? Well, I somehow knew how it would all turn out in the end...But my dear sweet heaven... I had no idea that a movie could really and truly be so incredibly bad. Words do not begin to describe the times when the stupidity of the dialogue or the inanity of the plot smacked me cross-eyed with embarrassment for whoever directed this monstrosity.Okay. Okay. Calming down. Surely there were good points... Ever want to see John Travolta stomp around in Gene Simmon's KISS boots and an 8-inch forehead? Well, this is the movie you have been waiting for. Ever want to see a poor agrarian tribesman fly a Harrier jet with Luke Skywalker-in-the-Trenches precision after seven days training? Then step right up, my friend...The plotholes are enormous. The acting is so over-the-top that it drops over the visible horizon, whirls around the equator and smacks you right across the back of the head. Yes, there were funny parts, but not the ones that were intended. When it tries to be chilling in its post-Apocalyptic view of our modern world from the eyes of our millennium-yet-to-be born heroes, it simply comes off as cornball and hackneyed. This kind of hike through an overgrown and disintegrated cityscape has been done before, and done so much better. Bruce Willis wandering around a decayed Baltimore in 12 Monkeys, or even the boy rebels of The Tripods (BBC) skulking around an abandoned future London, both of those had more believable emptiness and loss than BE's incredibly obvious models.The score is suprisingly reminiscent of Vangelis's contribution to Blade Runner. Almost too much so. Come to think of it, the alien domes in BE look a lot like the android pyramids in Blade Runner. And a lot of the alien technology has kind of a Blade Runner style to it. Even when our hero is shot in the back (there's one, set for stun) while running through a dusty old mall, the impact sends him running and crashing through about four plate glass windows, much like the first android Deckard shoots in Blade Runner. Hmmm......Is it worth seeing just from a "its so bad its good" perspective? No, but I suspect that it will develop a summer cult following of those who appreciate unintentional camp, even if its not so good. So there you have it. The anti-Scientologists were right. This movie will have an effect on its viewers, but perhaps not the one that good old L. Ron would have approved.But then, I guess I'm just not the Operating Thetan I could be....

I'm not going to explain on why this movie is so bad, all you have to do is watch the trailer or check the other comments. But, the only thing that I like about this movie is that it's the funniest movie that wasn't suppose to be funny..

reviews.review_title: Not to be taken as a serious Sci-fi movie
reviews.content:
First off, I'd like to say that this movie isn't your typical Sci-fi action movie.
If you have the DVD version you can actually hear the director and some of cast members mocking the movie. They didn't take this script serious.Personally, just to jump into it, the funniest thing is when Travolta's character is trying to find out what makes humans happy. This was hilarious, the whole demeanor of this character.Meaning he thought that being depraved of food for days in severe cold, with no possibility to make a fire, they (The escaped, or more to the point they'd been allowed to escape), they come across a rat.
So, with little choice they, after some hesitation, sinks their teeth into this rat. All in order to survive.
The conclusion of Travolta's character: It's their favorite food!
They've also been spied upon with hidden cameras.If you just ignore basically the whole script (Which really isn't that bad, really!), and just watch it for the comedic parts it's a good movie.I'd say that without Travolta and Forest Whitaker as aliens, this would indeed be worthless. In my opinion they're perfect as the ever scheming, dubious plotting. black mailing aliens.
So, ignore the mediocre costumes and other stuff that seems bad and focus on these two characters as kind of stupid aliens with low expectations.
These clowns couldn't possibly invade a planet, could they..?See it, laugh at it, enjoy it!

If anyone goes to see this movie after it has been universally panned by critics and movie goers alike needs to have their head examined.  I'm also included in this category.  I have been shaking my head all weekend wondering why I even bothered with this below-amateur rate film.  I have seen movies that have made me roll my eyes and even turned my stomach but this is the first movie I have actually "booed".  (More at myself for wasting money and 2 hours of my life.)  Don't even waste your money on renting this movie which will surely be on video in a month.  It's your duty as a "Man-animal" to warn everyone you know not to see this movie.  I weep for Travolta and everyone involved.

reviews.review_title: Stunning disappointment - horrible direction of a great story
reviews.content: I am appalled that inane direction and choppy camera work could turn such a great story (with super actors) into a total waste of cinematic time. You never get a satisfying view contrasting  human and alien size, the story has been butchered to the point of being almost unfollowable, and the annoying close-up blow-up repetition is totally boring, as well as incomprehensible. I'm a big Travolta fan, and I can't believe how bad this director makes him look.  There oughta be a law ....

I have seen this movie twice on DVD. The second time to make sure if there was something I missed the first time. Well there wasn't. There has been some complaining about the silly story, but who cares. I like the movie, but only for the acting of John Travolta and Forest Whitaker. Somehow I got the impression from Travolta he wanted to express he was only there because of the fact that, being a Scientology member, he could not refuse the role (if that is the reason). As far as I am concerned that resulted in a very relaxed way of acting. The rest of the movie is terrible indeed, but can be survived by using the FF button.

This movie is far more funny and well humored than anyone can imagine. Its absolutely unfair to put it down. Its a home movie, very well done, well plotted better than watch old stuff like JohnWayne projecting his fat shadow on the wall in a paper scenery, flat studio floors, blue eyed apaches and all that kind of horror. In this movie the villain and his assistant are absolutely hilarious they are brilliant! is a heart made movie not intending to win any prizes but just making something light and funny. For sci-fi fans only, good humored people looking for relaxing non-sense. Compare it to the planet of the apes and see how less absurd it is, even the effects, actor performances are far better, as matter of fact, the movie has a very harmonious color schemes, make up is creative, light is perfect, casting, edition, i cant see why it is so bad reviewed, i prefer to watch this than boring Titanic, tedious Casablanca or the soporific Metropolis. This is a good movie, full of nonsenses as almost all the greatest science fiction movies. Or have you seen lately anybody with a fly head around? It shoud be a second Episode!

When I saw the reviews for this movie, I thought that it wasn't going to be that good. But it is defiantly an extremely underrated movie.I saw it on VHS and enjoyed it a lot. Maybe not something you may all want to see, but if you are looking for a movie, take the time to watch it. The name may seem a bit corny and lets admit, that it is. But the fact that it came out when the Sci-Fi era was ending and that they didn't put the money into advertising, may be why it is considered one of the worst movie's ever. I enjoyed it, and recommend it if you need a movie to watch.

I love a great scifi movie like this. I'm only leaving a comment because I happened to see this movie was in the top 100 list of all time worst voted movies here on IMDb. I loved every minute of this movie. It's not a personal favorite but I have watched it several times. I really like the special effects and the environments in this movie. It's a must see if you haven't seen it already but most likely almost everyone has seen this movie by now. I can't imagine leaving such a bad rating for this movie like most people have. Maybe it's disappointing to the big sci fi nerds but for a guy like me that usually only watches headline news, law and order, and sometimes family guy, this movie was an awesome change and full of great eye candy.

reviews.review_title: Don't watch it as a Sci-Fi action, watch as Sci-Fi comedy.
reviews.content: I first watched this movie on a movie channel for our cable package. STARZ maybe? I find myself coming back to this movie when I want to watch a solid comedy. I unironically love this movie.

reviews.review_title: Not As Bad As You Heard It Was
reviews.content: BE takes liberties with the Novel it is based on, but as a summer action/blow up movie it works just fine. This is not supposed to be a foreign art film.  If you take it for what it is then you will enjoy the movie.

Why is it that every review of this movie must mention scientology, for those that have not read the novel in the afterward L. Ron Hubbard clearly disassociates this work of "Pure Science Fiction" from his more serious scientological exploits. That said, The movie was good, although it cuts off about half of the book, I was looking forward to seeing it and wasnt dissapointed, I do believe that Sci Fi fans are a breed apart and many mainstream movie fans probably wont like it. Get rid of your Scientological inhibitions and view the movie as just that, A MOVIE!

Ok, first off, I've read the book 6-7 times. Loved it, still do. My first bit of advice is do not go to this film expecting to see what your head has dreamt up in the process of reading the book. If you haven't read the book, then you might enjoy the film more than I did. I have been following Travoltas' attempts to make this movie happen since the late '80s. This was back when he was trying to get Romero to do it, but Romero was too tied up doing one of Stephen Kings' books to try. The scope of the story in it's book form is huge. I always wondered how whomever made this movie would manage to wrangle this story into a solid film. Well, in my opinion, it didn't happen here. So much of the core of the story was left on the cutting room floor or in Travoltas' head. The only character that I believe stood up to its literary counterpart was Jonnie Goodboy Tyler, played by Barry Pepper. Good job Barry. The Psychlos were visually believable but the nowhere near as intense as the book portrayed. To all of you who keep comparing the Psychlos to a mix of the Ferengi and Klingons from Star Trek, all I have to say is  weak, weak. Be a little more original in your comparisons. You should count yourself so fortunate to have those two character types to use as a comparison. This movie could easily have been made in '89 or '90 had there been the money and interest and who then would you have used to draw upon for character comparisons, hmmmm? Weak. There are major segments of the book story that are completely gone in this movie. This event by the book was *supposed* to be a global event, not an "American" event. The planet was attacked, not just the good 'ol USA. Oh well, I could ramble on for 2k or more about it's shortcomings. It was less than what I had expected considering the amount of time, money and desire Travolta had invested in making this movie. It is, in my opinion, an epic ruined. I sincerely think that had this film been lengthened to 3.5 to 4 hours long, maybe with an intermission, it would have been a massive success. Anyway, off to hopefully enjoy the X-Men I go.

0 points for everything else in this high budget cringe worthy film essentially about nothing with some bad acting thrown in! Disaster Artist was made for The Room. Perhaps this film will get one such movie.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people describe
reviews.content: ....but not particularly good either. Hard to believe that 2 of Hollywood's greats: John Travolta and Forrest Whittaker are in this film! But by the same token, they're the only redeeming features of this film. It was a poorly written and directed film, the plot was all over the place and characters unlikeable. Definitely only watch if you are wanting to laugh in disbelief.

I don't usually take the time to comment on movies. I am such a die-hard sci-fi fan that it is completely out of character but after wasting 2 hours of my life viewing Battlefield Earth, I felt compelled to spread the word.
