I watched this movie for the first time in 2001 and went on to watch it several times repeatedly ever since. I never get enough of this movie. I was skeptical before renting this movie before watching it for the first time but while watching it, I was immediately gripped by it. The movie is great for those who like the idea of independence from tyranny or ruthless occupation, organizing a great revolution from scratch, winning a battle which had no chance and against all odds and also how humans from this planet can outsmart an advanced alien race with help such as re-education of one man in science-history-physics-language, everlasting human spirit to be free and unity amongst all humans for one cause. Some critics fail to understand one more point about this movie. One of the possible reasons why Earthlings failed to defend against this alien invasion 1000 years before the time in this movie is because as most times, most Earthlings were divided into various governments, countries, regional powers, etc. Even today, if Earth were attacked by advanced aliens, we may have no chance to defend against them especially because we humans are always so divided as countries and groups. Most of our energy goes into greed, money making and useless conflicts instead of advancements. I think the movie is very well made, the idea and concept are amazing and the urge to know what happens next never goes away. Although it's been more than a decade since this movie was made, the graphics and special effects are still amazingly advanced even for today's standards. Heck, there are major movies made these days which appear less advanced than this one. The alien vehicles, the simulators and lots of new ideas which were utilized in this movie are impressive, even with a few negligible factual errors on the part of Earth technology and weaponry. Yes, some directorial and cinematographically errors could be improved but overall the movie is good entertainment. If you are a true science fiction enthusiast, you will not be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Finally, proof of Travolta's missing acting skills
reviews.content: I've said for years that Travolta is a terrible actor. The problem has always been that a few good directors have made decent movies despite him, not because of him. These 'red herring' movies have put reasonable doubt into the minds of the jury of public opinion.However, this movie leaves no doubt about his abilities. With him in charge(producer), and as the lead there is no one to blame for this travesty but Travolta. Even though I was sure that 'Broken Arrow' had already settled that argument.Anyway. This movie has no legs to stand on. L. Ron Hubbard was a crackpot with barely passable writing skills. So your screenwriters had nothing to work with. Then you have Travolta basically running the whole thing. Even choosing the director and basically directing him (or so the stories go) since he didn't want his beloved cult leader's story messed up.The plot is MIA, the acting horrible, the cinematography so-so, the FX average or less with a scene or two that are exceptions.Even though I usually enjoy a "good bad" movie, I can't think of anyone that deserves to be made to watch this crap. Save your money and rent 'The Day the Earth Stood Still' instead.Note: I've tried hard to follow comment guidelines (see "Profanity, obscenities, or spiteful remarks." from the "What not to include" section) but this movie requires extraordinary measures.

It really wanted to be a super cool, sexy, action-packed movie... but it only managed to be accessible to those who are seasoned "suspension of disbelief" gurus. Yes, some of the effects were neat-o... but it's hard to enjoy that when you are transfixed with how truly bad the script is.With all of that in mind, I really think every movie should get a chance, and I want you to be able to actually sit down in front of this film and give it a try at entertaining you... so here's my advice:
The whole thing was watchable if you do these 3 things: 1) Forget Ronny Hubbard wrote the story, and that Scientology came into play in any of it... if at all possible, never find out. 2) Shut of the mechanism in your mind that wants things to make logical sense (or just watch it when you are sick in bed and desperate for entertainment, or can't move enough to reach the remote.) 3) Think of it as a comedy... if you do that, you might actually enjoy Travolta's performance.It was very mediocre... it failed to entertain me, but I DID watch it right through, so I gave it a 3.

reviews.review_title: A truly beautiful and unique film
reviews.content: Before the movie starts an horrific battle takes place that, in minutes, leaves Earth destroyed and mankind enslaved!  The reason that it is not in the movie is because it's childs play compared to what follows.  The charismatic villan, Terl the Terrible, is the real gold mine.  With ferocity so far unparelled in the movie world, Terl learns how to fire a gun, hunt for gold like a ferocious lion and use his master wit to persuade a foolish rebelling earthling and his companions to help him.  Between these truly elaborate and well formed scenes a decent plot developes.  It's understandable that Terl would let the truly unique and well thought-out character of Jonnie the Earthling know all of his secrets.  I can even see how it would be necessary for Jonnie to know all about Terl in order to hunt Gold for him.  How could Terl know that Jonnie would manipulate the system and teach his friends all about the truly horrific aliens.  Even if Terl found out about this betrayal how could he know that the earthlings would start a small rebellion that would later crush and overthrow the alien conquerers.  In a truly magnificent and original final battle scene, hundreds are killed but the earthlings come out on top to retake their home planet, Earth.  I can tell you now that I left the theatre feeling refreshed and exhilarated.  I'm crossing my fingers for an even more fantastic sequal.

reviews.review_title: A great big dose of fun

His will be remembered as one of the great characters of all time in the Sci-Fi genre.The interplay between Terl, played by Travolta and his "trustworthy" sidekick Ker, played by Forest Whittaker was alone worth the price of admission.Of course, you'd expect great special effects and sets. The story is very interesting  the world has been taken over by a very humanoid alien life form that is exploiting the earth for its minerals. Most humans are enslaved, and those that are not, have degenerated to a low level of technology. In spite of a significant difference in technology, the humans revolt, and incredibly, win. But given this interesting story line, this is an incredibly idiotic film. These aliens rule the universe, but are incredibly stupid in how they relate to each other. In spite of much evidence to the contrary, they believe that humans cannot think. They are so obviously based on the Klingons that the story borders on plagiarism. Some of the special effects were very nice (as when they aliens teach Johnny Tyler their language). For all the hardships humans face, all of them appear well fed, well groomed, have great teeth and look great in general. The movie is lost in execution  a nice opportunity lost.

What an ugly movie. When you look at the poster, you can notice a powerful influences from other science fiction series and movies, but minimized and reduce to a ridicule satire.There are a lot of things without any explanation, like "Why the Psychlos didn't searched on Fort Knox?", "Why does a bunch of VTOL AV-8 Harriers (with an estimate of 1010~ years) didn't got rusty, or destroyed by the Psychlos, or become flyable, since the Jetplane gasoline must be dispatched when unused in a certain period of time", "How mankind went to that 'Stone-aged' ambiance with uncertain explanation", "Why didn't the radiation killed the humans?" and "How come the Psyclo breathing gas be so unstable, being an extremely advanced civilization that would correct that mistake a long time ago?" Bad movie. Travolta, you owe us a nice explanation for acting on this 'movie?'

reviews.review_title: There Was Some Mild Effort Put In Here.....
reviews.content:
That being said, all of it went towards the hokey, way over-the-top, over-zealous, over-inflated, over-dramatic acting. It was like watching the sci-fi space edition of Rupaul's Drag Race & you know what?
I kind of enjoyed it.
However, I wasn't exactly a fan of the movie's lack of glitter & back rolls, but I did see quite the array of bad lace fronts, insane makeup, & some very queen-ish behavior (especially from our dear friend Mr Travolta), so that was good enough for me.
Please do give this one a spin.
As the kids would say, it's pretty dam "extra" so it fits in perfectly with today's "reality" television shows. Even though the film takes itself takes itself so seriously to a point that it's obviously hilarious, I highly recommend that you do not do the same. Needless to say, People who don't have a very prompt sense of humor WILL NOT FIND THIS CHARMING.
Just picture Star Wars &/or Star Trek mashed up together in a very potent concoction alongside mass helpings of Tommy Wiseau's The Room, & Presto!
Either you'll love it or you'll find it absolutely abysmal.
Peace mofos! - Svend Sorensen

reviews.review_title: I am a huge fan of the book.
reviews.content: Two things.1. I read the book 3 times over the last 15 years and I think it is one of the greatest sci-fi books ever written. The movie made an attempt, not a good one, but it was an attempt. As to the complaints of Terl being too overplayed, Travolta played him EXACTLY as he was written. He was meant to be a stupid arrogant evil bastard. At some points I even think he may have been underplayed.2. I am not a scientologist nor do I believe anything they do. Having said that the thing that annoyed me most about this movie is not the movie itself, but all of the people spouting off about how this was so obviously influenced by Scientology.Huh?The book and movie are both completely UNRELATED to Scientology and Dianetics. Please people, go hunting witches elsewhere.Interestingly enough, whenever Steven Spielberg makes a movie about jews, no one accuses him of trying to covert everybody.

Watching Battlefield Earth is rather like buying real estate in Silicon Valley, over-priced, painfull, and built on a fault line. This $22-million-dollar "Epic", not, is a joke. You really can't imagine just how bad it is. Some movies are so bad that you have to watch them, this isn't one of them. The only good thing about this film, is that Ed Wood Jr., will no longer be know as the man who made the worst film of all time. That title now firmly belongs to Battlefield Earth. There is a reason it's pulling a 2.3 rating.

reviews.review_title: A movie that is light-years behind expectation
reviews.content: I am the kind of person who looks at the critic's reviews of a movie and disagrees with everything they say, but this movie is a BIG exception. Although this movie may have some elements to it that would make a satisfactory movie to the average viewer, it is a slap in the face to anyone who is a fan of Hubbard's work.  The only similarity to the book is a very broad generalization of the plot and the character's names.  There are so many things wrong with the movie that I don't have the room to list them here. I understand that the book was too long to make a movie out of the entire novel, but even only going as far into the story as it did left out too much to make this a worthwhile venture.   Considering the fact that Travolta is a Scientologist, I am surprised he wished to insult Hubbard's memory with this complete waste of time and money.

reviews.review_title: If you like campiness--you'll love this one.
reviews.content: I know this film has been trashed a bunch-and let's face it for the most part deserved it. But let me offer a different angle and tell y'all why I love this film. It is, bar none, the best piece of trashy campy sci fi made in years! Really, to find something this campy you have go back the great early Star Treks or quest for fire. In time I think folks will see this film as the unintended camp classic that it really is. These days so many film makers want to be hip and "inside" so they embrace the campiness of their genre-the nauseating oeuvre of Quentin Tarrentino for example. But the problem is, if you embrace it, you loose it. The best camp happens when the work is made in all seriousness as this film clearly was. Watched through the right lens and with an eye toward a specific viewing experience this film will not disappoint.

Another great book, poorly translated to film.  While I found many things to like about the movie, it could not really compare with the book.  Many of the plot absurdities, simply, were not in the book.  And some of the most important elements in the story where glossed over and underdeveloped.  For instance, The whole Fort Knox thing was not in the book. Also, the humans learn to fly the Psychlo's ships. The characterization of the humans, made into "cavemen" in the movie, were much more "Indian-like" in the book. Johnny's character was surrounded with intelligent, capable characters in the book and all were missing in the movie.If you want a great ride, read the book.  The movie, while visually appealing simply does not come up to par with the characters, which ironically, is the essence of the book.What could've been a landmark Sci/Fi film was pretty disappointing.

reviews.review_title: This movie is not that bad
reviews.content: It's funny how people can read a bad review and automatically get a negative view of the movie before even seeing it.   What is a review? It's an individual's taste of the movie that is why I care less to read critics reviews, heck to most of them, if it is not Gone With the Wind; the movie is not worth watching.It is funny how some people are complaining about the realism of the film. Ok lets see, we are watching a movie about a group of aliens that took over earth, and you are complaining that a group of grunts learn how to pilot a jet fighter in a week?  Ummm, which do you think is more believable in real life?  The fact this, movies are ENTERTAINMENT, if I wanted to watch something based on real life, I would watch COPS, never know when I might spot a friend on there.  :)In my opinion if you like SCI FI's , watch the movie, if you don't, don't watch the movie.  To be honest I would wait for it to come on video, simply put I think there are a bunch of good movies out there.  Only waist your 8 bucks on Must see movies.

I think that this movie is a sleeper. Like Blade Runner, Dune and the Matrix, you have to see it more than once to really get into it.  But once you do, it's fantastic.  I've seen it twice and can't wait to see it again. I'll definitely buy the video!

Sometimes a movie can be so bad, it can actually be entertaining. "Showgirls" is actually one funny movie, although never intending to be. This movie is so goofy, that to view it as a comedy almost works...ALMOST.....This movie is too stupid to be funny. The first question I have is.....if earth nuked itself, and there were some survivors, why are they all stupid? It seems like the world blew up but only people in the DMV and the every guest on the Jerry Springer show were saved.It appears that this movie was written by someone who just read "Planet of the Apes" on LSD!

Having read and enjoyed L. Ron Hubbard's Battlefield Earth book years ago I must admit I was a little wary of how it would translate to the big screen. However, I was very pleasantly surprised when I caught a preview a couple of weeks ago.This is a great film with all the twists and turns one would expect of a direct reading of Hubbard novel.  This movie covers just the first part of the book. I hope they make the second part!  Treat yourself to a hugely enjoyable rocket ride!

I enjoyed the action and thought Travolta made a great bad guy.  I think if you have a sense of humor and saw the humor in it, it was funny as well. I particularly liked how they bridged from Psychlo language over into English. I look forward to part 2.

reviews.review_title: Going against the grain here-- I like this film...
reviews.content: OK, it's not Oscar material but it is campy fun with a plot that you can root for... I think the casting was great because it was all over the place... This film seemed to liberally borrow from both Star Trek and Planet of the Apes- not bad source movies... But it still brought enough originality to be (IMHO) very entertaining... The "ook ook" monkey sounds of the 'humans' is a little (no, a LOT) dumb but hey- this is Hollywood and you have to sometimes dumb down... It's one of my go to films when I can't find something new to watch...If you haven't seen it, give it a watch! If you look in DVD bargain bins you can pick it up cheap (I got mine for $1)... Should that tell me something? Nope, I got Citizen Cane for $1, too... LOLMovies should entertain, right? :)

I remember how my friend convinced a few of us to come out and watch this movie a few years back. We were all a little reluctant, but we all said "Oh, sure why not? It couldn't be that bad!" Oh, how I wished I stayed home that night! After the movie, we all gathered in the parking lot and sat there laughing about how horribly bad this movie was...we were just in disbelief that something so stupid and incomprehensible could ever be produced by a major studio.First off, the storyline is ridiculous, the acting is unbelievably horrible, and the cinematography is a joke. Speaking of the camera work, the crazy "angled" look wore off after the first few times, but we get that the WHOLE movie! This movie just gives you unintentional laughter throughout, so I guess that's its only redeeming factor. My friends and I were cracking Rasta-Travolta jokes for weeks. And we just loved how he delivered his lines in such a Shakespearean manner. Our favorite being, "Well, since you rat-brains had enough time to SMELT the gold into bars...." Classic.I think Steven Rosen of the Denver Post said it best when he reviewed this movie: "You don't watch this movie - you survive it."

As a film industry professional and a life-long fan of sci-fi films, I anxiously awaited the release of the movie BATTLEFIELD EARTH, based on the novel by L. Ron Hubbard (one of the best "futuristic" books ever).  I knew it would be a huge task to adapt this work to film, because it's a huge far-reaching piece of writing.The makers of the film have followed a certain path through the story which gave me: immense visual excitement (the explosion of the evil planet is remarkable), tremendous acting (check out John Travolta's take on a true villain--filled with charm and seductive appeal while at the same time being totally threatening; see Barry Pepper's depiction of an action-oriented hero); see Forest Whitaker's portrayal of an underling who finally rises up in protest over his boss' mistreatment); thematic importance (an individual actually can take matters into his own hands and make them right).BE also has a wonderful balance of humor, adventure, action and jeopardy which kept me rapt and at the edge of my seat the whole time.A most refreshing look at the future!  Destined to be a classic of the genre.--Eric Sherman Author/DIRECTING THE FILM

In contradiction to earlier comments, I actually enjoyed this movie.  It has a good story line although there are some issues with continuity.  If the movie was made exactly like the book, there would be any plotholes, i.e. (Spoiler) the 1000 year old jets were completely corroded and useless in the book, yet in the movie they are fully functional.  All in all, it was a good movie though, with Respectable acting and a strong supporting cast.
John Travolta's acting was very good and I commend him on his effort, I only wish more thought was put into the movie, at least then they could have told the second part of the story. This half would have tied up many of the plot holes left by the first movie.  But, that's just what could have been.

I've read the book twice. The book is a great and detailed look at what could happen here, but I could not envision how the movie could be made (maybe that's why I'm not a film maker). So I was pleasantly surprised to see over-the-top aliens who were arrogant and brutal to the point of being funny, which I believe was deliberately done to temper the bleak setting. They were very much in character as the indifferent squanderers of planets, as were the natives - struggling, ignorant and nearly beyond hope. The combination preserved the darkness of the subject matter. I was impressed.The visuals are great - the darkness, the wilderness and the remains of the planet's infrastructure. I also enjoyed how Earth's history is interpreted by these future characters. It is above all a non-stop action movie. I think it is a great sci-fi flick, and has elements that will make it a classic a la Rocky Horror Picture Show.

reviews.review_title: Nowhere Near As Bad As I Expected
reviews.content: Two months ago, I challenged myself to watch all movies considered the worst by Roger Ebert. I couldn't find this movie anywhere, until last week when I found it in the one-dollar bin at the video store, the bin where bad movies go to die. I went home and started watching it. I'd read the reviews, heard what my friends had said about it, so I was expecting this to be bad. About half an hour in, I still hadn't found something I hated very much. By the end, I realized that I had enjoyed Battlefield Earth. Yes, the movie has its flaws, and Jesus, there are too many to list, but there are some positive things to say. -John Travolta'a performance as Terl is delightfully hammy and over the top. -The premise is intriguing. -The views of the post-invasion Earth (wrecked skylines of Denver, Washington) are great. -And my reason for it is that it's just... cheesy. It doesn't feel like the worst movie ever made, it feels like a bad episode of Star Trek and a bad episode of Stargate Atlantis had a love child and it grew up with William Shatner and Jim Carey. It's bad, I'll never say it's good, but I will watch it again. This movie is the ultimate guilty pleasure.

reviews.review_title: You've read the reviews, now get the advice!
reviews.content: Viewer reviews have been consistently negative for this film, not without reason. I was afraid it was going to be bad, and calling this movie bad is too high praise. I agree with most of the other reviewers, except I did like Forrest Whittaker, even if he didn't fit the description or characterization in the book. I just finished re-reading the book last week. The book was about 20% action, 80% plot. The screenwriters pulled about 10% (of the 20%) and shot action sequences. They forgot to add any of the plot to it.This movie can be compared to StarShip Troopers, in that 10% of the book was used to make the movie, and the rest was left out.Bottom line. The book costs less than if you see this movie in the evening. Skip the movie, read the book. You'll get a lot more entertainment and thought provoking ideas for your money. Don't quit half-way through when it seems like the book is over. There are lots more goodies to come.

What could be better than a movie based on the stumbling science fiction scribblings of a racist pedophile cult leader? Well, a broken glass catheter inserted by Michael J. Fox, for a start. Follow that with a sandpaper massage and bathing in a tub full of lemonade, and you will be approaching the sensation of watching Battlefield Earth. There is no discernible reason for the (over)use of color filters, except perhaps to distract from John Travolta's complete lack of talent. Possibly the worst offence (from a technical standpoint, that is) has to be the Dutch Angle -- normally used sparingly to "throw off" the viewer's perspective to create feelings of unease and/or discomfort, but in Battlefield Earth is literally the only shot used. This film is the cinematic equivalent to having your genitals mangled by rabid weasels with dull teeth while laying in a Taco Bell dumpster in July. I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: Excellent, beautifully acted and executed film
reviews.content: This is an excellent movie.  I have seen it three times and it gets better each time.  Hubbard has incredible insight and ability to portray the good guys and the bad guys!  His work is and always has been bigger than life. I thought Travolta did a fabulous job,  as did Pepper and the others.  The special effects were cutting edge.  Bravo!!

I basically knew what I was in for but seriously, they should have test audiences to continuously test scenes as they go along. I liked a feeeeew scenes, like the utterly subjected tutor (-hologram) but the story was just so stupid. 1 Let's take the most trouble-making insubordinate man-animal out of controlled boundaries for a hush-hush experiment. 2 Let's teach HIM of all people advanced calculus and history so he can operate heavy machinery. The term Euclidic geometry is universal, by the way. 3 We can build a teleporter and conquer a planet in 9 minutes but if we search the planet for gold for 1000 years our sensors still can't find Fort Knox.Stupid stupid stupid.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as others would have you believe
reviews.content: Let's get it out of the way and say it: Battlefield Earth is awful. Had it never been made, the money that was used to produce it could have been used to make several better, smaller-budget movies, or perhaps the money could have fed children in refugee camps somewhere. But that's neither here nor there, since B:E was made, and it's here forever.So, like the many unfortunate youths that have uncles with boundary issues, we need to come to terms with what just happened to us. Battlefield: Earth is bad. It's horrible. It's an affront to all that is righteous and beautiful in this world. And it's also extremely entertaining, if you view it correctly. Here are my suggestions:1) Get drunk while watching. Take a drink every time somebody says "Terl," or "gold" or something like that. 2) Invite your friends over for a bad movie night and rip on it as much as you can. Nobody cares if you talk over an important plot development, because let's face it, there are no important plot developments. 3) Watch it in a language you don't understand. Seriously, I caught in on Univision one time and I found that the Spanish dub was extremely enjoyable. It was the first time I liked watching the movie, and since then I have gotten more and more enjoyment with each subsequent viewing.Watching this movie is akin to drinking what you think is tea, only to find that it's soda. Your brain doesn't recognize the soda flavor and for a moment you are convinced that you've consumed a poisonous batch of tea. When you first watch this movie, you're expecting something wonderful, but once that bad taste wears off you're left with a beautiful experience. It's bad, but it's not that bad.

reviews.review_title: A highly entertaining piece of sci-fi cinema!
reviews.content: Just before the opening of John Travolta's Battlefield Earth (based on the book of the same title, authored by L. Ron Hubbard) I ran across something I found very interesting.  I read a review in Entertainment Weekly magazine which attacked the film in a way I had never seen done with any other film before it. Now, it is a very well known fact that John Travolta is an outspoken practitioner of Scientology, and that L. Ron Hubbard is that religion's founder.  What I found unusual was the amount of concern dedicated to both figures. Surprisingly, the entire first page of the review was dedicated to only a catty criticism of John Travolta's hair and makeup.  The writer of the article, Owen Gleiberman also stated that "it may take a blind zealot to believe that L. Ron Hubbard is an inspired science-fiction writer."After researching the possible truth of this statement I discovered that L. Ron Hubbard is actually one of the top sci-fi writers of all time by sales volume alone and is also widely regarded as a master of his craft by people such as the legendary Robert Heinlein himself, who said of Hubbard's Final Blackout, "as perfect a piece of science fiction as has ever been written!" and called Battlefield Earth "a terrific story!"  It makes me wonder whether Gleiberman has ever even read any of Hubbard's work.In his article, he mentions Hubbard nearly twice as often as the film's lead, Barry Pepper.  I've never seen an author get that much attention for a film.  I therefore had the sneaking suspicion that Mr. Gleiberman may have some sort of personal grudge with either Hubbard himself or Scientology at large. In any case, the curiosity of all this was such that I just had to see the film.  I did end up seeing the film and I would swear I was watching an entirely different movie than the one Mr. Gleiberman commented upon.  The experience was so startling it inspired me to write a review of my own.Lacking Gleiberman's religious fervor and interest in cosmetology, I decided simply to stick with the basics:  writing, directing, acting and production value. While a film can rarely live up to the book that spawned it, I thought the screenplay beautifully communicated the themes which made Battlefield Earth a best-seller:  the resilience of the human spirit, the power of truth over deception, and the triumph of knowledge over might. Two-time Academy Award-winner, Roger Christian, the film's director and protégé of George Lucas proudly displays the hallmark qualities of his mentor.  Expertly capturing the themes of the story while simultaneously allowing the talent on his set to shine unhindered, each in their own unique way, Christian leaves us both curious and enthralled.  He paints a grimly contrasting picture of both the oppressed populations of Earth and our affluent alien captors, one culture dead of technology, the other dead of spirit, one pulsating with the will to be free, the other long ago resigned to live as slaves. Travolta (the film's villain, Terl) performs with the same brilliance which has come to be expected by most movie-goers from a long and successful history of cinematic bad-boys.  Like many of his other films, I couldn't decide whether I loved to hate him or whether I hated the fact that I loved him.  In either case, he was as thrilling to watch as his creepy eyes were disturbing. Both Barry Pepper (Johnny, the film's hero) and Forrest Whitaker (Terl's devious sidekick) brought with them the same honesty and realism that made them famous for their roles in Saving Private Ryan and Good Morning Vietnam respectively.  Pepper definitely lives up to the larger than life reputation of Hubbard's Battlefield Earth hero, Johnny Goodboy Tyler.  Expect to see Pepper's already impressive career flourish grandly in the years to come. As far as the film's overall production value, all I can say is that apparently, when a film has one man in charge of production design, creature design and costume design (in this case, the supremely competent Patrick Tatopoulos of Independence Day)  you get an artistic continuity unmatched by almost any sci-fi film ever made.  An excellent call on the part of the film's producers, Elie Samaha, Johnathan D. Krane and John Travolta.  In addition to the film's superb look (credit to Lucasfilm alumnus, cinematographer, Giles Nuttgen), the Academy Award-graced special effects team on this one definitely put in their overtime.  Gripping action sequences, terrific spacecraft realism, and wonderfully subtle alien enhancements make Battlefield Earth one of the best films of the summer lineup. No doubt, Battlefield Earth will be remembered as a highly entertaining sci-fi action thriller and anticipation of its sequel is already bubbling wildly both in the Hollywood community itself and in sci-fi and Hollywood fandom alike.  Like the best-selling sci-fi novel which inspired it, Battlefield Earth is truly a work not to be missed. As an end note, I loved Travolta's hair and makeup.  They make him look like exactly what he plays, a deliciously evil intergalactic bad-ass!  Go, John.

I read the book first and was totally thrilled with it.  So consequently when the movie came out I was one of the first to arrive.  It was definitely different than the book but it was great in its own right.  The story is very exciting and the special effects are like I have never seen.  Mostly I always enjoy freedom fighter type movies!  Great fun and even better when you see it a second time!

reviews.review_title: a great parallel to the present earth condition
reviews.content: good going ,john travolta, you got it made and out there! it came out great. kept my interest and i read the book first. i liked the pace the special effects and it was a complete different character that we are not used to when we think of travolta. it shows he has depth and can change from good guy to bad in an instant.

I guess I must have weird taste in movies, but I enjoyed this movie. Being an engineer and wanting everything to make since, I don't normally like movies that have such plot errors (as everyone has pointed out here). My wife is always yelling at me "IT JUST A MOVIE" (as I point out plot errors). Also, I do enjoy science fiction movies (I robot, Matrix, etc), TV shows (Star Trek (all of them), etc) and Books (Orson Scott Card mainly). So with all these complaints, I must have missed something. When I watched this movie, I was interested in it the entire way threw. So, I must have been in one of those moods where I suspended logic. I guess I need to see it again, so I can see what everyone is complaining about.

This film is NOT as horrible as everyone has labelled it so. I still can't understand what is so wrong. My friend Sean mentioned to me the "sloppiness" of some of the scenes, and how "wipes" were used in every transition. These are problems?This is a movie about aliens, *HELLO*, anyone using they're brains? Yes, of course there were less believable sequences as in the USA flight simulators, and how quickly the human characters were to learn. With this in mind, you have to remember one detail. Think for a moment; there is NO, I repeat NO reality check needed here. This is a science fiction film. And as far as the acting goes, I thought it was great. Maybe I am the only person to have enjoyed the alleged "worse movie of the year", and maybe; everyones opinion is inflated based on critics reviews. I thought it was brilliant how the ruthless aliens pumped all of they're own knowledge into a human. They were so indulged in they're own superiority, they didn't even consider the possibility of a measly little human accomplishing an uprising. The acting was great, above average at the least. The directing was perfect, shots were lit well and original angles for action sequences and "close up" shots. As another plus, the musical score was perfectly in tune with the action, and allowed me that "alien world" feel to enjoy as I watched the story unfold. So as everybody cold shoulders this piece of originality, I pity the man who has the same opinion as everyone else. This movie reminded me of "Planet of the Apes", with primitive characters that learn of the past, and shape the future. This film had my attention glued to the monitor for the entire production. I respect that everyone has the right to they're own opinion, it just amazes me how everyone can "agree" against it. -------Violent G

.... watch zionist Gal in Wonder Woman 1984.Just like this film a man out of his time travels in time and goes to the future and pilots a modern fighter jet without training across three continents...Hollywood is not a quitter!

I felt like I was watching independence day meets the matrix.  It was so boring, but the acting was par.  Some of the graphics are cutting edge, but nothing anyone hasn't already seen a thousand times.Nothing meshed together, and I fell asleep. I gave it a four.

For the respect I hold for anything science fiction/fantasy, I couldn't bring my self to give this movie a 1 of 10.  Any movie or films that attempts to portray a new world, and forge in new directions in such a conservative era has my respect.  So I've respectfully given it a 2 of 10.On the flip side...oie, I had to restrain myself from walking out of the theatre.  Given that I wasn't the one that drove to the theatre, the alternative for me was waiting outside in the cold.  Once I stopped attempting to take the movie seriously, and hoping that it would pick up at some point, I felt a lot better.  Personally, I don't feel that the director meant for the audience to fall out of their seat laughing when the band of good-guys show up near the end of the movie in their Harriers.I have to say that I'm a bit insulted that the movie suggested such an over-the-top arrogant race such as the Psychlos were able to take over earth.  Especially since a handful ragtag cavemen were able to overthrow their whole settlement.I couldn't find myself caring too much for the 'hero' of this movie either. Motivation that comes from where; his horse getting shot?  The hero himself couldn't be more of a stereotype; never making a mistake and having seemingly endless reserves of charisma to command his followers.John Travolta, I cared more about what happened to him than the hero. Travolta is a good actor, and will portray any role that he is given well; and that isn't to say that he did a smash job of acting in this film.	I don't recommend this film.  I haven't read the book, but from the other comments I've read from the people that have read the book, it is worlds above the movie.

John Travolta, most famous for the boogying Tony Mannero, will dance his way into your heart with his endearing portrayal of the Chief Psychlo. Travolta plays a giant alien sent to Earth to help save what the movie cleverly calls "earthlings" from the evil Johnny, played by Barry Pepper. Johnny is on the verge of building a giant "Death Star" that is not so much a star as a space station capable of obliterating a planet.On the way to it's inevitable happy ending, "Battlefield Earth" will thrill you with emotion and confound you with its paradoxes. Look closely and you'll see William Shatner, the famous actor and author on whose "Tekwar" novels this film is based.

Battlefield Earth is a quasi documentary on how big corporations run their business. the internal politics, the power struggle and of course the working doe. It also shows a fight for "freedom" which could also be a worker takeover (i.e. Delta airlines). Perhaps it was too witty for the audience OR not understandable to those outside of politics and/or large business standards. However, I must agree that the ending was too much. Uneducated baboons learning to fly sophisticated fighter planes in three days??? Not really. Finally, the end with the gold and Ker can be seen as symbolic to today's constant pursuit of wealth (although it was not intended to be so). The bottom line is that I really enjoyed this movie.. no matter what it's IMDb ranking may be.

Don't be fooled!  Don't waste your money!  The book was simply awful and the movie (which I got a free pass for otherwise I would NEVER have gone - yes the book is that bad) actually makes it worse.  At least with a book you can skim over the really tedious parts.  Interesting dialogue? Plot? Characterization?  Weren't in the book so I guess it was too much to ask for any of them to be in the movie.  The special effects were well done but you could just as easily see ID4, Godzilla, The Matrix, hell go back a few years and add Aliens, T2, etc if all you want are pretty pictures and actually be able to stomach (if not enjoy) the story.  That simply isn't possible here. 1 out of 10.

I had a good time watching Battlefield Earth.  Travolta did his usual excellent job as the absolutely wicked Terl.  Travolta's ability to continuously win audiences as good guy or bad is a salute to his acting skills and his popular appeal.  I had read L. Ron Hubbard's bestseller some years back and was impressed by the movie's close adherence to the book, though I think the rich detail of Hubbard's book was the better of the two. The great special effects, action and the tribute to the indomitable spirit of Man gave this flick a Rocky/Star Wars feel that I found briskly entertaining.  This was good, fast fun.

This movie was about as weak as they come--and I'm not that critical. Everything from why humans have returned to the stone-age to where they get the walkie-talkies is inexplicable and unlikely, not to mention going from "cavemen" to "fighter pilots" in just 7 days!  And I'm not talking basic "suspension of disbelief"--I'm talking suspension of any common sense. There are a few acting highlights, but they do not make up for this poorly written and directed film.  Even Armageddon had more plot, continuity, and plausibility than this film.  The Psychlos (the aliens) were a poor but obvious combination of Klingons and Ferengi from Star Trek: The Next Generation.

Reviewers are already calling this movie the "Plan 9 from Outer Space" of the year 2000. That's a bit overstated; "Battlefield Earth" is worse than you ought to expect from an $80-million movie, but not as bad as many of the media reviews have said.  It's more like "Dune" than "Plan 9": not REALLY bad, and not terribly good either, just proof that some decent talent, cool special effects, and a few creative ideas can't save a poor script."Battlefield Earth" is based on the 1982 novel of that name by L. Ron Hubbard.  The year is 3000.  Earth has been overrun by the Psychlos, a cruel, opportunistic race of giant aliens that mine entire planets of their precious metals.  A thousand years earlier (that'd be around now) the Psychlos routed the entire human race in only nine minutes.  What is left of humanity now cowers in caves in the mountains, where the Psychlos can't go because the radiation levels are too high (radioactivity ignites the gas they breathe).  Unfortunately, the radiation is slowly making the humans extinct as well.  Enter Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper, the Bible-quoting sniper from "Saving Private Ryan"), a young human who is trying to find a better way of life for his tribe. While exploring the ruins of the city of Denver, he is captured by the Psychlos and pressed by their corrupt security chief, Terl (John Travolta) into mining a secret vein of gold.  He takes the opportunity to motivate the remainder of the Psychlos' slaves into revolting against the aliens.This ought to be an OK premise for a space opera, right?  Unfortunately, in this script, illogic carries the day.  Although it is supposedly illegal to teach non-Psychlos how to mine, you never see a Psychlo so much as pick up a shovel. The humans do the mining, and the Psychlos are more like taskmasters (something like the Egyptians in Exodus).  When Jonnie proves to be aggressive, untrainable, and rebellious, he is marked for termination, but instead Terl hooks him up to a teaching machine and gives him the knowledge he needs to stage an effective revolt.  Although Terl gives Jonnie two weeks to mine the vein, appparently the Psychlos were too dim to raid Fort Knox, so the humans simply take that gold and spend their two weeks hunting for weapons.  Fort Hood has been a ruin for a millennium, but luckily the Harrier jets stored there are in working order and still full of fuel; what's more, the fort still has electricity to run the Harrier simulator so that the cavemen can become Top Gunners in a week. (Heck, someone even left the light on in the simulator, and after 1000 years it hasn't burnt out yet!)  The gas that the Psychlos breathe is poison to humans, and vice versa, but at one point a suffocating Jonnie is able to escape from the dome the aliens have erected over most of Denver simply by diving into a pipeline that goes to the outside.  And so forth. To their credit, the scriptwriters managed to avoid some of the plot howlers in Hubbard's novel, such as the atomic bomb that can vaporize a planet but not the other atomic bombs sitting next to it.Technically, "Battlefield Earth" is a freaky mess.  Evidently director Roger Christian thought it would be cool to film most of the movie at odd angles, but it just ends up being disorienting.  The human characters are at times difficult to tell apart, since they are all long-haired and shaggy.  The Psychlo atmosphere is purple, so all the scenes inside the dome are dark and indigo-tinted.  Unfortunately, since the Psychlos are also long-haired and shaggy, in the dark good guy and bad guy alike are identical silhouettes. Travolta appears to forget about Terl's pseudo-British accent about half the time.  At the beginning of the movie the Psychlo weapons shoot gobs of green energy, but at some point they start firing bullets instead.  The sound effects are good, and the computer-generated effects are OK - though better suited to "Babylon 5" than a big-budget movie - but the musical score is loud and overdramatic.But despite all of "Battlefield Earth's" faults, and being forewarned by dozens of negative reviews in the press, I actually had a hard time not enjoying it.  It was just fun to watch.  Certainly the novel it's based on is overlong, poorly edited, and in places just plain weird, but it isn't the worst thing Hubbard ever wrote.  I enjoyed the way the director switched between the Psychlo and human points of view - humans perceive Psychlos speaking gibberish, while the Pscyhlos regard the humans as apes.  It was evident that Travolta had fun hamming up his role as the Machiavellian and arrogant Terl.  Unfortunately his lines, consisting primarily of diabolical laughter and childish semantic games, did get tiresome after a while.  Multiple variations on the theme "I agreed we wouldn't spy on each other, but I never agreed *I* wouldn't spy on *you*" can only go so far before getting silly.  And the Psychlo technology is more or less the way I pictured it while reading the novel: grimy, metallic, and more functional than decorative.The idea of an influential Hollywood Scientologist producing a film based on a novel by the founder of Scientology has, understandably, raised some concerns that "Battlefield Earth" might be a subtle promotional tool for the controversial religion.  But as reprehensible as Hubbard and Scientology are, these fears are unfounded.  A few of Hubbard's ideas come through - most notably that psychiatrists, like the Psychlos, regard humans as mere animals (Psychlo/psychiatrist - get it?).  But nothing in the film is intrinsically Scientological.  Face it - Hubbard was about as subtle as a bull in a china shop.  Note, for example, the good guy/bad guy dichotomy in this film: the hero, Jonnie Goodboy (get it?) Tyler can do no wrong, while the evil Psychlos manipulate, exploit, blackmail, drink a vile green intoxicant called kerbango, and shoot the legs off cattle for kicks.  If you want Scientology propaganda, go read the 10-volume "Mission Earth" series, a heavy-handed monstrosity replete with obvious Scientology references.Rather, "Battlefield Earth" is a self-indulgent act of hero worship that John Travolta has finally put to film after nearly 20 years of trying.  L. Ron Hubbard was an over-hyped, self-promoting, mediocre writer with an inflated sense of his own worth to society, and in that respect "Battlefield Earth" is reflective of his character.  But as an SF movie, there have been worse films in the last couple of years.  "Armageddon" and "Soldier" come to mind.

reviews.review_title: So Much Worse Than You'd Expect
reviews.content: I put off seeing this film until 2 for 1 night at my video store, and even at this price I felt ripped off. I'd read the novel this is based on years before and wondered how something so talky and philosophical could be made into a film? The answer is, very very badly. The filmmakers wisely played down the philosophy, but were left with nothing more than a tangled & lame sci-fi tale that was dated when it was new.Now I'm a sci-fi fan and cut my favorite genera flicks a lot of slack, but here different sequences seem to have been done by different directors, as the tone shifts from bad to worse with awkward scatterings of forced humor. These shifts seem an attempt to disguise a confused screenplay that would have us believe that everything from paper books, to Harrier jets and atomic weapons will function just dandy after a millenium of neglect. This comes after we've seen that a few sessions on a teaching machine will enable an ambitious aboriginal and his pals to teleport atomic bombs and destroy entire planets. We also learn that humanity has sunk to the tribal edge of extinction and speak in `Me Tarzan' phrases that also include `Piece of cake' and `Get the hell out of here'. It all feels cut down from a much longer film, which could only have been worse then this one. The bombastic score tries to make us care about characters that we've never been introduced to, and tell us Johnny is doing something important while leaving us to only guess what that could be. Such important points are lost as we hear a lot of people talk about the importance of `leverage'. The special effects are a bright spot, as they are up to industry standards, however they hardly justify sitting through this film.What does justify you seeing this film is John Travolta's wondrously bad performance as the villainous alien Terl. With his beehive hairdo and giant high-heel shoes, Travolta looks like an outer space drag queen, which must be why he tries to be evil but only comes across as bitchy. His entire performance is delivered in an exaggerated effeminate manner that will remind you of some evil queen in a fairy tale, or of the cult classic `Vegas In Space'.  Alas, it doesn't make `Battlefield Earth' bad enough to be fun, it only makes it very very bad, so bad that you have to see it to believe it.

reviews.review_title: Should have been burned on a pyre.
reviews.content: Undoubtably the worst movie ever made.  Ed Wood never even came close to the depths of depravity and stupidity this colossal bomb exacts on its viewers.  I actually saw the film twice (well, almost twice).  I never thought it was possible for the film to appear any worse than it did the first and last time I beheld its malformed, festering stupidity.  Mind you, I don't even have the decency to give this film one-half star.  Personally, the film was so bad it tipped backwards to negative stars in numbers roughly equal to those found in the Dwarf Nebula.  Flies would avoid the grotesquely foul stink of it.  If you have even the slightest notion that it might be so bad it's funny, let me assure you it isn't.  This film is a rancorous insult to your intelligence.  There is simply no way for even a semi-intelligent viewer to suspend disbelief at any point in the story.

reviews.review_title: I Might Be the Only One, But I Liked It
reviews.content: I can see why John Travolta wanted to bring this story to the screen. It is funny, entertaining and even, dare I say it, inspirational.  I really don't see exactly why this movie has been lampooned more than any other in recent history. Watching the relationship between Travolta's Psychlo and his chief assistant is, by itself, worth the price of a rental.  And as far as the story goes, there is more intrigue, action, innuendo and irony than I have seen in many a movie trying harder to be intellectual than this one does.And the costumes!  The aliens are incredibly odd looking, but yet, just human enough that I can relate to them on some level. I would recommend this movie for anyone open minded enough to swim against the stream and judge the movie on its own merits and not simply based on what the media says about it.

I really enjoyed the movie and now it's great to be able see all the behind the scenes fx and secrets of filming.  My favorites include the camera angles and how the art director created the mood of the movie.

reviews.review_title: Basically, if you're an idiot, you will love this film
reviews.content: ...And judging from about a hundred of the responses here, there are many of you out there.  Some of the people here have asked how movies like this get made.  You need only read the user comments here to understand.For those people, I'll say this:  There are big 'splosions and lots of noise to take your mind off the problems ongoing in your life (your hair isn't as bouncy as it should be, Patsy told Megan that Grace told Bob that Mikey doesn't like you anymore, etc...)  There are cliches in this movie that, since you've probably never heard or understood before, will impress you. Plus, the good guys win, so you'll all sleep soundly at night under Mommy and Daddy's roof.For those of us who know how to tie are shoes, this movie is an insult. The plot holes have been covered in other comments, and are so unbelievable, you have to wonder if the producers cringed as they saw the finished product. Nothing saves this movie, and it's probably for the best.  Maybe these guys will be told "No!  Bad Director/Producer/Script" in the future.

reviews.review_title: This movie isn't so bad and I think it's quite actually good
reviews.content: It isn't that bad and It is actually one of my favourite movie's and It would be good of them to make a sequel, it was actually funny sometimes and the CG is good and I don't know why people think this movie is so bad. It is funny when Travolta is talking to Whitaker and he whip out the bartenders dead head and say our favourite bartender. It is a bit stupid when the humans learn to fly perfectly the jets and don't crash into a wall our nothing. Near the end of the movie when the dude has the nuclear bomb and explodes it on the Phsychlo home planet they blow up a couple of planets and kill like probably a 10 billion physchlos. Other than all this the movie was very good and should have made a trilogy.OR WILL THEY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!1

reviews.review_title: The film was true to the book!
reviews.content: It was very hard to go to see a movie that I had already read the book of but I found it very true to the original concept of the author.  It would have been incredibly difficult to have gotten a book of that magnitude translated onto screen.  I think John Travolta did a great job in his role and working to get the movie made in the first place.  A great triumph!

I felt compelled to write my comments after seeing so many vehemently negative comments about this film. The movie had its departures from the book & it ran into trouble when it did that. It reminded me of an artistic, European production in its coloration, textures, angles & general tone.The major weakness for me was that it moved so very fast, I had a hard time keeping up with it, so I saw it a second time, with my family.  I liked it better the 2nd time & saw minor bits of clever dialogue or nuances of character that whizzed by the first time.  It was there but too fast to be easily accessible. I had read the book years ago & have also heard the Roddy McDowell audio book production.  I consider the book a complete, detailed universe of characters with a timeless message & story - simply great!So when I saw the movie, it clicked with me.  It was enjoyed by my family, too.  My grandson laughs at Terl's antics, seeing him as a stupid villain who loses.If any person reads this wondering about Battlefield Earth, I would only say, read the book...if you like it, then see the movie

reviews.review_title: Should have been a low budget miniseries
reviews.content: John Travolta's acting was over the top.  The story line was completely unbelievable, even for science fiction.  Decent special effects and a good acting job by Barry Pepper make the film close to bearable, but not quite.
Thought it was a sci fi spoof movie and it even failed at that. At least i dozed off for an hour and that's the only good thing about this disaster.

reviews.review_title: Very interesting take on a great book
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth takes on the challenge of turning an epic, 1000-page novel into a 2 hour movie and pulls it off in a very interesting way. Fortunately, the novel has a logical dividing point half way through and the movie takes on only the first half of the book.To capture the spirit of the book, the film makers had to combine fast action with complex plot elements, humor and aliens who are developed characters (not just cartoon adversaries for the hero). Even divided in half, the book had 500 pages to do that.The film makers do it by stripping the plot back to it's key elements and turning up the speed to maximum velocity. This is a fast movie and you'll probably end up seeing it twice to absorb it all. If you've read the novel you'll have a few favorite characters that you miss seeing. Of course, if you haven't, there's a whole lot more story to look forward to in the book.In any case, Travolta and Whitaker pull off their performances as the scheming aliens while the cinematography and special effects give the film an unusual and cohesive visual style. Once you get caught up in the rhythm of it there a lot of humor in the very exuberant script.Another thing that I liked about Battlefield Earth is that, like Star Wars, it maintains non-stop action without turning to the blood and gore that mar many films these days.As a fan of the book I was nervous about what the film makers might do to the story. I was very happy with the movie. I put it among my top sf films of all time along with Star Wars, 2001 and Bladerunner. I think a reviewer once described the book as a combination of Star Wars and Raiders of the Lost Ark. The movie manages to capture that. It's a lot of fun and I'm looking forward to part 2.

"suspend disbelief."You know how many movies have reviews which state "suspend disbelief"?That is not possible with this film.It is that bad. One cannot suspend disbelief! 2 stars as a tribute to the actors and actresses who kept straight face and worked on this.

I have a feeling that this film will be appreciated more as time goes on. I also speculate that if a young person saw it, without preconceptions, that he or she would respond quite favorably.There is a simplicity and strength to the performances and the story that is surprisingly moving.John Travolta gives a brave perfomance, sticking his neck out and doing a great job.  Barry Pepper is terriific!This movie is classic sci fi, in ideas and form.

reviews.review_title: As bad as The Phantom Menace without the benefit of nostalgia
reviews.content: First off, this movie is not as bad as everyone has seemed to make it sound. Don't get me wrong, it's bad, just not that bad.This movie tries to be a lot of things and fails at every one. The problem with this movie, and why it will probably not become even a cult classic like some have said, is that it is almost good. It hovers just below the line of good and bad, so I was unable to even enjoy riotous laughter like I did at Starship Troopers. It's a strange thing to say, but this movie is neither good enough nor bad enough to be enjoyable.As for the elements of the movie, the acting is terrible, the effects are so-so, and the story develops at a good pace for the first hour then speeds through the next two hours of story in less than one. A pet peeve of mine as well, and George Lucas could deal with hearing the same thing, is that the quick scenes and all the wipes really do look ridiculous. Maybe when wipes were first introduced in film, they were cool for their novelty, but these days they are just annoying.To review: Definitely not the worst movie I've ever seen, and that may be to its detriment. Travolta really messed up here. I've never read the book, but it seemed like many of the sequences in the movie were just bad puns and cliches, and I would hope Mr. Hubbard was a better writer than that--although, Psychlo is a pretty awful pun.Definitely stay away from this film. It does not offer even "it's so bad, it's good" entertainment.

reviews.review_title: AMAZING! BREATHTAKING! BETTER THAN STAR WARS!
reviews.content: There are no words to describe it.  Awesome?  Hardly.  The level of awe this movie inspires cannot be described.  Breathtaking?  Not quite...while watching this I don't think I even breathed once.  For a long time Sci-Fi fans have looked for something better than Star Wars...and I think we all agree, this is it.Where to even start?  The characters?  Johnny-Goodboy's name alone gives you a good idea of the incredible depth his character brings.  You can almost see the emotions rumbling in Johhnys face...a no-doubt acadamy award for his performance.  But where does that leave Travolta, with his performance that with all respect...blows every performance ever given away.  The way Travolta laughs at the expense of the human shows just how evil this character is.  How evil?  Far more evil than anything ever before.  The sight of Travoltas character by the end of the movie made me nearly leave the theater.But we haven't even gotten started.  The metaphors...oh the metaphors! This movie is filled with them...symbolism that can inspire everyday people to lead a bettter life.  Johnny-Goodboys quest to save the world symbolizes the burning passion inside everyones heart to be a hero.  The way the aliens have those snot tubes coming out of their noses represents the snot tubes we all have coming from our noses...the tubes that represent our love. Our love for one another, and our love for ourselves.The special affects?  I could go on forever!  The way dirt was thrown across the screen to show the great explosions of spacecraft was magnificent.  It already holds it oscar.  And the camera tilt that was used in nearly every scene? Undescribably.  It was like looking at perfection through a window.I WOULD RATE THIS MOVIE, BUT WE ALL AGREE IT DOESNT NEED IT.  A FILM LIKE THIS DOESNT NEED TO BE CLARIFIED AS THE BEST FILM TO EVER BE MADE.

reviews.review_title: Introducing: Battlefield Earth, The Drinking Game
reviews.content: Last time I checked I was a sci-fi buff, but this movie is making me reassess that. I'm going to have to re-watch some good SF movies to get back to enjoying that genre.Before I get to the announced game part, I'll list three things I found highly annoying about this film [semi-spoilers below]:The entire dog concept was, sadly, never developed on. Some interaction between Psychlos and dogs would have added a lot of humor, warmth and intelligence to this movie. The linguistic implications of this film are mind-boggling. Psychlos are depicted as a species fairly keen on intelligence work and surveillance, but still don't bother to keep anyone on staff who can a. figure out that human languages work about the same as psychlo ones and b. spoil the entire human liberation thing by even listening in every now and then. Truly sad. Another one would be the phrase "man-animal" which is either a bad translation from an Elron fantasy or a tiresome contradiction; if the Psychlos are unable to communicate with man, how come they would use a phrase like that? Flash Gordon is beginning to look like a really good film.What's up with the symbolism? Take the necklace, which was clearly introduced to be mockingly destroyed by the psychlos. Was there any effect in that?Now for the official rules on how to be able to enjoy this film and make it worth watching:Load your DVD player with Battlefield Earth. Put the movie on auto-repeat. Lean back and enjoy:Every time Travolta says "leverage", take a swig of beer.Every time Travolta says "man-animal", take two swigs.Every time Pepper is choked, down a shot of tequila.Repeat. Eventually the word "leverage" will start to bug you, "man-animal" will make you cringe and you'll have forced yourself to enough empathy with Pepper's character to appreciate every minute he goes un-choked.This movie proves, like so many before it, that a couple of big names or a big budget cannot save a project destined to doom. I will say this: I noticed today that this is just about the only non-R-rated movie in my DVD collection. This is perfectly fine, except the lack of blood is contrived to the point of making the viewer confused (my room mate didn't quite figure out what happened with some of the arms here). Are Scientologists really that desperate to get underage people to watch their 3rd-level propaganda?

Wow, this could have been the sci-fi epic they're STILL claiming this to be, cause the second half of this just turned into absolute garbage.  I watched this for free on the plane, and had to force myself to not switch it for something else.

The movie takes off at a gallop and you are catching your breath the whole time.  The effects are excellent, the acting outstanding.  Travolta makes a truly believable villain.  I think the biggest challenge was to fit a very large novel into a movie only two hours long--it was a tight fit, but believable.

If you were bored out of your mind and this was the only movie you can watching it regret but its not a enjoyable film by any means. The story is weird and not believable. It feels like a rip off of better more classic Science Fiction Novels and Films. If you are on the fence about watching this I would recommend you save your time

reviews.review_title: Come on people , it's not that bad.
reviews.content: When i first saw this film i was ten and immediately i fell in love with it. I believe it gave the message of the strength of the human spirit but when i watch it now, well it's not as i remember. At first i had no background knowledge like Travolta was just bowing to the will and bizarre and pedophilic tendencies of good old LRH. I dono , i mean it is entertaining and still has elements of a time not so sceptical and more naive but essentially it's just great to watch when your drunk or stoned. If you get bored than think of Saturday Night Fever or Pulp Fiction.It always works for me.

My god! This movie was so awful, thinking about it makes me ill. I can't even remember enough of the plot to spoil it if I wanted to. I think I must have blocked it all out. What I do remember are, flashing across the screen, the giant closeups of John Travolta and whoever else, and their TEETH. Their teeth were all grungy and disgusting. I wanted to throw toothbrushes at the screen. I don't know whether this appearance on their part was deliberate or some freak accident, but it scared me. Very much.Who would spend that much money to make something this terrible? Really now. When I saw it in the theatre, my friend and I actually left the movie in the middle, went out to the lobby of the theatre, and played the claw machines for about half an hour, until we had each won a stuffed animal of some kind (I think they were rabbits, but I could be mistaken), then went back inside (only because we had come with a bunch of other people who would be rather irate if we abandoned them at the theatre) and hadn't missed a thing.
Of the absolute worst movies I had ever seen. I am 74 years old & have been a movie goer since I was a child.

Please, do not compare the movie with the 3 books of L. Ron Hubbard. We all know that books are always better. Battlefield Earth is one on the best Science Fiction movies I have seen in the last years. And I have seen many S.F. movies! John Travolta as Terl, the Psychlo Chief of Security, is very good in his job. Ok, while watching the film, you have the impression, that everything goes a bit to fast. But that is the problem when you try to include every detail of the novel into the movie. At the end I want to make clear that 80% of all Science Fiction movies are bad!! So if there is a good S.F. movie coming out like Battlefield Earth, do not vote so hard. I feel bad if you only give 2,5 points to such a good S.F. movie.
One of my favorite insomnia movies. A giant version of the Ferengi.

I read the book around 10 years ago, in fact I read it several times, the story is fabulous, original, I just love it. So I had to go and see it in theater. I was a bit afraid of the result, but I've been amazed. The adaptation of the book is well done (despite the changes which are by the way logical and clever), the spirit of the book is there. What I particularly appreciated about this film is the way it's done, I mean it's original, images, music and sounds are so powerful, different. While watching it you are indeed in an other world. This film is different, it's not a copy or is not inspired by an other film. It's more like a research of an new way of filming. Some kind of a preview of new science fiction. My conclusion is I love it. I know what I'm talking about, I'm an ardent sci-fi fan. P.S. This comment is only a comment about a film I particularly appreciated nothing else.

L. Ron Hubbard would have advised against doing this movie because he had a realistic view of his writing skills. He was a gun for hire and paid by the word for any pulp genre. Scientologists should read Hubbard's prefaces to the very books they so venerate. Aside from being too long a book, the pulp formula made the characterization shallow and cheesy. Aliens talked as if they stepped off the street of an American city so there was little hope of anything good coming out of it. Combine this with heavy backseat driving from Travolta and the church of Scientology and you have the Ideal film to show students what not to do. It was not an accident they chose Christian to direct. The book spent a lot of time justifying and explaining the improbable story, a luxury you can't afford in film. It festered Right down to the ludicrous alien costumes with their huge over-sized boots that actually had made the Psychlos smaller and awkward. I believe Travolta and Kelly will need some extra sessions on the E meter to get back up on the Scientology food chain. They should take a tip from Mr. Hubbard who was never blinded by Faith and adoration. They might also read up on Heinlein one of his best buddies who wrote "Stranger in a Strange Land" the basis for Rael and company. Both men hated Psychology and loved a good joke. Great guys, but they would have choked on their pop-corn had they seen this film

I have just watched this film, but I did read the review here on IMDb before doing so.I must say I found the story line of the movie to be alright. There were many areas of the story that could of, and should have been explained or covered better.The action in the film is simple, and I don't feel it was under done in that respect.I enjoyed the actors, and they did good job to help score the film better for me.I didn't expect much going into the movie, given that it has taken out so many awards for being so BAD, but I was surprised. The story needed more and the end was way too quick.Worth a once off look, Overall i gave the film 3/10

Surprisingly true to the book (a real feat due to the book's size and sheer brilliance!), great special effects, acting and cinematography. I laughed at the unexpected scenes (cameo by Kelly Preston, "curbango" pun uttered by the Ker character, and more).  My favorite scene was the planet Psychlo -- they handled this far better than I thought possible.  This was great sci-fi! I'm definitely getting the video and I can't wait to see the sequel and how the 'little gray man' is handled.

I enjoyed the movie.  It was very fast paced and I had to watch it twice before I got a couple of important pieces of the plot - so pay attention!The special effects are amazing.  Especially the part where ... (I won't spoil it for you) ... the audience was stunned after that one.If you read the book then don't expect the movie to be the same, it is quite different, but stands up on its own.BTW, the book totally rocks.

reviews.review_title: watch this movie for historical reasons
reviews.content: The main reason to watch Battlefield Earth is because this movie is the bad movie by which all other bad movies will be judged.I was able to overcome many of my critiques of this movie because the production values are in fact high enough. The sets well done, the camera for the most part are well handled, etc. Definitely the dialog could be improved though. The biggest problem is that after 1000 years there would be no harrier jump jets; the fuel would have long since turned into lacquer and hardened into semi-plastic, and every rubber seal would have long since disintegrated into dust. Not only would would there be no functional aircraft, these people with the mentality of 3-year-olds cannot believably learn to fly fighter jets and achieve what the worlds greatest military powers were unable to do 1000 years ago. (let alone the fact that the aliens have had an additional 1000 years of advancement since then, btw.)

Eleven thumbs up! (Psychlos have a base 11 number system) :-) Non-stop action, cool special effects and I don't think anybody but Travolta could have played Terl. Having read the book, I think they did a remarkable job considering the technical difficulties of translating the book to the screen. You have to read the book to really appreciate that. This movie goes on my list of all-time favorites.

I maybe a little late in commenting this film, however films like this come along very rarely and thus justify comment regardless. As an avid reader of science fiction and adventure stories during my youth, I read Battlefield Earth and thoroughly enjoyed it. I would actually go as far as to say it was one of my favourite books at the time [perhaps my tastes were less refined]. Even then I was aware that L. Ron Hubbard was a rather unbalanced character, as his Scientology church headquarters were less than 10 km from where I lived, and thus the ravings of the church were general knowledge in my home county. I wondered then if the book would ever become a film, hoping that it would. So when the film finally made it, I was concerned by the reviews it was getting, surely it couldn't be that bad. Now I have to be honest, I have not seen the entire movie. Battlefield Earth is the only film that I found so bad that I was unwilling to endure its entirety. I have seen many bad films in my time, but normally they begin to take on a comical character which allows their continued viewing. Battlefield Earth has no redeeming factors whatsoever. I would suggest that Battlefield Earth is more damaging to the church of scientology than the madness that they preach.

reviews.review_title: Nowhere near as bad as the critics say.
reviews.content: Well, I never pay the critics much heed anyways.  I went to see Wild Wild West twice, and The World is not Enough four times, so that should tell you something about the kind of movies I like. The negative reviews (I think if critics could give negative star ratings, they would have given them to this film)  were part of what drove me to this film, along with my love of science fiction movies. I found the movie quite easy to watch, and the plot easy to follow, unlike what most film critics have said.  And when people complain about how the movie copies from all sorts of other movies, Planet of the Apes, Independance Day, and Godzilla, I have to say that this is not the first time those concepts have been copied, and those movies were not the first times the "cliched" sequences were put on celluloid, either.  Dog fights and bleak future worlds are a staple of science fiction, critics should know to expect them, instead of moaning when they show up. The movie was good for what it was, a summer popcorn science fiction movie.  Lots of action, explosions, and special effects, which is what I go to movies for, anyways. There were a few problems, though.  The lighting was bad, and for a race that dislikes all the blue and green on Earth, the Psychlos use a lot of blue and green lights inside their own buildings. Also, I find it a little hard to belive that the human military hardware would work after 1000 years gathering dust.  These are about the only two points I agree with the critics on. If you actually go in to watch the movie, instead of concentrating on the fact that L. Ron Hubbard started Dianetics, you'd probably find most of Terl's plan made sense. Overall, not a masterpiece, but certainly not worth the scathing reviews it has received.

My friends and I laughed until we cried.  Scene for scene, the best example of everything you shouldn't do in a movie.  Plot holes the size of the Grand Canyon.  A nuclear bomb that destroys a planet!  "Man-animals"!! "Breath-gas"!!  Oh, God!!  A real treat for those of you who loved Plan 9 from Outer Space.  There's no point to this movie other than a wimpy protest against mean people.  In the end, I ended sympathising with the villain. He was the only one that showed any human-like qualities anyway.

This movie is amazing from start-to-finish. Battlefield Earth is a fascinating work of art and everyone involved with this film should be nominated for the Academy Awards. Everything about it is just so compelling. If I could give Battlefield Earth a higher rating I wouldn't let it pass by like a cold day in Hell. Scientology rules!

reviews.review_title: A movie ruined by bad directing and a lopsided cameraman
reviews.content: After hearing the bad reviews of this movie in the theatres I waited for the video release; I'm glad I did. After having condensed the lengthy and improbable plot laid out in L. Ron Hubbard's masterpiece of bad writing into a much better written script and managing to lay hands on a few noteworthy actors it is amazing how terribly the makers of this film screwed up what could have been a decent money making film. By far the worst mistake of the film was hiring the idiot that decided the movie needed to be filmed entirely at a 45-degree angle. The camera doesn't lay flat with the horizon once during this film and my neck is cramped still. This flaw although perhaps not consciously noted by all viewers was distracting enough that it completely drowned out the plot and acting (not that the latter was a bad thing) with unnecessarily annoying and excessive camera tilting and badly placed movements. I've never actually seen a movie that could be ruined by bad cinematography but apparently this goes down as the first. Save yourself time and aggravation and don't watch this movie, or for that matter the book. Avoid L. Ron Hubbard's work at all costs and pray John Travolta's association with him hasn't cost him his amazing come back (though it may be too late for that). This movie SUCKED!!

reviews.review_title: I won't be converting to Scientology anytime soon.
reviews.content: You know, if the Matrix never came around, I never would have seen this movie.  However, that (expletive) movie made me think that sci-fi movies were on their way back.  Then I saw Pitch Black, the second worst movie I ever saw in a theater (1st place will always be "Daylight," starring Sylvester Stallone).  And now I have seen Battlefield Earth.  It might be a long time before I watch a sci-fi movie again. I just have a hard time believing, as many others have, that a superior race could find strains of gold in the Rocky Mountains but not find Fort Knox. I find it hard to believe that cave and forest dwellers who thought that statues were frozen people could learn how to pilot a Harrier in a week. Now it occurred to me that perhaps they learned it that quickly because, after all, it is a thousand years from now and surely the brain has evolved, but I mean, they think STATUES are frickin' PEOPLE.
