We were engaged through out the entire movie with his ruthless and heartless character which he did a fine job portraying. It was interesting to see mankind as a "lesser species" forced to be slaves to a alien race. The masterly and entirely arrogant alien Travolta plays is most believable and menacing. He struts around like a bull in a bull fight threatening any second to erupt and destroy anything, any idea and anyone in his way! You keep thinking where is his weakness? You will never see the surprising ending of this movie coming! But you will be so pleased at the sudden twist of fate it affords! Can't say more or would give it away. Watch this movie if you love fun grade B Sci Fi and enjoy John Travolta movies in general. Travolta is a blast in this underrated movie.

First of all...did these people read the book at all?  sure it's a huge book but does that mean lots of main characters should get cut out.  The movie was nothing like i thought it would be.  Its almost completely different. I'd see the movie again, i just wouldnt spend my own money on the dvd.

reviews.review_title: However, not as good as book, not bad either
reviews.content: science fiction is where this would be on the shelf, not religious. I don't understand what is so bad about this movie. I thought the book was great. I had high expectation for the film; even though, I had heard mostly bad reviews. I don't feel like I was let down. I feel like they leave a lot of things out in movies. there's always the time constraint. There is of course a difference in media format, allowing to get the story with audio/visuals and in less time than reading thousands of pages. I am not going to spoil anything in this movie for anyone. if you haven't seen it and you manage to see it it it will NOT kill you:) you will live. you may or may not feel cheated. you may or may not be depressed. You may or may not want to be audited. anyway I have to take up ten lines in order to post :) so run over to youtube and watch the scientology episode of southpark if you want to watch some funny $#!% about what some may call a cult.

I really wanted to write a damning review of this piece of absolute tripe but, unfortunately, in an attempt to save me from a life of total depression and regret at having wasted not only the price of admission to a cinema but also 2 hours of my life, my mind has jettisoned most of the memories of the painful experience that Battlefield Earth proved to be.I spent the first half of the film in intense pain as I struggled with the conflict between my intense dislike for wasting money and my more intense dislike for films staring John Travolta as a Rasta-haired alien with bad dialogue.  Thankfully I have been spared seeing his other such films by the Cult of Sirius - a scientology based alien species that as removed most of Travolta's work to their home planet where it forms the basis of their intergalactic invasion plans.I spent the second half of the film in increasingly intense pain as my internal organs ruptured under the pressure of sustained laughing fits.Memories occasionally do leak through, sometimes waking me in the middle of the night to a vision of man, practically regressed to the level of an ape after the destruction of his entire civilisation over a millennia ago, conquering a technologically advanced species by figuring out how to operate VSTOL aircraft.  In a week.  My mind turned inside out by the illogic of these nightmares allows it's defenses to drop and more memories slip through.  The acting!  Oh, God, the acting!  Please mother, no more, I'll be a good boy.  I still get flashbacks of grinning, razor-toothed aliens bragging about 'leverage' with reference to influence about as compelling as a kidnapped lunchbox.The only possible use for this film would be to overlay it with Beethoven and use it to cure Malcolm McDowell of his violent tendencies.If you devise a rating system which awards Police Academy 8: Mission to Moscow a number of stars equal to the number that the Hubble space telescope is capable of observing I would still find it blasphemous to award a single asterisk to this piece of crap.

Never has there ever been such an enormous gap in the difference between the book and the movie. Take your pick. The immense differences and flat out omissions and ignoring of some of the most key parts of the book. Or perhaps that even the movie alone is simply awful, where as the book shines as one of the greatest science fiction stories ever. It was as if they just looked at the names in the book, and the cover and made an entire different movie that fell under the "cliche, obvious and predictable cinematic dung heap" category. the book is over a thousand pages long, they ignorantly skimmed through and made scenes and story lines that took nearly the entire book to work out and unfirl.

reviews.review_title: Watch it with an open mind!
reviews.content: I've just read a great deal of negative comments for this movie. With the exception of one part where it could have been sped up a bit, I thoroughly enjoyed it.I'm one of those people who look for story first, technology second. This movie had enough special effects to make it believable and that is enough, in my own humble opinion.Rent it, watch it with an open mind. Then watch it again. It's really a good movie disguised as a bad one.  (Of course, it might possibly have to do with my age:-)

I thought Battlefield Earth was something new and refreshingly different. The movie has a totally unique look - a trashed, grimy, alien-industrial look, which is quite a relief from all those squeaky-clean, white plastic space interiors.  The "dutch" angle photography and use of blues and greys gave the movie, for me, a unique feel, quite unlike anything else I have ever seen.John Travolta is brilliant as Terl - he really nailed that evil alien thing - and is funny as well.  The rivalry between him and Forest Whitaker's character was one of the more amusing aspects of the movie.  Barry Pepper's performance was outstanding.  I'm sure he is destined to become a major star.  The scene where he decides to unite the man-animals and free mankind from the evil Psychlos was really moving.  The Psychlo Planetary Head was totally disgusting, in a fun, grossed-out alien way.And to top it all, Roger Christian delivered some amazing special effects. One in particular even got a huge applause from the audience!  All in all, I loved this movie, and can't wait for the sequel.  It's a whole load of fun, with amazing special effects and tons of great action sequences.  A must-see for any sci-fi lover.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as they say!?
reviews.content: I have read numerous reviews and reports slating this movie. The movie is not perfect (what movie is?), but it is at least a bit of no brain fun. I am aware that a lot of the anti-battlefield feeling is actually concerned with the fact that it has links with scientology. I am *not* a scientologist. I do feel that any body has the right to make a movie, regardless of religion or belief. As for the claims that the whole film is a scientology recruitment film; How? Please explain 'cos all I saw was some guys in costumes having a laugh. Don't just believe everything you read. Hire the tape. The plot and script are no worse (or no better ;o)) Than George Lucas' Star Wars: The Phantom Menace. The effects may be a little on the cheap side, but it is a (fairly) low budget movie. Give it a chance.

reviews.review_title: I feel like I've seen it already
reviews.content: I have not seen this movie yet, but I felt it important to post a message beforehand.  I can't directly comment on the movie, but I can comment on everything that went into it.  Being that I know a good amount about the Church of Scientology, Travolta's styles, the current reviews, entertainment, and the common "agenda" movie format, I can go into the theatre considering the really wide range of reviews I've read on this site and, hopefully, come out with a simple opinion/understanding of the movie and it's qualities.  I've read that it's a great movie, that it should be rated at 0, that it is a good circumlocution from the equally good book, that it is a brain-numbing agenda movie, etc.etc....I like Travolta's acting which can make someone compassionate, no matter what role he plays, but I dislike Hubbard's Mensa-like arrogance.  I prefer to watch sci-fi movies, especially those which have good environment development, like Dune or Star Wars.  From secondhand information, it seems that this movie will have well portrayed environment.  Furthermore, I like movies with a hint of conquest/reconquest of land and property, which, to the best of my understanding, there is here.  I have no reason to disbelieve user-comments, and since I am a user of the same database, I would tend to relate to them more than to, say, newspaper articles.  Overall, I have a truly mixed preconception/prejudice about this movie.I guess I'll just have to find out.  Wish me luck (as I hear it is now hard to find).  This will be sort of an experiment.(I welcome discussion and debate.  Emails would be fine, though my response may be slow.)

reviews.review_title: Waste of Time, Talent, Money, DO NOT SEE
reviews.content: I admit this movie was spawned from Scientology.  Yes, L. Ron Hubbard may be a highly regarded writer in the science-fiction community, but he has yet to receive honor for his work in a movie.  All the movies adapted from his novels are bad.  This is because the only movie adapted from a Hubbard novel is Battlefield Earth. Let's get all the good parts of it out now.  I liked the special effects. They were pretty cool, but they're not ILM material.  Thats about it for the good parts.  (Except for the fact the sound went out at the end and I got to make up my own dialogue). For the real skinny on it- its awful.  Yes Battlefield Earth is a true flop- an utter embarrassment to filmmaking.  It wasn't even entertaining. Its shame lied in the following parts: 1)-  Dialogue- whoever wrote this dialogue sucks. I have never heard more corny lines since Starship Troopers.  The writer did not even attempt to give the dialogue variety.  I will never use the word "leverage" again and not grimace at the sound.  What the hell was that all about anyway?  Also- Travolta said about Earth "I hate this stinkin' planet" and "I can't wait to get off this wretched planet" and every other variation you could think of- REPEATEDLY.  The script is awful. 2)-  Hire a new editor. Every single transition between scenes was the same. Variation must be a problem with this crew.  Even worse than no variety was the embarrassing one they picked to use.  A wipe from the middle? It was embarrassing for me to watch.  The editor might have well had used a star wipe.  It would have been just as stupider and silly.  Silliness is not a word that should be associated with sci-fi movies. So don't pick a silly wipe.  Editor- hope someone throws an AVID at you and you die.3)-  The people.  Travolta must have done this as a favor to some Hollywood honcho, or it must have been a labor of love.  Maybe he thought that the Scientology community would look up to him if he produced and starred in its founder's novel.  Whatever he did it for, it disgraced sci-fi movies for a long time.  He set back the public's appreciation of Science Fiction movies maybe all the way to Star Wars.  Thats more than 25 years Travolta kicked the genre back.   Also- Barry Pepper, how could you follow Saving Private Ryan with this?? Anyway, I hated all the slo-mo shots of Pepper running and yelling.  They looked cheesy anyway without the cliched score pacing it through. Moreover, the cast was tired. They bored me and looked as if they showed up with a hangover every morning on set.  Maybe it was all that time in make-up for stupid looking costumes.  But Forest Whittaker- you need someone to give you better roles.  You deserve it.  You are very good when you choose the right roles.  (Ghost Dog, God Morning Vietnam)  But frankly you pick bad roles frequently (Species, this movie)  You just grunted your way to a paycheck here with Travolta.  You derserve just as much blame for flopiness.Battlefield Earth is an embarrassment to Science Fiction.  Those people who don't take it seriously have one more reason to solidify that opinion. Don't waste your money- Battlefield Earth has no redeeming qualities, (you can always see Special FX in Stuart Little and at least get a laugh).  Oh wait, Traovlta got a laugh, 18 laughs actually.  I counted 18 laughs in this movie.  He must have been going to the bank.

I have to say that Travolta is about the best sci-fi villain I've ever seen. His Terl is a hoot. Not only is the character savagely villainous, he's also incredibly inept and short sighted. This was true in the book and Travolta brought that characterization to life with brilliance. In my book he should be praised for an outstanding performance. (The scene with his wife, Kelly Preston, is also pretty unforgettable! She's great, too.)

Another point of view..."Battlefield Earth," based on the best-selling novel by L. Ron Hubbard, is a rousing, action-packed, sci-fi adventure which evokes the best of "Star Wars," "Braveheart," and "Independence Day."  Roger Christian's direction is first-rate; the production design is incredibly detailed, and makes you believe that this is the war-torn world of 3000 A.D.  The eye-popping special effects are an integral part of the film, and not just some showcase. The storyline is thoughtful, inspired, and ironically amusing, and the acting is top-notch.  This film is the reason why science fiction movies are always best-received out of the summer's blockbusters, and just a heck-of-a-lot of fun. Fun is the key word here--for this film is a great deal of fun. I laughed and cheered and cried and clapped, and enjoyed every moment and every aspect of the production from beginning to end.  It is one of the best science fiction films to come along in the last few years. Part of the reason for that is the fact that it is a literate film, based upon a literate novel. Most good SF films can trace their origins to good books--like "Contact," "Logan's Run," "Planet of the Apes," and "2001." "Battlefield Earth" is not merely a retread of pop-culture icons.  (I'm so tired of seeing "Alien" retreads or "Blade Runner" retreads or "Star Wars" retreads!!). The production also shows a love for the genre of science fiction, and not the cynicism that was shown with "Armageddon."  It is clear from the movie that the people who made "Battlefield Earth" wanted to make a fun movie that was thoughtful and inspired for fans of the science fiction genre.The artistry behind "Battlefield Earth" is most apparent as well, from the very first scenes through the last reel of the film. I have already mentioned the film's wonderful production design, but beyond the matte paintings and large-scale sets, there's a true artistry to how the motion picture was composed. The director of photography and lighting technicians create a wonderful metaphor using simple light and darkness in the composition of scenes.For example, when we first meet Jonnie, the primitive protagonist, his scenes are filmed with the warmth of sunlight glinting off rugged mountains and green pastures.  Later, when he allies himself with other primitives, the scenes are again in bright light, showing in a metaphorical sense how important and essential it is to band together against the hostile aliens. Even the gold in Fort Knox glows with a very warm light.  Those scenes are contrasted against darker ones which show the Psychlo homeworld and the dome-city that they have made out of old Denver.  The scenes are very dark, filmed with cold blue and dark green textures...you can almost feel the claustrophobia, death, and destruction in those sequences.The Psychlos are dark, dastardly aliens who have enslaved humanity and are strip-mining the planet, and what better way to portray this agenda than with the play of shadow and light.  Similarly, the dissolves between scenes are handled with an artistry that I haven't seen in motion pictures in years; in fact, I can't recall the use of such dissolves unless I go  all the way back to the original 1977 "Star Wars," and the editors on that film won an Academy Award for their work.  In "Battlefield Earth," the dissolves move each scene forward like pages turning in a novel...and this artistic texture reinforces its literary heritage.Finally, but not lastly, the music is rousing and triumphant, and stitches each sequence of the film together with an artistry of its own. Today, most films opt for a collage of popular hits; few present music of such a high caliber which recalls the best of John Williams or Hans Zimmer or John Barry. After the first viewing, most movie-goers tend to remember great special efforts or large action-adventure sequences in a film, and miss the subtle artistry behind a motion picture; however, repeated viewings often show a great deal more."Battlefield Earth" is the kind of motion picture achievement that holds up to multiple viewings.John Travolta gives one of his best performances in recent years as the wicked alien Terl with the all-to-human vices.  Several years ago, the great action-adventure hero Arnold Schwarzenegger took a chance by playing a villainous robot in James Cameron's "The Terminator," and became an even bigger star by playing against his heroic archetype. Travolta wisely chose the same path, and plays against his golden-boy image (forget Tony Manero here) to play one of the screen's great villains, with equal parts of Shakespeare's Iago and George Lucas's Darth Vader.  I had always respected Travolta's body of work as an actor, but could not count myself as a true fan until now; his turn as the chief baddie in "Battlefield Earth" is wonderfully wicked and delicious.  Forrest Whitaker also turns in a fine performance as his lieutenant, and I just loved Kelly Preston's cameo as the long-tongued alien. Barry Pepper is just superb as the primitive human Jonnie who leads the other primitives in a battle against the Psychlos.  He is not just another action-adventure hero in the Bruce Willis and Sly Stallone mold, but an actor who shows that he is thinking and feeling his way through impossible and improbable situations.  You actually think that he is thinking behind his cool exterior, and that's what makes him most believable for movie-goers.  He was sensational as the sharpshooter in "Saving Private Ryan," and shows that he's going to be a big star with his lead role here.I have a minor quibble with the movie and from what I have read of other critics this criticism is a familiar one.  In the film, the primitive humans learn to fly F-14s in less than a week's time.  I called a friend of mine in the Air Force, and he told me that was likely impossible; the primitive humans might be able to get the planes airborne, and might even be able to fire the plane's sophisticated weapons, but its highly unlikely they would be able to maneuver and land "worth a damn."Okay, so this is something that we are supposed to take on faith--a cinematic verisimilitude.  After all, the humans in "Independence Day" learn how to fly sophisticated aircraft is less than a day, and that misstep didn't keep the movie from becoming a huge blockbuster.  So, why not simply accept one more suspension of disbelief?For months, I have been listening to critics deride this film simply because of Hubbard and Travolta and their connection to Scientology, and after seeing the film, I must conclude that they are all wrong.  Deriding this film because of its connections to Scientology is like deriding a Barry Levinson film because of his ethnic background and his ethnic storylines and characters.  The film  "Battlefield Earth" should be taken on its merits or criticized for its shortcomings alone, quite separate and apart from this issue.On the whole, I would rate this film very highly--a must see!Dr. John L. Flynn, English Department, Towson University, Maryland, Member, SFWA

reviews.review_title: A picture is worth a thousand words...
reviews.content: .. but not in this scattered dismemberment of a classic novel. The book Battlefield Earth is one of my favourites and I was quite dismayed by this poor adaptation of it.I did like Barry Pepper, although his running ability is probably what got him the part.  It seems that Barry running slow motion was the focus of this film.The novel was a tremendous story with depth and character, but the movie was slapped together without the same care.  I can't believe that Travolta is actually happy with the results of his crusade to make this film.Don't waste your time on this film.  Go see Gladiator and then go home and read Battlefield: Earth.Rating 3/10

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people say...but still bad...
reviews.content: I actually thought this was okay. I wasn't expecting much so I wasn't disappointed, lol. I like Barry Pepper so this was tolerable.

reviews.review_title: Read the book, see the movie
reviews.content:
I've seen a lot of science fiction movies and the best ones offer something unique and different from the rest. Battlefield Earth is in that category. The director, Roger Christian, had his own vision for the movie and he created a dark world dominated by the alien Psychlos. Some of the special effects created for the movie were incredible. I saw the interview with Christian on the DVD and given the actual budget that he said he had to work with to make the movie, you have to be impressed at what he created. I also feel he got an excellent performance out of John Travolta. There was a lot of very dry humor which came out of the alien character played by him. This was one of the most enjoyable aspects of the film.
The book by L. Ron Hubbard that the movie is based on is a great read and fully lives up to its reputation as one of the great science fiction novels. One can read it and visualize many incredible actions sequences which never made it into the movie. At over 1000 pages there was so much going on that the best thing one can do is to read the book. You will not only have had the pleasure of reading a great story, you will probably understand the movie a lot better as well.

Not a great movie, not the terrible one it's made out to be either. I'd rather watch this than something like "Epic Movie." Here were the problems I saw in the movie. 1. Camera work, it almost seems to easy to point this out at this point. 2. Acting, again almost too easy. 3. Writing, again too easy. 4. I feel if this had been more faithful to the book there would have been more watch-ability. I can't say it for certain but the book wasn't that bad. Or at least... not THIS bad. I did however, come up with a drinking game for this movie. Every time a character has in their breathing tubes because they're in an environment they wouldn't survive and they end up breathing through their mouths, take a shot.

reviews.review_title: why do people hate this movie?
reviews.content: Hollywood movie critics wouldn't know a good movie if it fell on them. Battlefield Earth has everything one needs when watching a sci-fi flick, action, aliens and comedy. I think people are so hard on this movie because the writer of the novel is the founder of Scientology. I really liked this movie because it's entertaining. Which is why I watch movies, to be entertained. Barry Pepper gives a great believable depiction of an outcast made leader through necessity. John Travolta is hilarious as the security chief of planet earth for the aliens, I think it's funny how he's just not as smart as he thinks he is. lol... All in all be your own judge on this film don't let the Hollywood fakes decide for you. Thanks for taking the time to read me humble review.

There is one thing that Travolta got right and that is the darkness. This may be great for Psychlos, but for humans it makes for difficulties such as following the plot. That's OK, because the plot was disconnected anyway.I'm an admirer of Hubbard's work and found Battlefield Earth a wonderful book. When a book is adapted to the movie screen, I let the movie speak for itself instead of making expectations of my reading. In this way the movie is more enjoyable. However, the screenwriters should have gone back and read and re-read the book. Maybe they would have gotten a clue about constructing a plot.Robert the Fox is a main character in the book, but you wouldn't know it by the movie. The two met in Scotland after Jonny escaped from Terl. You'd never know it by the movie. There are a couple of major Psychlo and human players missing, which accounts for the holes in the plot.Don't waste your money seeing this loser. Go rent Attack of the Killer Tomatoes instead.

reviews.review_title: Horrible Film from a great book
reviews.content: This film was absolutely terrible. I believe that is pretty much the consensus. However, I would simply like to add that, although the film was horrendous, the book was excellent. I am not much a sci-fi type, but the book really was a great work in my opinion. Then they tried to take a 1000+ page novel and turn it into a movie? Why? How does one turn a complex 1000+ page work of art into a 130 page movie script? Well, I guess this film showed it cannot be done properly. After being a fan of the book and recommending the story (film included before I saw it) to so many people I feel like I owe the world an apology. If you are at all curious about the story and how the holes could be filled in, check out the book. I gave the movie a 2 instead of a 1 because of my devotion to the book which I feel is worthy of a 9 or 10.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst move I ever saw but....
reviews.content: This was not the worst move I ever saw but it was pretty bad. It was long, plodding, pointless and even silly at times. We are supposed to buy that people who have not seen technology in their lifetime can spend a week in a flight simulator and learn how to fly a Harrier jet?  Or that a Harrier jet sitting idle for 1000 years would actually be able to fly? BTW where did they get the electricity to power the flight simulator?.  The aliens were not even menacing.  Just tall dumb Ferengi...

Most of the reviews I've read for this film say it left a lot to be desired.(Like an intelligent script) I, on the other hand would recommend it as a mindless escape for anyone desperate for a Sci-Fi fix and a few good, though unintentional, laughs.  Also, brace yourself for an intrusive score that takes itself entirely too seriously too many times.

I read the book about 15 years ago.  It was a great and very long read, but an awesome work of science fiction.  None of Hubbard's scientology came through in the work, thank God.  Unfortunately, it seems the only reason that this movie was made was because of Hubbard's #1 disciple being a producer in the film.  How long does it take a regular Navy pilot to learn how to fly a Harrier?  I'm guessing more than a week.  Very poorly done, little resemblance to the book.

reviews.review_title: This review contains spoilers. Please, I implore you, read them instead of seeing the movie. You'll thank me.
reviews.content: "Battlefield Earth" is not so much a movie as it is a random assemblage of images, pasted together without even basic skill or talent. I have not seen such a poorly written/acted/filmed movie in a long time. Where should we begin to dismantle this film? Let's start with the alien villains, the "Psychlos". The Psychlos are, without a doubt, the most inept and blundering aliens ever. They make the aliens in "Spaced Invaders" look calm, cool and collected by comparison. They invade the Earth, conquer humanity in nine minutes, but then it takes them a thousand years to get around to looking for gold. They have built a big 'ol dome over the poorly drawn ruins of "Denver", so they must realize that things like cities and cars exist, but apparently don't realize that the enslaved "man-animals" originally made them. They have been watching humans for a millennium, but think that their favorite food is rat. They have a perfectly good prison, complete with cells and everything, where they wash off the humans, but then they actually store them in an abandoned and easily escapable Zoo. And, wait a minute, why did they bother to wash the humans in the first place? They just get dirty again instantly.The lead  Psychlo is Terl, a mid-level bureaucrat played, tragically, by John Travolta. Terl is the head of Earth Security, and has been hoping for a transfer to someplace with better set design. Unfortunately, as he is dumber than a sack of man-animal feed, he is doomed by an executive from the "Home Office" (in Sioux City, Iowa, presumably) to stay on Earth indefinitely. This makes Terl mad, and his two volt brain comes up with a cunning scheme. He will mine a bunch of gold and bribe his way back home! Terl decides to use man-animals to mine his gold, and he chooses feisty and grungy Johnny Goodboy to lead the work detail. Terl zaps Johnny with a few volts from his learning machine, and teaches him Psychlo language and other things that are equally stupid teach to slaves, especially slaves that have already outsmarted you six or seven times, as Johnny has. But, as I have noted, Terl is not the swiftest Psychlo around. Actually, as it is mentioned several times that Terl graduated at the top of his class at the Academy, maybe he *is* the swiftest Psychlo around, and that makes me wonder further how the Psychlos even managed to invent the rubber band, not to mention conquering planets and teleportation. Maybe they bought their technology second hand from the Klingons, along with their makeup.OK, so where were we? Oh, yes. Gold. Terl sends Johnny and his comrades into the Rockies to mine for gold. But Johnny has a better plan. You see, in a brilliant scheme to convince Johnny that resistance is futile, Terl has taken him to the ruins of the "Denver" public library, and lets him look at the dusty books, thus instilling in him the realization that the Psychlos are the superior species. But Johnny instead reads the Declaration of Independence and other patriotic documents, and his rebellious resolve is solidified. Of course, as the humans of the future don't seem to have a written language, and the Psychlos don't know English either, so they couldn't have taught it to him, you have to wonder how, exactly, Johnny understood the books he read. Oh, well. Maybe he was inspired by the nice penmanship. At the Library Johnny finds out about Fort Knox, so he and the other miners fly there and take that gold and give it to Terl instead and.and.Ahhhhhh!I'm sorry. At this point the movie completely collapses into a babbling nonsensical cesspool. Ok, it collapses further. I can't even bring myself to describe the details of the finale. With good reason: It is so poorly edited and shot that it makes no sense whatsoever. I think the humans won, but I may be wrong. The Psychlos home planet gets blowed up real good, but Terl survives. The end.That's the plot. But the plot is only one of the movies problems. Second is the acting, which is uniformly dreadful. Trying to compare the John Travolta in "Pulp Fiction" to Terl is impossible. Travolta plays the extraterrestrial imbecile like a whiny, petulant eight year old. He is, I guess, supposed to menacing, but he ends up just being annoying. The humans are all dull, and Forrest Whittaker, as Terl's clerk/dogs body Ker is completely wasted. The acting is not helped by the direction. Roger Christian, the auteur who gave us "Masterminds", has no idea about how to frame shots, or transition between scenes. There about 1500 wipes in "Battlefield Earth", which makes it look like an old "Commando Cody" short, only less skillfully executed. Christian has also observed that sometimes, in good movies, the camera is tilted. So he tries to imitate this by randomly tilting the camera, regardless of the action of the scene. The whole film looks as though it was filmed in the Jokers Lair. To top off the hideous direction and lifeless acting, the movie also appears to have been edited by untrained tube worms.In conclusion, avoid "Battlefield Earth" at all costs. Do not think that it is a so-bad-its-good kind of movie. It's not. Its so bad its unwatchable. If you want one of the former genre, rent any Ed Wood film, all of which are more enjoyable. On a scale of 1 to 10, this piece of cinematic sputum gets a.5.PS. "Battlefield Earth" contains what is meant by the filmmakers to be an homage to "2001", by having two of the characters be named "Floyd" and "Heywood". Under these circumstances, it is  much more of an insult than compliment. If they liked "2001" so much, maybe they should have paid more attention to how it was made. It might have helped.But I doubt it.

reviews.review_title: L Ron Hubbard meets Hollywood.Big Screenplay
reviews.content: I'm sure it was an entertaining read as a book. And follower, John Travolta, fell obligated to see his master memorialized on the "big screen ". I have not even read any of the reviews for this movie on this website. But I will bet my next 10 paychecks, and yours, that there are parallel observations.Ok. Nothing fit. The acting and directing... Left a lot to be desired. A lot of assumptions were made that the viewers would already know or had a knowledge foundation to draw from when understanding details. The music score, it really didn't fit some of the scenes. Details were murky. And in a post apocalyptic movie... Does everyone need to be wearing canvas colored clothing and sport long disheveled hairdos?The plot was simplistic. Honestly this seemed like Cliff Notes to other movies were the captive becomes the savior. This movie was at best a mix between Mad Max meets The Postman.As a researcher, I drew more from learning about the author of the book that this movie was based on. Now... That is a real story!

reviews.review_title: On my list of worst movies ever made
reviews.content: Anyone who supported this movie being made should be, in the words of Boss Nass in Episode I, "poonished". I think Barry Pepper is a great actor, I loved him in Saving Private Ryan and The Green Mile, but geez WHAT THE HELL WERE YOU THINKING?????????????? The majority of the characters and plot from the book were taken out and this "waste of time" was only about......actually I don't know what the point of this was. Did anyone notice that Jonnie and Chrissy were not addressed by name until an hour into the thing????????? And where was Pattie? And Robert The Fox? And that Psychlo that Terl had killed cause of his paranoia? I could go on for hours about what was left out.........In the near future, let's hope that they make a miniseries with all the important parts and characters included........No wonder Gladiator has made more money than this bad adaptation of a novel.......

It would be far too easy to say that I simply did not like the film.  While my friend assures me that the movie *is*, in fact, better than the book, by feelings can be summed up as follows:Battlefield Earth is an epic cinematic endeavour composed entirely of errors the tactful avoidance of which has contributed to every other excellent movie's success.

I agree with the previous reviews that Battlefiled Earth: A Saga of the Year 3000 is arguably the worst movie ever made, I ask readers to wait before passing judgment on the plot/book. The book is over 1000 pages long, with a very extensive plot line. When compressed into a movie of this length, there is obviously some serious cuts made from the plot. I ask only that for those of you who have watched the movie, give the book a chance. For those of you lucky enough not to have watched the movie....don't. Just go ahead and read the book. I read the book first and loved it. When I saw there was a movie out, I was ecstatic. Upon watching the movie, I wished that someone had beaten the idea out of me. Regardless, despite the ....suckiness? of the movie, the book it was originated from was excellent. Movie : 1 out of 10, Book : 9 out of 10

Everyone who says this movie is bad must have an IQ of 80 because it is a fantastic solid sci fi epic. It has all of the logical and decent parts that make up a great Sci-fi film. Excellent costume design, beautiful cinematography, very realistic CGI, compelling story, along with solid acting performances. The over the top elements were not laughable as so many people have said before me. Sci-fi is over the top inherently there is no denying it.Honestly the only reason I can think of as to why people disliked this movie was the lack of profanity, topless woman, and transforming catch phrase slinging robots.This movie was so reminiscent of Star Gate, Star Trek and Star Wars it was beautifully crafted and deserves so much more then people on IMDb give it credit for. I give it an 8 out of 10. It's not incredible, but rather a solid film with a great story and lots of eye candy.

reviews.review_title: I'll see this classic again and again!
reviews.content: It's amazing how many people really seem to hate this movie - it's too bad that religious bigotry can affect one's movie choices and reviews, isn't it? Although really, critics are just like psychologists - they really don't have a clue as to what they're talking about, and can only tear down what others are trying to build up.  So it's not too surprising that the reviews for this movie are so uniformly awful, right?In any case, this movie was awesome!  I've been a fan of Travolta ever since my friends told me about all his movies and how I should see all of them, even the older ones he did between Saturday Night Fever and Pulp Fiction! Has anyone here ever seen Look Who's Talking?  That's a great comedy with both Travolta and my favorite actress, KIRSTIE ALLEY!  Mmmmm.... Kirstie.... And wow, did Travolta crack me up as the evil alien Terl!  He was just so amazingly evil with his forbidding costume and breathing apparatus, he just seemed incredibly alien.But anyways, like I was saying, the movie was AWESOME!  None of that blood-and-guts and sex stuff we see today in Sci-Fi movies like Independence Day and The Matrix, this movie has instead a stirring theme of duty, honor, and sacrifice, not to mention the best special effects since the original Star Wars!So go out and see it today!  It's the feel-good Sci-Fi flick of the summer, and it deserves to be seen multiple times, with as many of your friends as possible, in order to experience the wise themes of Battlefield Earth again and again.  The book was also excellent, easily the second greatest book I've ever read.  I have several copies that I own myself and pass out to friends every chance I get.  They don't always return them, but I figure hey, that means they've passed them on to other friends, right?But anyway, go out and see Battlefield Earth, and hope along with me that it'll go international, and spread its wisdom across the globe!Especially to Germany, which really needs it.

I went to this film expecting it to stink. I have masochistic tendencies and I hoped this movie would punish me enough to make me right with the world for a while. On that level it succeeded. On every other level it failed horribly. This movie somehow managed to be terrible and cheesy, yet robbed it's tortured audience of even the small joy of laughing at it. It was just too boring! Walking out of the theater I had the same feeling I had after completing eight hours of traffic school. My guess is that anyone on any planet in any galaxy who claims to have enjoyed this film is either under the sway of scientology or has a grapefruit size tumor damaging their thought process.Booo

John Travolta with shoelaces through his nose???? I mean, Come on! It's not surprising to know that John spend 10 years to sell this idea. Battle for Endor is a masterpiece comparing to this piece of nothing!

reviews.review_title: Not horrible, bad with a lot of plot holes, but not the worst movie ever made
reviews.content: I didn't think it was the worst movie ever made. First and foremost there was a lot of unintentional comedy. True, the fact that all of the jets and the declaration of independence and even cities survived over 1000 years is kind of hard to believe but who cares? It was entertaining. It had the basic action movie script, good guy versus evil guy, helpless situation, good guy somehow manages to defeat all-powerful bad guy. Granted the plot was kind of hard to follow and some of the dialogue was choppy and didn't make a lot of sense and the aliens were kind of goofy looking and didn't have very good hygiene but I can't say that I was bored and just counting the minutes until the end. I was rooting for Barry Pepper and the humans to beat up those aliens. As someone who doesn't go to a movie looking to analyze and dissect the movie into smithereens but rather just goes for sheer entertainment value alone I can honestly say that I've seen worse films ("The Boxer" comes to mind, what a horribly boring film.)

With out of this world special effects shot with such dark filters that you can hardly see them "Battlefield Earth" is so disappointing that I found myself hunched in my seat with memories of summer debacles past, ie "Godzilla", rushing through my head.  Travolta is way over the top, Pepper grits his teeth as a show of emotion, and Christensen should be banned from using slow motion shots ever again.  As a fan of the book, after seeing the film, I can honestly say that it should not have been filmed.

reviews.review_title: The Greek The Ruler of the universe??
reviews.content: I just want to ask Why did they do such a bad movie .. ??  Maybe the temptation of doing one bad budget movie was too great but anyway ..Have you notice that after the "HERO" have learn about the Cyclops and all the science he refers to the euclidean mathematics??    my  question is the fallowing How in the world the cyclops knew about him?    Also, is this movie trying to say that we actually live in euclidean space??  I found that quite interessting since even euclid had doubt about this fact that the triangle truly measure 180 degrees  ...

reviews.review_title: not just bad -- so memorably bad it gives banality a bad name
reviews.content: First, let me say: You NEED to see this movie. It establishes a new benchmark for the millennium. Will we ever see another sci-fi movie this putrid? I can't imagine it. Battlefield Earth certainly sets a milestone that will be hard to beat as the cheesiest big-budget sci-fi film ever made. Based on one of L. Ron Hubbard's countless pulp-sci-fi novels, this is in essence Independence Day all over again, but after the aliens have destroyed Earth and established a colony to mine it. Characters, dialogue, action and acting all reminded me of nothing so much as a Saturday-morning, Transformers-type cartoon specifically targeting 5-year-old boys. Directed by Roger Christian (who's made a career of shlocky losers) Battlefield Urrrp manages to give banality a bad name. The protagonist is named Jonnie Goodboy Tyler. No: I'm not making that name up. He lives with his honey as part of a very small tribe of renegades in the year 3,000. Being very brave, he wanders fearlessly close to `the gods' and is of course captured by the aliens. Ah, the aliens. That would be Terl (John Travolta) and Ker (Forest Whittaker). To make them appear very tall, they're obviously walking on huge platform boots. This is obvious because their walk is, literally, stilted and laughably awkward. In fact, I found myself constantly expecting them to start saying `Ni!' since they seemed very much like Monty Python's Knights Who Say Ni! In one of many paradoxes in the film, here are aliens from a race so advanced they were able to wipe out the entire planet in exactly 9 (not 8 or 10, mind you but 9) minutes, way back in the 21st Century, yet they obviously know nothing of personal hygiene and all of them are in desperate need of basic dental work. Even the names would do Saturday-morning cartoons justice. The aliens are Psychlos from the planet Psychlo! I am not making this up, either. And these highly intelligent beings call humans `man-animals.' Of course, when they catch man-animal Jonnie Goodboy Tyler, they come to find they've met their match. Had Ed Wood received the astounding $80 million budget of Battlefield Earth to spend on Plan Nine from Outer Space, this is probably what he'd have done with it. If nothing else, with that budget, the effects should have been awesome. Or even good. But they were just plain cheesy - laughable and low-budget in appearance. One of the funniest moments occurs when the very bad Travolta drops a man-animal down an abyssal chasm to see if it can fly. The way the hapless fellow falls, lying on his back, looking up and waving his arms - allllll the way down - made me feel I was watching a 1950s-vintage flick. Rip-offs of other films abound, but it's as if someone decided to rip off all the worst aspects of sci-fi films from recent years. Jonnie figures out how to beat the seemingly invincible aliens and part of his scheme requires his band of wild, uneducated man-animal workers to learn how to fly the United States' most sophisticated jets from 2000 (they know just where to find lots of them, of course). Sure enough, Jonnie leads them to an old training module; each one sets a spell in it and comes out an incredible ace fighter pilot, despite having never even seen a jet before. Never mind that after 1,000 years these birds might not start right up (even if the jet fuel were any good). Never mind that these same planes and even much more powerful weapons, during the invasion 1,000 years ago, had absolutely no effect on the invaders' technology. Now, suddenly, these jets are deadly - knocking the transplanetary craft unerringly out of the sky. Hell, the wild, loin-clothed man-animals must have learned jargon in the training module, too, so they suddenly spout marvelously incongruous lines like, `Hang on! I'm right on his tail!' The acting was as laughable as the plot. Travolta's forced `evil laugh' matched the special effects for cheesiness. And, certainly, Forest Whittaker has never been so ridiculous. Both actors spend the film varying between malevolent smiles and evil sneers; that's the range of their performances. Of course, if their heart wasn't in it, who could blame them with dialogue that would have made the Power Rangers sound childish. `Man-animals operating machinery?' asks alien Whittaker to Travolta, aliens technologically light-years ahead of Earth, from a race which freely traverses galaxies, `Have you blown a head gasket?' But if the aliens are petty villains, the wild humans surviving in `the hills,' are profound. Such as man-animal Jonnie Goodboy's woman-animal who says to him, `Jonnie, I've always known you don't believe in fate, but I've always known this will be our destiny.' (And she does it with a straight face!) As if all this weren't bad enough, the cinematographer apparently wanted to do his part in making the film worse - by inexplicably shooting scenes throughout the film with the camera tilted - at up to 45 degrees.  I kept waiting for the actors to start sliding right out of the frame! And apparently the editor's idea of action means `fast cuts.' The cuts were so fast, in fact, that during what could have been at least marginally interesting fight scenes, all we got were muddled flashes back and forth so quickly that we knew fighting was going on but couldn't follow any of it - until it was over, at which point we had no idea how the winner prevailed. Before the film came out, some controversy erupted over the fact that this movie was nothing more than an insidious ploy to spread Hubbard's (and Travolta's) religion of Scientology. You could find a deeper, more evident message in any episode of Pee Wee's Playhouse than you'd find in Battlefield Earth. If there was any message intended (which I can't imagine), it was completely lost in this puerile, brainless turd of a movie. 0* (and that's being too generous)  (May, 2000)

reviews.review_title: The book was ok, the movie should be trashed
reviews.content: Being a hard core scifi fan I just had to see the movie. I read the book shortly after it was published and thought it was ok, so when the movie came out with John Travolta I decided that the bad reviews must be wrong and I went to see it. Big mistake After about 45 minutes I came to the conclusion that only a massocist could set through the hole thing. As for me I went home and watched re-runs of Gilligans Island.The nicest thing I can say bout it is that it is the worst movie I have ever seen. I only hope that John Travolta is able to recover from this and continue an otherwise fine career.

'Battlefield Earth' is an excellent movie full of dramatic excitement.  It is full of suspense, and the action never stops.  The villain is played with truth, as are the intelligent men working for good.  It is a true symbol of human intelligence and how men working together for good can succeed, however impossible their plan.  It is truly enjoyable, and many people who have seen it truly enjoy it.  My advice is to watch the movie before the book, because the movie is based on a 500 page section of the book (the first half), which is fairly hard to squeeze into the short amount of time the movie lasts.  The book is also excellent, written by an author who knows how to write what people will enjoy forever.  It is a timeless classic already, enjoyed by adults and children alike, as the movie is.  Everyone who enjoys sci-fi or even just action, adventure, drama, or romance should go to see it.

reviews.review_title: Since when is 1 the lowest number you could come up with, IMDb?
reviews.content: "Battlefield Earth" has all the elements to a good sci-fi epic. Several, in fact. I think they should sue.Let's set "Braveheart" in a sci-fi setting, I can see them saying. Yes, but that was called "Independence Day." Ok, so include some of the more savage elements of "Braveheart" and use the sets for "Blade Runner." This also cuts from the lighting budget, which we can use to pay for John Travolta's makeup. Oh, and to save money on the costuming budget, let's use stuff we can five-finger discount from Goodwill and the Salvation Army.Of course none of that happened because the book is older than that, which is what makes it really uncanny. The plot could not have been canibalized from those sources. The fact that they feel so stolen from is a tribute to Roger Christian's inability to show any talent that cannot be found in a Blockbuster.Action sequences from "The Matrix." A camera wipe from "Episode I" (they could only afford one). Special Effects robbed from "Bablyon V," and then darkened with the Curves tool in Photoshop. A soundtrack that was pieced together from "Earth 2" and "SeaQuest DSV" at the local used CD shop.Oh, and then the leg on the camera tripod broke, and they couldn't afford a new one. And the editing was done by the director's 12-year-old son in Adobe Premier.Ok, the film had one thing that in my desperation I clung to as a saving grace: John Travolta. I mean, he just LOOKS funny. When he starts talking, it's just hilarious. Somebody call Tarentino and tell him that Johnny needs a third career after he flushed his second down the drain.Now, for the final question... is the film a Scientology tract? Hmm. Scientology means "knowing about knowing," but all I learned about was the pain inflicted by an overcaffeinated editing job. I didn't see any deleting of engrams, and definately nobody that was "Clear." Not a smidgen of an idea of thetans. There were some references to Freedom, but those were more like Mel Gibson imitations than liberating oneself from "Matter, Energy, Space, and Time." So all I got out of that was a bunch of people on IMDb wondering why I know this much about Scientology and thinking I should be committed. [Eh, I got it all from ask.com].Definately see this film. In the day. When nobody else is. And heckle.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie! If I didn't get in free I wouldn't have went!
reviews.content: Effects were good, acting was horrible, the story was worse than the acting! Travolta hasn't done anything really worth while since Pulp Fiction. Don't waste your time on this movie. If you have a hard time sleeping at night, perhaps you might want to watch this flick.

Loosely based on the Hubbard book this movie tells the story of the remnants of humanity attempting to reclaim the Earth from alien invaders who defeated the combined military might of the entire late 20th century Earth in 9 minutes.These remnants (by all appearance a couple of hundred of them), with no more concept of technology than to call an airplane a flying spear, learn to fly fighter jets, detonate nuclear weapons and organize a revolt in one week.One would hope that the worst part of this movie was the impossible plot line but, unfortunately, this is not the case. I suspect we won't be seeing any best actor Oscars for this one.On the plus side, I didn't have to pay to see this movie but if you have to dig into your pocket for this one, just don't do it.

Battlefield Earth is one of the best S F movies I've seen in years. I grew up with Star Trek, and Star Wars, and I love this type of epic battle. It had just the right amount of Action and humor for my tastes. I can't wait for the sequel to see how all of this turns out. Maybe I'll cheat and go out and buy the book.

reviews.review_title: Best Science Fiction movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: John Travolta and the rest of actors did an excellent job in this movie. This is an instant classic and the best movie I have ever seen.  The story is captivating and incredibly suspenseful.It is an emotional roller coaster and I highly recommend it.  I liked it better than all the Star War movies and can't wait for the sequel.

reviews.review_title: I liked it in a kid of Star Trek kind of way
reviews.content: I enjoyed this movie.  It won't win any academy awards but not many Science fiction movies do.  If you see it without any preconceived ideas about it I think you will find it enjoyable.  It is pg13 so if you want sex and a lot of violence you won't find it in this movie.

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst I've Ever Seen...
reviews.content: Simply put, this movie was awful.  The plot was force-fed at a frantic pace with no room for any meaningful dialog.  The action scenes weren't really that interesting.  The MTV-esque cinematography made me want to hork.  This was easily one of the worst films I have ever seen.

Not since Batman And Robin has there been a movie that I laughed at so much. This movie starts off sounding kind of interesting, but the more you learn, the less you care. The characters are 2 dimensional at best, the story is decent, the leaps of "suspension of disbelief" that are required to like this movie are just too great. Many times in this movie I said to myself, "Don't think about it, just go with it" but even then I found myself laughing at some of the situations.I went into this movie not expecting much, and was then extremely disappointed. If there was one saving grace to this movie, it was that the special effects were pretty good.This is one of those movies where you just hope everyone dies.... not just the "bad" guys (who are more interesting than the humans!) but everybody....

the movie was good except for the fact that you were dropped into the action too fast it could have done with a bit more of an intro but i was otherwise good.  the camera angles at first made the movie a bit confusing but it got better.  the acting was good except a bit hokey with people continually commiting suicide for the plot

Whilst on Holiday in Toronto, I had the misfortune to go and see Battlefield Earth.I usually love all things sci-fi, a bit sad but we can't all be perfect, so I decided to spend some of my quality vacation time seeing this movie, so that I could boast to my friends back in England at having seen the movie 3-4 months before they could, now all I can do is spend 3-4 months warning everybody I know to never, under any circumstance see this movie.The story was slow, and cumbersome, the plot was laughable, the acting was totally unbelievable, in fact the only thing to recommend this film was the two blackouts caused by the theatre being struck by lightning!If this is the stuff a cult is based on, it must be a pretty sad cult.

I'm normally not a sci-fi fan but I got sucked in by all the controversy -- so many people saying it's terrible, so many others saying it's great. Finally had to see it for myself. Actually, didn't find it terrible or great,  but for a sci-fi flick, I thought it was pretty entertaining and I'm definitely glad I saw it. I was actually so engrossed the whole time, I couldn't believe almost 2 hours had elapsed by the end. Most fun I've had at a show in a while. At the theater where I saw it the place was packed and everyone seemed to be enjoying it. As I said, I didn't think it was great, in the sense of carving a niche in the history of film or anything like that, but it was certainly entertaining, much more so than most of what passes for entertainment these days.

It was really cool. The special effects were incredible. The sound effects were spectacular, and the movie didn't diverge too much from the book. I thought they did a good job of condensing the story, keeping the most important parts. I do wish they had made it a little longer. I can't wait for the DVD uncut version, and for the sequel, since the book carried on afterward (c:

reviews.review_title: This is the reason "Epic" novels should be made into Mini-Series
reviews.content: I always thought Battlefield Earth was a great book, "Epic", I've read it several times. I was hoping that if they ever made a movie out of it a lot of care would be taken to preserve the story. (I can dream can't I?) The Stand and The Lord of the Rings threesome fall into the "epic" category also. It looks like a lot of care and thought went into bringing The Stand to life in a mini series, and I hope since they are doing LOTR in 3 movies they will do a decent job. There's just too much in books like these to condense them into a few hours. And if you see Battlefield Earth you'll know what I'm talking about. So much is missed and you get what we have with "Battlefield Earth: The Movie That Sorta Promises a Sequel". At least thats the impression I got from the ending. They tried to cram so much into 2 hrs that enjoyment of the story was lost in a race to get to the climax. The Psychlo's were portrayed well. Travolta makes a good Psyclo. Whats his face that played Johnny Goodboy Tyler looked like if he concentrated hard enough everything would be all right. But he tried too hard to be Mel Gibson in Braveheart, right down to the braid in his hair. Probably wasn't his fault, but its hard not to draw comparisons. Overall this would have been better if they broke it up over 4 nights on network tv and made even a half-a**'d attempt to stick to the story line.Bottom line... don't expect a whole lot. Just go back and read the book to try to blot everything you saw out.

reviews.review_title: BE had my son on the edge of his seat, like only Toy Story!
reviews.content: Wow!  Do you know what it takes to keep an almost seven-year-old on the edge of his seat through an entire movie?  Well, only Toy Story has ever done it before!  And his first word of commentary? "Awesome!"  This moving comic book was just great!  I give it 4 to 5 stars.  We'll see it several more times, then be ready for the sequel.

I had a good time, and so did my family.  I read the book long ago--liked it better than the movie, but it sure beats seeing four lovely girls kill themselves over nothing.  Isn't it time for some HOPE than man can do something about even the worst situation?

This movie is simply terrible.  The plot is tenuous and unfollowable and the writing is actually funny (but only when not intended).  John Travolta looks like some sort of half made-up Klingon and his little schemes just get redundant (and his overacting gets painful).  I was unable to keep track of most of the minor characters largely because they seldom said anything more than catchphrases; the sci-fi cliches abounded. The film also had a terrible habit of using slow motion in extremely unnecessary circumstances (made more painful by the fact that I just wanted to movie to be over).  Finally, the hilariously named Psychlos had to be the most incompetent aliens since Alf, with their inability to do anything right whenever a human tried anything against them (especially when they got a gun). This film is so derivative and just terrible, that it is almost not worth writing about.  However, I just hope that I can spare other people the waste of seeing this movie.  Simply put, it added nothing to the much "overused us vs. them in a post-apocalyptic world" genre of sci-fi and it simply should not have been made.

reviews.review_title: Great! Really enjoyed it, took my kid the second time.
reviews.content: This is a great film! And possibly the entrance point for a new genre of science fiction films. The humor is terrific...interesting what the interpretation and viewpoint from the year 3000 might be. And while there is plenty of action, it manages to be non-gory...a first for present day films. My son and all his friends loved it as well.

reviews.review_title: One of those movies you wish to see again and again!
reviews.content: The movie Battlefield Earth had some of the most amazing special effects I've seen, certainly on the level of Aliens, Star Wars, etc.  John Travolta in his role as Terl, continues to prove he is one of the great talents of our day .. his character and the plot's friction between the Psychlos and "Man Animals" very believable.  The cleverness and resourcefulness of Johnie is a salute to mankind and his ability to survive! I love uplifting epics like this one and hope we will see a sequel in the future.  I hope to see more of these characters!

reviews.review_title: Excellent Sci-Fi Film; Travolta awesome as Terl
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth portrays a futuristic view that no other sci-fi film has addressed; the fact that it involves our own planet makes it unique and memorable. The special effects are spectacular and Travolta is true evil as the Psychlo "Terl". This film is better than the last Star Wars and ranks up there with Armageddon. A must see and a must read on the book. I'm looking for a sequel, and seeing this first film more than a couple of times.

reviews.review_title: Seen it twice and will go again
reviews.content: The book is absolutely awesome and definitely one of my most favorite SF stories EVER. (I've been reading SF since 1962).  The movie is doing a very good job telling about 1/2 of the book's story with great special effects and some real bad ass aliens. Travolta plays the Psychlo security chief Terl and I just hated his guts. The concept of NEVER giving up, no matter what the odds, was very uplifting. There is a lot of action in the movie and I got more out of it the second time. And I will go and see it a third time. I like this movie!

I was very impressed with the speed of action that took place in this film. I have to admit that I had to see it twice, which in itself is a testament to how I enjoyed it as it's not every film I want to see again. John Travolta played a great villain and Berry Perry played an excellent hero figure. It's a must see movie.

reviews.review_title: If you liked American Beauty, see this movie
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is an acceptably fun action movie. It accomplishes its purpose. There is lots of dumb stuff in it, of course, but that's part of its goofy charm as a B-movie.If you are a sophisticated film aficionado, the kind of person who is really impressed by movies like American Beauty, then you simply must go see this movie. Why on earth would I say something like this? Because, based on some reviews of Battlefield Earth I've read, the movie can in some cases give this type of person a massive, gratifying rush of self-righteous venomous spite, unlike any movie in recent memory. Go figure.I recommend it! I give it a 6 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Wall to wall special effects - dont mess with the Earthmen
reviews.content: BE is a film to see.   It's a movie about the triumph of the human race and its recovery of freedom.  With extremely well done art to convey the message. Better than watching gladiators hack each other to pieces.  When was the last time you saw a movie review put on a front page?  And in papers tied to a chain who rated Hitler as "Man of the Year".  Obviously an orchestrated and paid for effort to pan a great flick.  Stupid comments from critics whose opinion is for sale or so out of touch with creativity they doubtlessly flunked finger painting and went down from there can't hide the truth.  And of course the frothing  mad dog ravings of the anti Scientology garbage who would be better off dead (better for them, better for the rest of the world) mean nothing.  Anyone who doesn't like a movie where the human race triumphs and wins its freedom, well, it tells you where THEY are at. Definitely worth viewing.

I got fully caught up in the fast moving story. Loved John Travolta as the bad guy, Terl. Maybe what the critics miss in this movie is that the Producers & Directors seemed to think that other effects were more important than blood and guts of most action movies today. We didn't have to watch the cattle being slaughtered or watch a decapitation in slow motion, with each blood spurt followed to its final destination.I did overhear comments from other viewers as I left the theater that made me wish I had read the book first. I will read the book, now.

reviews.review_title: John Travolta/Forest Whitaker were Hilarious as Evil Aliens
reviews.content: I very much enjoyed Travolta and Whitaker as the lead aliens.  Their performance and the scenes of the aliens made the movie worthwhile.  They were more interesting (and believable) than the humans.While this movie is worth seeing, it does not do justice to the book.  The book has much more character and plot development.  And the plot hangs together very well.  The screen play took a lot of license and left out and added many elements.The movie's graphics were very good.  It reminds me of Blade Runner with its rough look.

This movie was really fun to watch. Really amazing FX. Travolta and Whitaker were great. The make-up and design was really different and very cool. I loved the Clinko/Learning machine part, the FX in that section were stunning. This film keeps you very entertained throughout.

reviews.review_title: Travolta is worth the price of admission
reviews.content: Travolta has played some villans--some excellently as in Face Off, some not as well as in Broken Arrow. In Battlefield Earth he is at the top of his game as the Psychlo head of intelligence Teryl. He delights in his perversity just as Max Von Sydow did as Emperor Ming in the underrated Flash. Travoltas byplay with Forrest Whittaker is marvelous.If there is a shortcoming to the movie it lies in the difficult task of distilling a 1000 page novel into two hours running time. Dune met a similar fate but it remains one of my favorite sci-fi movies and favorite books of the genre.I recommend the movie--especially for Travolta's performance and those of Whittaker and Barry Pepper as the hero of the story. I'd say see the movie and then read the book and you'll get the full experience.

reviews.review_title: This was a terrifically casted film -- I loved the characters!!
reviews.content: I loved the casting for the film -- John Travolta was perfect as Terl, Forrest Whitaker was fabulous as Kerr, and Barry Pepper was without comparison as Johnnie Goodboy Tyler.  The artistic creation of the Psychlos was incredible and exactly as I imagined from the book.  Soundtrack for the movie was awesome!  I've seen it twice already, can't wait to see it again!

reviews.review_title: A Good but very different sci-fi flick
reviews.content: I enjoyed this movies for several reasons but two stand out more than others: the performances and the theme.I think that Pepper, Travolta and Whitaker were more than excellent.  There were several places where they could have screwed this film up (and I thought that they might) but they not only didn't, they made it work well. Because of the compressed, rushed pace of the film, it would have been easy to let some of the scenes be done in a superficial manner; however, they turned these into scenes that made the characters more understandable. Some character development was done with glances from the actors and that is not an easy task.The theme of the movie is truly noble and might escape some people because it also is not superficial.  It is about a quality that does not exist around us in high quantity and is almost not taught any more.I recommend it and think that parents should encourage their kids to go as well.

reviews.review_title: Great content, great story, lots of action and intrigue
reviews.content: What I liked most is the heroic epic content where someone was able to rise above those who gained control over the planet to win it back. There are parallels happening today that makes the story that much more real. The action was fast moving.  I was unable to take a mental break because of the speed of the scenes.  One blink and you could miss an important point. I have seen few films that I every would consider seeing again.  Matrix is one and Battlefield earth is the other!!

reviews.review_title: Battlefield Earth is full of action and has a very profound theory of Earth's future!
reviews.content: The movie had a lot of fast action. The movie was over before I knew it. I hope there is a sequel to this movie. John Travolta definitely earned his money on this one. It was a very realistic view of what could happen to earth in the future.

I liked the movie.  I was disappointed at first that more of the story was not shown.  Then I realized what a huge book it is.  I went and saw it again and the 2nd time I forgot about what I knew about the book and just watched it as if I'd never read it.It changed the whole story for me.  I liked the innovation of the way the scenes changed and it surprised me that 2 hours went so fast.  I loved Barry Pepper.  I had not thought he'd made a good Johnnie.  I also like John t.  he got better in the part as it moved along.  I think this movie will do better than expected

With all the negative hype that looked pretty cooked up, I could'nt wait to see this movie.  I wish it could have followed the book better but then it might be 10 movies.  I saw it twice to settle into the changes and my wife and I liked it much better the second time.  Bad guys were way evil and could talk.  That was a novel change for sci-fi.  I have to admit, I didn't get any subliminal messages for my money though.  Of course, how would I know?  Ha!  I for one am looking forward to the upcoming finale.

reviews.review_title: Battlefield Earth is already a classic!!
reviews.content: I am one of the many people who read the book, Battlefield Earth, when it first came out in 1982, and have been waiting for the movie for 18 years. In fact, I read the book five times. I've already seen the movie twice--I had to.  The first time, I spent the first hour comparing it to the book. Major waste of time.  It was inevitable, but still a waste.  The movie is BASED on the book, it is not an exact telling of the story.  And although they differ, I am in no way disappointed.  The movie is fantastic in it's characterizations, in the story it tells and in the special effects.  The movie captured the very essence of the book, and made it come to life for today's audiences.  And knowing the book as well as I do, I am impressed at how well that was done.  I had personally thought it wasn't possible.  And I can't wait for the sequel.

reviews.review_title: Great story, Great Special effects fun and exciting!
reviews.content: See Battlefield if for no other reason that the sequel will be out next year!  This story is a great one about taking back a planet after 1,000 years of alien domination. You want this back story data.  The book is a fantastic read as well. Only those with religious bigotry in their veins have decided to trash this movie. They just can't seem to seperate Scientology from Hubbard's other numerous activities which besides developing a great religion included writing, cine and music.So forget the weirdos on the fringe and see Battlefield Earth a fun fast paced movie!

A very fast paced movie. Excellent sets depicting planet earth in the year 3000.  The costumes and make-up of the aliens in this film added to the overall feeling of decadence and betrayal portrayed by these aliens (called Psychlos).The special effects were completely captivating.A fascinating plot twist was to have the culminating confrontation between the earthlings and the Psychlos moved forward by a character flaw inherent in the main psycho character.Travolta embodied evilness in his Psychlo character to the point you almost don't recognize him. A very insidious type of evil.  He's the villain you love to hate.My favorite character was Forest Whitaker who plays Travolta's sidekick. You could just feel the effort of the underling trying to get the upper hand on his boss who always seems to have the upper hand.Kelly Preston made a short surprise appearance - and a very delicious appearance it was, too.I definitely rate this movie as MUST SEE.

reviews.review_title: Takes Sci-fi into a new era..
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is an incredible movie. It contains everything a good movie needs - action, heroes, villains, drama etc. and it's got a very good story-line also and the story seems very pertinent to these times, the year 2000, even though the movie is supposed to take place in the year 3000..There are forces in the world today, trying to "colonize" the Earth for own profit - at the expense of anything, or anybody..So in that sense this film gave me another dimension which was very powerful. Go see it. It is great!

I just saw the movie Battlefield Earth and was astounded by the spectacular action and special effects! John Travolta was outstanding in his role as Terl, and Barry Pepper rocks as Johnny.I also think it's wonderful that Mr. Travolta had the moxy to bring to light the work of Mr. Hubbard on the silver screen. For years now all people have done is attach the word "Scientology" to L. Ron Hubbard - quite unfairly forgetting that he was one of the greatest and most prolific sci-fi writers of all time. Right up there with Asimov. Yes, he was most certainly a founder of a religion, but with the release of this movie, I think it is plain for all to see that Mr. Hubbard was a gem of a sci-fi/action writer.
And as for the critics out there: What exactly IS a critic? It is a person who cannot produce and so they find ways (little or small) to tear apart the work of others who are working to create something. Keep your harsh opinions to yourself! It took alot of time and effort to make this incredible film and some of the special effects rival ANYTHING out there including Star Wars, Independence Day, or some of the most well-known action flicks like Die Hard.This movie was wonderful. Outstanding entertainment! Time to try out the book!

I went into this movie expecting it to be a number one, blockbuster "hit" and was very disappointed. I did not read the book and I don't believe a viewer must in order to get the plot if the creators do their job. That a plot isn't the same as a book does not bother me either. But I found the plot incoherent and hard to follow. I found the characters very undeveloped and these two things are needed to create an emotional impact in any film. Special effects cannot carry  a movie alone in lieu of a good dramatic and clear message. And to be a "hit" as it was promoted these things must be done from an audience viewpoint not what Travolta, Christian or the Scientology public thinks is a good movie. And herein rests the problem with this flick.As a special effects art director and set decorator Roger Christian is not a film director with any experience. He was a second unit director. Nor is he known for developing  characters although I also found his film to be too darkly filmed. Even the screenwriter was a beginner. You don't hire people at this level for a brilliant epic that is difficult to recreate on film. It was also Travolta's  first attempt at producing. I have to give them credit for the attempt but I think the three of them bit off more than they could chew and it shows.As far as those writing in saying that all the good reviews are by Scientologists I feel that there is prejudice and bias at both ends of the spectrum which is  obvious. On one end there are those who hated it before it began because it was written by Hubbard and produced by Travolta. Even if it were good these people would be writing the same thing. They  are just more delighted that it also wasn't a "hit". These people have an agenda and are just as organized in their attack as they allege the Scio's are in their support. I am one myself. The fact of the matter is that the reviews amongst my group are actually mixed. We are individuals with our own opinions about a movie. As far as all of us buying the book six or seven times-I never even bought it at all and my husband bought only one. He loved it! But he did not like the movie. This goes the same with some of my friends including non-Scio's who are not prejudiced. I do believe that some guys truly had a high opinion of the movie eventhough I don't agree with them. It may be true that some are automatically partial to it at the get-go but no single person is totally free of any bias. We all bring our personal tastes to any work of art. Some of these guys like this kind of story and message regardless. So what.I also did not see any sublimal messages for the religion either except that we don't like psyches and/or psychotics. It was overt, not hidden. What is wrong with that?  What about the Christian messages in "Ben Hur" or Jewish ones in "Shindler's List" ? Jewish people don't like Nazis. That doesn't make them bad.  These are very valid points of view shared by others.In place of invalidating criticism some constructive criticism is due-a better way to do. The story is better suited to a TV miniseries or at least an epic length of three hours to  flesh it out more and develop the characters. Roger Christian could still direct the special effects, but hire a top-notch experienced screenwriter and director,  cast a more charismatic Johnnie Goodboy-Tyler; someone more blond and blue-eyed. Prior to release market test it for response.  Spielberg would have been a great candidate but may not have had the courage to take it on. Gene Hackman would be great as Terl, not that John was bad and Kelly Preston was great.It's true the creators did not put the film "over the plate" but the extreme Scio critics couldn't have created anything better if they could create anything at all. And that's my humble but Constitutionally protected opinion.
