I had heard that this movie was a star wars type thing, but I thought it was 1000% better.  It made me realized that our political system is so important and being involved and knowing what is going on and having freedom is worth fighting for.   I thought it was great.

reviews.review_title: Not a bad first sci fi effort for Travolta
reviews.content: Personally I thought the movie could have been better, although I did enjoy Terl. Pretty classic "stupid evil villian". The hero should have had more character development and I would have injected the invasion scene. It made humans look a bit stupid, but then were saved by Johnny (hero).A star wars classic it was not, but then again this was Travoltas' first Sci-Fi effort. I'd go see it again with my kids. They were blown away by it.I give it a thumbs up as its own work.Go see it but don't compare it to Lucas masterpiece models.

The book was outstanding and usually I am disappointed by a movie that is taken straight from a successful novel.  In this case I felt the director was able to portray the characters very well.  I was totally entertained from beginning to end.  John Travolta played a totally evil and nasty alien and I was impressed by his duplication of the novel's character.  Johnnie Goodboy Tyler was the ultimate hero in both the book and the movie.  I will watch this movie more than once and I look forward to the sequel.

reviews.review_title: The movie kept me on the edge of my seat the whole 2 hours!
reviews.content: John Travolta shows his range as an actor in portraying the evil Terl. That underlying evil glint in his eyes kinda reminds me of a few terrestrials I have run into!  Barry Pepper as Jonnie portrayed the type of hero I would definitely want on my side in a tight spot. L. Ron Hubbard is a great story teller. All in all a fun, fast-paced action film.  I will definitely see it again!

reviews.review_title: Nowhere near as bad as others say here
reviews.content: 1. It's not any worse than any average sci-fi film out there. 2. All sci-fi films require suspension of disbelief - and this requires nothing more than anything out of any of the star trek, star wars, Matrix, or SG1 universes. Even someone with advanced degrees in astrophysics and cosmology can enjoy sci-fi movies - and the gaping holes in known science or logic in this movie are no greater than any other sci-fi movie or show - you could take apart any movie - even Casablanca - with it's flaws - but that would only ruin the movie. 3. I don't know or care about the author or his religion and followers - it's irrelevant to the movie. Christian, Muslim, Mormon - they've all got ridiculous myths, beliefs, and followers - followers who have to suspend logic in real life everyday - so why not for a movie? 4. I have to assume that people must have come into this predisposed to dislike it. I saw it on TV years ago just channel surfing - partway through - and found it completely distracting and enjoyable. Perhaps it's the Lord of the Flies crowd mentality but just drop the attitude, bias, or thought that it's real and IF you really like sci-fi, you might find this movie quite enjoyable. 5. It's got more-advanced and bigger-than-human sinister aliens (Independence Day), a devastated future earth (planet of the apes), a protagonist standing up for the human race (Stargate), A hero and a woman standing up together against 'the man' (Total Recall), wily & plucky humans (Flash Gordon, Buck Rogers), a few explosions and harrier jets (Arnold S. movies), etc. - what's not to like? I'm giving this an 8 partly because I like it and partly because it doesn't deserve the collective ~2.0 it has now. There are tons of actual 2.0 deserving movies with 7.0 rating on the IMDb simply because of crowd mentality - ever notice that most new movies hit the street with at least a 7.0 but most drop down to at least a 5.0 once they're no-longer current - especially younger-audience movies?

I enjoyed the movie Battlefield Earth very much and would definitely recommend seeing it.  There were many smiling faces and interesting comments to be heard as the movie let out.  I plan on seeing it again, as do many of the viewers I have since spoken to.

Being a Travolta fan since I used to watch Welcome Back Kotter after school as a kid, it was a real pleasure to watch him at his evil comic best as an alien bent on destruction of all mankind in Battlefield Earth. Recently, John has created a new persona for the big screen with funny, villainous characters in Pulp Fiction, Face Off and Broken Arrow. I was impressed with the way he has added more elements of comic dark humor in B.E. I'll definitely be seeing this one again, like all his movies, to catch all the subtle lines and facial expressions I missed the first time.

reviews.review_title: This is science FICTION, everyone should realize this and get over it...
reviews.content: I love this movie, I have watched it several times and it hurts me to see it get lambasted by almost everyone. Sure there are holes in the plot, physics not behaving as they should etc, but this is science FICTION, not reality based drama. The book is fantastic and answers a lot of the questions asked by the people prepared to blast this movie. The humans use the aliens technology to learn how to fly, etc. Who knows what technology will be like in 1000 years from another planet?!? The Psyclos arrogance to everything non Psyclo is a parallel to America's arrogance to the rest of the world as it is today. After millenniums of being the master race of the universe, they have stagnated and look down upon all other species/races with contempt. Their society is based on corruption and I can't help but think LRH intended this to parallel the consumer capitalism that rules the western world today. Read the book, I am not a scientologist, nor a Christian, and I think most of the disliking of this movie is due to prejudice (towards Scientology)and people not following the story and filling in the blanks themselves. This is no worse an attempt at the scifi genre as any other movie, including the completely unoriginal Star Wars trilogy, Star Trek etc. I can't wait until someone gets the balls to do a movie of LRH's Mission Earth decology, what a great yarn that one is, full of corruption, temptation, greed, lust and science FICTION at its best. I gave this 8 out of 10, it could have been longer and more in depth by explaining all the little bits people with no imagination couldn't figure out for themselves, but overall it is a good attempt at a very complex and long piece of science FICTION.

reviews.review_title: Take a look, there is depth here!
reviews.content: I always hesitate to add my comments, not being as articulate as many, but this time, I feel I must.  I saw this movie and was very impressed. Having read some negative reviews, I suggest they see it a second time.The movie has depth.  There is much to learn about how education contributes to ability to do what you must, how prejudices can bring about the downfall of any race, no matter how powerful and how freedom from oppression is the goal of all.The special effects are so good, one doesn't think of them as "special" just part of the story.  And it moves fast, faster than the book, but doesn't stray from the actual story line.I've seen movies that had little or no link to the book it is based on, and that is not the case here.All I can say is take a second look, it's worth it.Lorraine

reviews.review_title: Thoroughly enjoyed the movie -- edge-of-your-seat adventure!
reviews.content: The movie, Battlefield Earth, was based on the book by the same name by author L. Ron Hubbard.  The book was recently named the best sci-fi of the century by Publisher's Weekly.  The movie closely follows the book, although there are some changes, which I can only assume were made to successfully adapt such an epic to the screen.  It's easy to sit back with a critical eye, not having been the producer/director who had to make the critical decisions in the movie's production.  From start to finish, the movie kept me on the edge of my seat, but refreshingly, without the unnecessary gore or foul language.  There are many humorous moments to ease the tension as well. The special effects were exciting and seamless (the transition between the actual footage and computer graphics).  Overall, the film invoked the kind of excitement I felt while watching the very first of the Star Wars trilogy years ago -- a great movie for the entire family.

This movie was a fascinating story of a possible future of planet Earth and the struggle of humanity to survive against overwhelming odds and an oppressive alien race. It showed how ingenuity and a determined spirit can overcome what may seem to be an insurmountable challenge. The movie incorporated an appealing hero, a despicable villain and a little bit of romance.  Our family enjoyed watching the story unravel- the adults and the teenagers in our family all enjoyed the movie.

reviews.review_title: Liked the movie, loved the music!
reviews.content: It would be impossible for any movie to truly do justice to the book, "Battlefield Earth" (which I recommend to all and sundry; I've read it four times so far), because of its enormous scope and long time-line.  The movie makes a valiant attempt to include as much as possible of the events in the book, mostly by truncating the timeline and the number of characters.  The severe truncation makes the movie storyline more like a myth, with larger-than-life characters doing impossible deeds against incredible odds in an implausibly short period of time.  Nonetheless, the moviemakers did a good job, and the effects are spectacular, if somewhat derivative.  You may have seen similar effects in other movies, but they're used here to tell a new story (just as you have seen words like these before, but I'm using them to tell you something new).  And the story is a good one, well worth watching.  The part I liked best, however, was the music!  It enhanced the movie without overwhelming it (I didn't really think about how good the music was until we got to the credits ~ which we always watch, all the way to the very end, as a matter of principle ~ when the movie wasn't distracting me).  I plan to buy the soundtrack, which I almost never do, and play it often, especially when I feel I'm in an uphill battle and need to boost my spirits.  It is stirring, inspiring, almost martial music. Perhaps I'll play it the next time I read the book!  If you like the movie, you'll love the book (it will explain many things that they couldn't fit into the movie), which will also tell you the rest of the story ~ this movie covers only the first half of the book!

reviews.review_title: I thought that Battlefield Earth was a lot of fun!
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is loosely based on the first half or so of L. Ron Hubbard's classic Sci-Fi novel.  I liked the movie, but the book is better, and recommend that to those that liked the movie as well those who didn't as it is excellent reading.The movie was fun, if perhaps a little over the top, in the mold of Independence Day, and Armageddon.  There was plenty of action and it moved along pretty well, although some details provided in the book were left out. I enjoyed Travolta's performance as Terl, the villain and thought Forrest Whittaker was great as Ker, Terl's assistant.If you are looking for light, fun summer movie entertainment, i recommend Battlefield Earth

reviews.review_title: Travolta was fabulous, the book was butchered.
reviews.content: If the movie would've been 2 1/2 hours long to accommodate for some background setting and showing a bit more of the book content it could've been an awesome movie, since the book kept me hanging, made me sad, happy and then burst with excitement. Th movie was pretty dark in lighting etc.Was worth watching one time, I was planning to see it 3 times originally.

I have been a great fan of the book, for years.  However I had heard of some of the changes, so I went to see how the movie was on it's own.  The story was 97% different, cinematography was horrid, lighting left you wishing for a lighter so you could see, and pacing was too fast.  My wife had never heard anything about the story at all and she didn't like it at all.  The movie moved so fast that the characters were there and gone before you even knew who it was.  No plot development.  To me the worst part was the fact that the picture was ALWAYS at a 20 degree angle. Nice touch once in a while, but not every shot!!! 0 believeability factor, (harriers still in mint condition after 1000 years, Barbarians learning to fly a harrier like a pro in 7 days? [must be the "Sally Struthers Learn to fly combat in 7days or your planet back" classes]) I accepted that it wasn't the book early on, but stuck it out to see where they were going to go, and how it would play out.  Wish I had left at the opening credits! I have only walked out on one movie in my life, and this one almost made it two, and I am not very picky! (ask my wife)

reviews.review_title: Amazing what you can do in Hollywood
reviews.content: While there seem to be many mixed reviews on this movie, I rated it quite high. I had read the book some time ago and had a very very vivid "movie" in my head of what occurred in the pages of that book. I was not only skeptical when I heard the movie was being made, but doubtful that it would carry any semblance of emotion/impact that the book had. You know, everyone always says, "the book was better"... Well, I was very surprised that so many elements that made the book so incredible were kept in the movie. Most of the book seemed to me to be all but impossible to duplicate on film -- I mean, how can you make a 9' or 10' tall alien using the real actor's head and not end up with a tiny head on a big body? The characters looked very good to me. Also, I was impressed with the photography (there is no blood in the movie, but you sure feel like there is). I thought John Travolta did an excellent "evil" and Barry Pepper did a fine job as Johnny -- excellent acting on both of their parts. All in all I think it was a very tough challenge for Hollywood to undertake. I think my book "movie" was better, but there really is no way to make what I have in my head become a reality even with the most modern technology. Hats off to those who pulled it off!

reviews.review_title: The spirit of mankind wins again!
reviews.content: I have read the book 3 times.  It was interesting to see the movie version, which, of course, had to be shortened and written to have impact on the big screen.  John Travolta did an excellent job of portraying Terl.  Barry Pepper moved and represented Jonnie very well.  Both brought forth the actual characters as Hubbard made them in the novel.  Man's spirit came through and hope for mankind against all odds.  The Psychlos were advanced technologically, but stupid on how to best use that technology.  They underestimated man.  I thought the sets were excellent and portrayed how it could look in 3000.

I was shocked to see that this movie has such a low rating. I loved this movie. I've seen it half a dozen times at least. I don't know anybody who doesn't like this movie, personally. Sure, it's not the greatest movie ever. It may even be a little cheesy on occasion. But overall it's a great sci-fi movie. The writer must have been obsessed with leverage for some reason, because they use that word like 20 times in this movie. In truth, I wouldn't give this movie 10 stars, I would have given like 7 or 8, but since it was so low a rating I wanted to bring the rating up a little. If you're into Star Trek, Star Wars or other sci-fi movies, then you'll probably enjoy this movie. It's definitely worth watching. And if you don't like it, then what they heck do you know? Go watch Driving Miss Daisy, cause you're a douche.

reviews.review_title: what I thought of Battlefield Earth with John Travolta
reviews.content: good guy, bad guy.  good guy wins.  I thought the movie was fun. (Whenever critics knock a movie and I take it as a sign that I should go see it)  I enjoyed it.  My wife and kids enjoyed it.the evil of the backstabbing Psychlos was hilarious.  The evil looks from their glowing eyes when outdone by another Psychlo (or earthling) was great. Travolta did a great job.  I liked the bad guys and their portrayal better than the good guys.The story was like the book with few changes.  (Books are always better than movies.)Lots of action and good special effects.  The ships were utilitarian and real.  Was neat seeing them rumble around the planet.The Psychlos were best.  Evil, sneaky, corrupt... you name it.  Worth it just to get a load of their squabbles, rudeness and scheming.Entertaining.

reviews.review_title: A real and human hero, a super mean villain
reviews.content: They did change a few things from the book in the movie and that made it hard to be objective. So I saw it twice, and the second time actually really enjoyed it. The  hero is very real and human. The villain is funny. The film is visually very interesting, and they managed to capture some of the grandness of the adventure of the book. I recommend it, though if you've read the book you have to remember that books and films are completely different art forms.

reviews.review_title: Don't buy what some of the critics say!
reviews.content: While this movie may not be the next "Casablanca", it is nowhere near as bad as the vengeful attacks I have read. Seems either the movie hit some raw nerves or there's a mass hysteria because the story came from an L.Ron Hubbard novel. If you just watch it as a movie-goer it is an entertaining story, with great sets and fast action.  And it tells a message of intelligence that perhaps we ought to listen to a bit harder in this current civilization: greed and criminality do NOT pay, while courage and guts and willingness to fight back against oppression are indeed virtues.  Maybe there's just one or two vested interests out there that would rather not "entertain" that idea amongst the populace at large!! And by the way the book itself is fabulous and it IS a Sci-fi classic!

I enjoyed this movie very much!  For a two-hour movie it went by very fast and was over before I knew it.  The action was fast-paced and my interest was held firmly.  The special effects were fun to watch, too. Travolta did an excellent job as Terl. The covert hostility of the character he played was executed well. Like good wine, he gets better with age.  I would recommend this movie to anyone who is looking for a good time at the cinema.Carol McLeod

This movie is great!  Action, adventure, wit and great special effects.  It seems impossible that the hero can pull off a victory and then does it in a way that makes sense.  It is wit and human courage triumphant over evil. Seeing the side of the aliens and their money motivation is unique and makes it logical.  It is just like when the Europeans conquered and exploited the frontiers in America and Africa.  A must see.  It is even better the second time.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable and fun Sci-Fi. Even better on the 2nd viewing!
reviews.content: Despite the fact that this movie does not adhere totally to the incredible story line of the book of the same title, it is an enjoyable and fun movie to watch in and of itself.  It has some of the elements of other gangbuster movies such as Star Wars, (the special effects guy is the same, so big surprise), but it is unique all on its own.  Suggest watching it more than once as greater understanding of what is occurring results on the second viewing as well as, if you have read the book, you may have less attention on trying to compare it to the book.  Doing this movie is an incredible project as the detail given in the book is impossible to get across in 2 hours.  Well done to John Travolta for making sure this entertainment became available to us in film form.

reviews.review_title: A monstrously dull and slow-witted yarn that seems unduly impressed with itself.
reviews.content: When, several months ago, John Travolta referred to the writing of his guru, L. Ron Hubbard, as "the fine wine of science fiction," I KNEW something fishy was up.  To the best of my knowledge--and I consider myself fairly well read in the genre--the late L. Ron Hubbard is widely regarded as an amateurish hack of a science fiction author, given to poor spelling and worse grammar, and further hindered by his apparent inability to spin a trite piece of fantasy in less than 1000 pages.  Actor John Travolta, who admits that he has read "The Time Machine" and "Leagues Under The Sea" [sic], seemingly elevates Hubbard's scrawling above the works of H.G. Wells and Jules Verne.  And THAT, my friends, is a stretch.It is no less a stretch for the film, "Battlefield Earth." A monstrously dull and slow-witted yarn, here we have a typical high-school script: Aliens rule the earth, Mankind fights back.  How many times have we seen this theme rehashed through the years?  Most schlock producers can work with such a premise in an entertaining fashion, but not so with "Battlefield Earth." Produced as a "labor of love" and as a "tribute" to L. Ron Hubbard, the film is nothing more than a thinly-veiled and campy Scientology lecture on breaking the bonds of bureaucracy and defeating the System (yawn). Features the CGI effects that may be expected in ANY mediocre film today, but the movie is poorly framed, poorly acted, poorly scored and very poorly edited. More than embarrassing, the film is mortifyingly bad--it makes one ashamed to be a theatregoer.Without bailing off into the childish storyline, Salvation Army costuming and dastardly dialogue, it may be enough to note that this movie is based on merely the first HALF of Hubbard's 1982 novel, "Battlefield Earth."  A hugely boring tome of over 1000 pages, it reads like the scribbling of a neurotic recluse who starts out sober and finishes in a drunken stupor. Which does not bode well for the promised sequel film, presumably based on the remaining half of the same book.CineDigest

I thought this movie was just fine.  It wasn't perfect and there were things that could have been done differently and didn't follow the book (which was MUCH, MUCH better) as closely as I would have liked, but it was enjoyable, action-packed, and best of all it was a sci-fi movie with John Travolta AND Forest Whitaker.  Bravo to Travolta for making a sci-fi movie, there are never enough, and for being a discerning enough guy to play the bad guy instead of having to be the protagonist (no matter how ill-advised, as some actors are embarassingly want to do...) I would recommend this film to others and will buy it on video.

reviews.review_title: Battlefield Earth the film vs. Battlefield Earth the book.
reviews.content: I have been waiting for this film to come out since I read the book.  At the time, I wasn't a big sci-fi or fiction reader and the size of the book was daunting.  But because I had heard so much about it, I picked it up.  Good thing I wasn't working at that time because I didn't put it down for three days.  It was that engrossing. As many book readers complain, I'm afraid that, even though John Travolta is one of my favorites, the film didn't stick to the plot of the book or tell enough about the characters for me to root for them.  I liked many things about the film but it didn't capture Mr. Hubbard's masterful tension, expression and warmth for the characters. Johnnie Goodboy Tyler was alone as a human when Terl brought him to the base, not one of hundreds. He was alone in knowing that he had to save the world of humans. He was alone. Chrissy was blonde and sort of whimpy til the end.  Johnnie was an exceptional human being with a depth that included razor-sharp wit and an insoucient sense of humor that allowed him to triumph over the plodding, evil minded psychlos. The director did not do justice to Hubbard's masterpiece. If you want to find out about Battlefield Earth, get the book.  I dare you to try to put it down.

Had high hopes for this one because the book was really good. I do realize that most if not all movies never top their books. Knowing that I would have to say this movie was one of worst I've seen.Too much of everything was jammed into a 2 hour movie.  The movie had no time to build characters, scenes or even a plot.To sum it up, I was lost throughout the whole movie. I even read the book so I should have some what of a clue.  No clue.

Battlefield Earth is loaded with great special effects.  The spaceships are very cool.  Travolta is very funny as Terl the alien security chief. Forest Whittaker is excellent as Terl's sidekick.  This is a must see for sci-fi fans and anyone that is looking for a fun and action packed movie.

reviews.review_title: Excellent adaption of a great science fiction novel!
reviews.content: The movie Battlefield Earth was a great adaption of the science fiction novel by L. Ron Hubbard.  I felt the movie captured the essence of the first half of the novel to the screen very well. I am sure Mr. Hubbard would be quite pleased with the work put into this movie.The special effects were well made and the actors put on a great show. I felt like I was sitting in the theatre for several hours but I enjoyed every minute.  Everyone should see this movie! I look forward to seeing the sequels!

I thought the film was entertaining.  It is hard to make a movie that compares to a large book.  Some parts have to be simplified.  Overall I thought the movie was entertaining.  The movie did simplify the book and leave out parts in the second half.  I thought that the book was much better.  But if the book had been strickly followed the movie would have been 5 hours long.  I thought that the acting was great.

I loved the book and the film did it some justice. I liked John Travolta as an evil alien and Barry Pepper was quite good as an action hero. The special effects were very good. I also liked the message of the movie, that's not something you see in every flick in this genre.
I thought the plot line was good even though some of the costumes were hoakie. It does not deserve a 2.4 rating

I thought the movie was very entertaining.  The actors were great and they played their part very well.  I loved the outside view of the snow cap mountains, the rolling hills and the special effects that made the movie.

reviews.review_title: Acting and art direction v. good.
reviews.content: I really liked this, especially the second half of the film.  The main character has some very good moments, and has a never-die attitude, but not just with false bravado, but with clever actions as well.The main character's goal is not just to "kill the bad guys", but to free all people from their oppression.For example, there is a moment where he could kill the bad guy (John Travolta) easily, but turns it around to make the bad guy think him less a threat, and so the main character gets more leeway to achieve his larger goals.Lots of moments where the audience laughs, cheers or applauds.

reviews.review_title: Why so much trashing of the film.
reviews.content: I liked the book. It mixed adventure, Sci-fi and some wry social commentary. It is always hard for a movie to live up to the book but the film is entertaining and puts a different twist on what aliens are like. Who says because you have space travel you are that smart in other areas. I liked bringing the alien characters down to a more everyday level. If you like sci-fi movies Battlefield Earth is worth seeing. And if you have not read the book, definitely worth reading.GL

reviews.review_title: Battlefield Earth Is A Good SciFi Action Flick
reviews.content: Battlefield Earth is a good SciFi action flick.Barry Pepper, John Travolta and Forrest Whitaker are way cool in this last ditch battle set in the year 3000. Humans have this one chance to take back the Earth from alien conquerers, the Psyclos.Battlefield Earth is a way better movie than Wing Commander, Supernova, Virus or Deep Blue Sea. Moving outside the SciFi genre into the broader set of action movies, it's better than Entrapment or The Thomas Crown Affair.READ THE BOOK (it's a 1,000 page edge-of-the-seat rocket ride) and see the movie version of Battlefield Earth.George Lucas said Battlefield Earth is a great movie and he's a man who knows a thing or two about SciFi fight for freedom movies.I'm right here with you George!Take care, be well, have fun,Tom

reviews.review_title: Loved the book- Enjoyed the movie!
reviews.content: The book was totally amazing.  I have read it 3 times and seeing the movie has made me want to read it again.  The movie was very good, but it didn't follow the book very much.  It was a very entertaining movie and I thought it was great.

FREE THE EARTH!A Review of the Screenplay for Battlefield Earth by Brad LinaweaverBrad Linaweaver, co-author of the best selling Doom novels. acquired a copy of the Corey Mandell shooting script that was used during the Summer 1999 filming of Battlefield Earth in Montreal, Canada. A Nebula finalist and Prometheus award winner for his first major science fiction work, Moon of Ice, Linaweaver has also written the Sliders books based on the popular TV series. In addition to selling over seventy short stories and 200 articles to anthologies and magazines, he is co-editor of Free Space. Following are his comments and thoughts.Adapting one of the modern classics of science fiction for the screen might seem a daunting task but Corey Mandell has proven he was equal to the task. Everything L. Ron Hubbard learned as one of the top writers of the Golden Age of Science Fiction is on display in his magnum opus, Battlefield Earth. If ever there was a novel demanding the big screen treatment, this is it!The screenwriter understands that the strength of a book-to-movie project lies in faithfulness to the original vision. All too often, Hollywood spends a fortune bastardizing the work of gifted authors. That hasn't happened this time. Reading the actual screenplay used for the filming of Battlefield Earth has been a revelation. Imagine Hollywood spending tens of millions of dollars to get it right.Mandell trusted the novel. This gave him the advantage of using the well-structured plot and the interesting shadings of the characters. The hero, Jonnie (played by Barry Pepper), is adaptable in a manner we rarely see on the screen. We've seen action heroes who do incredibly brave things. We've seen more cerebral heroes who outsmart their opponents and even flatter their vanity. But Jonnie can do both as the situation requires. He can switch back and forth in a second. He knows his opponents have all the advantages but they also have one potentially fatal flaw, their pride. Jonnie never forgets that at crucial moments his enemies will underestimate him.In fact, the bad guys the alien Psychlos are the literal embodiment of foolish pride. Because it only took them minutes to conquer the Earth with superior technology, they assume that the remnants of human beings who remain will never cause them any trouble. After a thousand years of dominating the Earth, there is little reason for them to think otherwise.The primary villain of the story is Terl, head of Earth security, portrayed by John Travolta. He is smarter than the other Psychlos. He is the first to realize that Jonnie is smarter than the other man-animals. Even so, Terl can't overcome his prejudices sufficiently to imagine that human beings might be able to take back their planet.Already we are dealing with a level of sophistication in the writing beyond most film and televised science fiction. The script also retains many nice touches that only show up in real science fiction. A good example is that the aliens find a beautiful blue sky with white clouds to be one of the ugliest things they've ever seen.The plot is never boring. Terl is so busy plotting against other Psychlos that it distracts him from the human threat to his power. The fundamental weakness of all tyrannies is that they must ultimately devour themselves. When the ruling power becomes decadent, the victims of Empire have their chance if they possess sufficient courage. The script couldn't include all the material about economics and politics found in the novel but it kept what was essential. The result is a surprisingly adult film that will appeal to teenagers with its action and adventure. Maybe some of the kids will even be inspired to read the book.Already the film version of Battlefield Earth is being compared to other block-buster science fiction films before it even comes out. The obvious and best comparison is to the Star Wars films. There are very few films like these. The comparison is also inspired by Roger Christian in the director's chair when he'd earlier been art director for the original Star Wars and unit director on The Phantom Menace. He was even recommended for Battlefield Earth by no less that George Lucas! And, of course, the design and special effects experts are the same people who worked on the Star Wars films as well as the Alien films, Independence Day, X-Files and Titanic.But after a close reading of this script, I think Battlefield Earth can be favorably compared to a film that has nothing to do with science fiction - Spartacus. Only a handful of films have dealt with the full implications of slavery and what it takes to resist the most evil of institutions. Cynics won't understand what I'm talking about because they share the psychology of the Psychlos.A good plot puts characters in conflict and then has clever resolution. Battlefield Earth the novel has this. And so does the script. How ironic that there are snobs who dismiss this kind of story as pulp fiction.
Pulp fiction! The title of a movie that was one of the great moments in John Travolta's career. Pulp fiction! The kind of high adventure and romances that L. Ron Hubbard wrote back when people read to get their entertainment thrills.Today's kids are hungry for stories of heroes and villains on an epic scale. The situation with which Battlefield Earth begins seems far more hopeless than any problems the audience might have. There seems no conceivable way for the good guys to defeat the bad guys. To quote the opening line of the novel: "Man," said Terl, "is an endangered species."For two hours in a darkened movie theatre, a new generation will be shown that sometimes cliches are the truest things in the world: "While there's life, there's hope."Mandell has done his job well.) 2000 Brad Linaweaver

This is a amusing look at or planet in the future. It's about having a dream and pursuing it.  It's about stepping out and believing the earth is not flat so to speak.  It's about the oppressed overcoming the oppressors.  And defeating them with their own greed.It's a light hearted, fast, fun view of what happens when a race doesn't pay attention to their self destructive ways and then overcomes their mistakes.Entertaining and not too far off the original book.Highly recommend it, more than once.  John Travolta does one evil dude.  Makes ya want to slap some sense into him :)  Forrest Whittaker was superb. Barry Pepper did a great job!This is not 'Business as Usual' in Hollywood SciFi.

My 13-year-old son loved it. A great movie? No.  A fun movie? YES! Travolta is great as Terl and Barry Pepper captures the spirit, determination and courage of the hero, Johnny.  The special effects were fabulous.  The dog fight scene between the Psychlo fighters and the U.S. Harrier Jump Jets is too cool!

reviews.review_title: I thought Battlefield Earth was a great adventure!
reviews.content: I thought Battlefield Earth was a great adventure-- John Travolta did a great job at depicting a truly evil entity.  It shows it's not just earth that has the greedy businessman!  The story itself tests man's ability to overcome a different type of enemy and use his intelligence to win over evil.

I just have to say, that I am shocked at the amount of scathing criticism that  has been going on regarding this movie.  You would think this movie was like the seventh sign to the ending of the world or somethingI liked this movie. I liked it even better the second time!  The book is an all time favorite of mine, as well as the stars of the film. I was thoroughly entertained.  Yes, the movie really followed more the spirit of the book and not play by play of the book, but still I thought they accomplished what was needed to get across the story line, and the feeling of `taking back the planet'!!!I look at these reviews and normally, even on a Sci Fi movie, which usually gets picked apart by even the nicest of critics, this film was blasted! What's up with THAT?!?  It didn't even seem to me, in some of the reviews, that the critics even WATCHED the movie before lambasting the whole thing! Half of them didn't even have the basic premise of the movie or even the NAMES OF THE ALIENS correct in their reviews!!!! The reviews seemed like some sort of panicked attack on the religion of the book author and the starhellooooooit's a movie.   And it's an interpretation of a book by just a guy.  And a big movie starwho is just a guy and who seemed to have had fun making the movie too!  I can't wait for the sequel.

Earth, 3000 A.D., and we lost the war against the aliens a long time ago. Man is an endangered species on the way out, and they know it.  The aliens are big, bad, dress in long black trenchcoats, and display a wicked combination of stupidity, greed, and self-interest.  Humans are small, emaciated, desparate, but partiotic, self-sacrificing, and very interested in learning all they can, especially about how to take back the Earth. The Dome City is the one respite from the cliche views of a Post-Apocolyptic Earth. The acting jobs of the humans are convincing and evocative of the most noble character in men.  Travolta and the other aliens are frightening and comic in their arrogance and displays of raw power.  Time and again, you have to wonder how they managed to make Travolta and the aliens look like specimens of Giganthropicus while standing next to humans.  A fun sci-fi show that displays a range of character and spirit with the requisite explosions and gunfire, while avoiding profanity and explicit sex.  A beheading is done off-screen, while you see the actors react to it.  The two amputations (performed on bad guys) are handled almost as comic relief. While you don't leave the theatre pumping your arm up and down like you did after Independence Day, you do walk out smugly thinking "Homo Sapiens Kick Butt".

I was really eager to see this movie. I had not read the book, and don't have an opinion about LRH or his works one way or the other. I was enticed by the premise and the few previews I had seen and talked a friend into seeing it who is generally not much of a Sci Fi fan. I should have read a review.I knew we were in trouble from the opening cave scenes. The acting and filming were middling daytime TV quality, at best - stereotypic characters, over dramatic dialog and camera movement. Ughh. I hoped that with the debut of the Travolta character things would get on track. Unfortunately, it got worse throughout the film.Other reviews have already pointed out many of the obvious logical errors in the film. I am pretty good at ignoring that kind of stuff as long as there is some element in film that is interesting, endearing, enticing, funny, etc. For me this film had nothing.My friend and I were close to leaving several times, but for some reason chose to stay. We chose poorly.2 out of 10 - with the only points being for fair special effects.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  I read the book, so I know how hard it was to make this into a 2 hour movie.  They did a good job, and it is worth seeing.  While it is not perfect (what movie from a good novel is), it is a fun movie.

I thought Battlefield Earth was a lot of fun. I am a big fan of the book, so ended up seeing the movie three times.  I enjoyed it the first time, and enjoyed it even more the second and third.  I think I enjoyed Travolta as Terl the most, just because he obviously had such a good time with the role. I thought Forrest W. did great as the side-kick and loved his scene at the end of the film when he got to turn the tables on his jerk of a boss. Pepper did a great job with Johnny's character - playing it with the right amount of seriousness for the situation Johnny was in - basically a "common man" rather reluctantly thrust into the role of hero by virtue of his own desire for freedom and strength of integrity, rather than any thirst for power.  Good versus evil in a wild-ride, fun, campy sci-fi setting...that's a good time and a good movie experience in my book any day.  (By the way, the audiences I saw it with also really got into the film - laughing, cheering, etc. - this is always a sign to me of a good film.)

This could have been a campy short if distilled to its essence, but instead like the book it is based on it is drawn out and postures too pretensiously. This is one of those I would rather seen on video, so you can take a break or just fast forward when it bogs down.

reviews.review_title: The book was amazing but the movie...
reviews.content: Ok, L. Ron Hubbard. Genius writer. Dianetics? Whether made on a bet, or fondly believed, not to my taste. What I can't understand is how one of Scientology's premier poster boys could take one of the absolute best science fiction novels of all time, and make a work of utter nonsense out of it.1. Ignore the fact that over half the novel is left out of the movie altogether. I didn't think it was possible to cover 1000 or so pages in a two hour movie anyways. 2. Ok, so half the characters are missing. I can understand that as well. It's just a part of the economizing to make a shorter movie. 3. What the heck did they do to the plot? While Hubbard's plot was not always coherent or believable, the liberties they took with the screenplay should have made him come back from the grave and rip Travolta a new one. This movie finally takes the place of "Sleepaway Camp" when it comes to plot holes and inconsistencies. I'd sooner believe that Jeff Goldblum can interface his Mac with an alien computer system (windows 2000?) than I believe cavemen using 1000 year old Harrier jets. In case you haven't guessed, I'm disappointed.

I had a lot of fun at this movie.  I liked the first half, but thought the second half of the movie was great.  I hope they do may a sequel to this thing because I heard the second part of the book is even better.  If you're ready for some fun, seeing this movie will do it.

reviews.review_title: All in all a good movie.
reviews.content: I don't understand why people rubbish this movie, I found it to be very entertaining. I think people forget that movies are for entertainment only and not always a reflection of the world around us therefore they don't always have to be believable. I think people are watching far to much reality TV. This movie is set 1000 years into the future and therefore should not in any way be compared with life as we know it. I found this movie to be both funny and entertaining and I thought John Travolta, Barry Pepper & Forest Whitaker all did very well in their individual roles. This is not a movie to be taken seriously and if it is taken seriously then maybe people need to get out more. I guess I can only say that if you didn't like this movie then maybe SciFi isn't for you.Battlefield Earth is set 1000 years in the future in the year 3000. the Earth has been taken over by an Alien Race and People are treated like we would treat monkeys. Jonnie (Barry Pepper) sets out from his tribe to find a better life and to verify the existence of the demons (Aliens). He meets up with two men out hunting for food and they bond and become good friends after an auspicious beginning. When Jonnie and his two new friends are captured by the Aliens they are taken to a processing plant, there they are imprisoned and made into slaves Jonnie is taken by Terl (John Travolta) who then attempts to educate him with a learning machine in the ways of his race in an attempt to get them to mine gold for his own personal gain, Jonnie, realising that this education is the key to there freedom, and uses the learning machine as much as he can, and with his new found knowledge relays the rest or the captives to rebel against their captors.
If you liked this film here are other titles I suggest for you:Mamma MiaThunder Force(it's not out yet, but I am predicting this review will be read in the future): Thunder Force 2.

reviews.review_title: Read the book - watch the movie
reviews.content: Like many many movies, Battlefield Earth had to leave out part of the book to fit in to the time frame allowed. Battlefield Earth is a tremendous sci-fi novel. The movie picked out many of the action scenes in the first half of the book (the second half wasn't covered at all).If you read the book, the movie really starts making sense. I think the director did a fabulous job of portraying the Psychlos, the transport ships, and planet Earth in the year 3000.Like lots of things, check them out for yourself. Read the book, then watch the movie and make up your own mind.joelm-3

Let's leave the movie itself alone for a minute - in 10 years time this will be a cult classic.Students will gather in lecture halls, wearing moon boots, dreadlocks & nose clips in order to communally recite lines with John Travolta.I know someone who actually PAID to watch this twice - I paid once, having already been warned! An alien race has enslaved humanity by the year of 3,000. The Earthmen rebel.Just the sort of thing to take one's mind off the daily worries for two hours--will "our men" succeed--or will they not.An apt analogy to any activities towards Man's liberation, such as the American Independence etc.

Putting all the fiery rhetoric, nasty rumors, falsehoods, prejudices and other hot comments aside, I'd like to review this film for what it is: an adaptation of L. Ron Hubbard's epic sci-fi novel. Here's my view. For me, the book was terrific, which millions of others who bought it internationally can vouch for I'm sure. But the film is mediocre at best. There is one basic, major flaw with the movie, which I believe, doomed it from the beginning, and that was trying to tell this story in 2 hours. It never should have been attempted. Maybe three hours would have worked, but Travolta and director, Christiansen, didn't have that luxury.The book is rich in characters, sub-plots, humor, and most importantly a true sense of the world. Battlefield Earth is basically a story about the subjugation of mankind by an evil force and how one man helps the rest of the ragtag survivors of the planet fight back. What I loved the most about the book (besides the obsessed character of Terl) was the Scots and surviving tribes of other nations teaming together to fight back against impossible odds. I remember when I saw the film, I kept saying: where is Robert the Fox? Where are the Scots? Where is the sound of bagpipes coming over the hill? Where is that sense of "Braveheart" that I felt when I read the novel. None of that wonderful sense of the world made it into the film.And that's why it failed.It's my opinion that Travolta had a worthwhile dream to realize the book in film, and unfortunately, out of practical necessity, cut far too much of the richness of the story, and thus, unintentionally, ruined it. The flaws should have been seen at the shooting script stage, but they weren't -- and then everyone was on board the Titantic (though I don't think the film is that much of a disaster really. I would give it a 5-10 -- worth watching if you're expectations are not super-high.)Too bad it can't all be done again as an animated series which could do justice to the depth of the book. But that's showbiz.

reviews.review_title: Got it on DVD - it was great!
reviews.content: I never saw this movie in the theaters, just on DVD.  Firstly, the 5.1 channel surround on the DVD was VERY crisp, with good dimensionality and excellent effects.  The whole room was shaking during some of the blast scenes.  Overall, the movie was very enjoyable.  I  liked the whole concept, especially the fact that this all takes place 1000 years after an alien invasion.  Quite frankly, this is a lot more realistic scenario than Independence Day.  The difference here is that human technology was no match for the aliens.  This is much more realistic since any race which manages to reach Earth with interstellar travel is likely much more technologically advanced than ours.  The key to the human's success is that Johnnie was trained in the alien technology, and then figures out how to use the alien technology against the aliens.  This is much more realistic.  And realize that it was only with the help of the aliens in the first place that the humans learned alien technology.  The chances of the humans being able to figure out the advanced technology without the aliens teaching it to them is almost nil.  There were many other facts which correspond much more closely to real physics than other movies.  So I thought the concept very good, and I would recommend any SF buff to check out this movie, especially if you have a good home theater set up with 5.1 channel Dolby Digital surround. This movie is now one of my top 2 choices for showing off my stereo system (the other one is Fifth Element).

Battlefield Earth is not a classically good movie. It's not even an OK movie. It is bad. But you know, I'm a little suspicious about just HOW MUCH people seem to hate this film. I'm sure I can hear a bandwagon somewhere around here. You will hate this film if you go into it looking for intelligent science-fiction that teaches us anything new or worthwhile about the human condition. That's a shame because this film represents a missed opportunity. The idea of the human race reduced and in thrall to their alien masters on Earth could have been a wonderfully insightful poke at our notions of mastery and arrogance over this planet. But the unbelievable background story and the dramatic ending, combined with dodgy dialogue serve to ruin the whole piece. If you go into this film with lower standards, just looking for a no-brainer to waste some time with, you'll find this movie OK. Don't believe the bandwagon press. You'll cringe a few times but you won't throw your back out.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as it has been made out to be!
reviews.content: I have heard horrible reviews of Battlefield Earth.  Like others I had to watch it and see what all the fuss is about.  I waited until it came on cable and I tried to watch it with an open mind.  After seeing it for myself, I feel that the movie is not as bad as it has been made out to be. I agree that for such a big budget movie and all the hype and star power that went along with it, there should have been a better pay-off. However, if you look past all that, there is actually some pretty cool stuff in the film.  The way Barry Pepper's character evolves throughout the story is brilliant.  I also thought that the make-up and costumes were really good. I think that if people look at the movie for what it is, which is good old fashioned sci fi, they will enjoy themselves.  I also think that John Travolta and Forest Whitaker have gotten a bad rap; they carried off their characters as good as they could have in my opinion.

There was so much good material to work from, yet they still managed to create a movie that won an astonishing seven razzies. It's quite a remarkable achievement if you think about it, but certainly not in a good way. As an avid science fiction reader, I prefer to read a book before I see the movie, but in this case I don't think that was such a good idea. Yes, this was a bad movie, but amazingly enough it's even worse if you know what the story was meant to be like. L. Ron Hubbard wrote a true masterpiece and it is really disappointing to think of how it was misrepresented in the movie that bears the same name of Battlefield Earth.The original book is really just too big to try and cram into a two-hour movie; I think that the 1050 pages and 400,000 words would be a good indication of that. Just look at what happened to Dune: they took one of the most monumental works in science fiction and turned it into a movie that was nearly impossible to follow. I'll have to see it again to see if it makes more sense after reading the book, but still, it's just the thought of taking a masterpiece and mutilating it beyond recognition.In Battlefield Earth, the story was chopped up so badly that the majority of the characters in the book weren't even mentioned in the movie. Example: (Caution: Contains spoilers [not that it matters])* Robert the Fox- The Scottish war chief who is more or less Jonnie's main helper.* Dunneldee, Stormalong and Glencannon- Other Scotsmen who help with taking back the planet.* The seventy-seven remaining Scots- Where were they? Did you see any Scottish people? I didn't see any Scottish people.* The Chinese- I didn't see any of them either.* The thirty-odd alien races- Nope. Definitely no aliens besides the Psychols.Where did they all go? You might be asking if you actually care, and I would be concerned if you did. Well, I have one word for you: Carlo. Yes, Carlo. The guy with the dark, curly hair who tried the suicide dive into the dome that failed at first. I'm not sure exactly how they managed to get eighty-one people into one character, but somehow they did, if rather unsuccessfully. Actually, there was a Robert the Fox in the movie, but I didn't realize this until reading the cast list. Not to mention that only about a third of the book was covered in the movie, but I can't imagine what it would have been like had they tried to put all 1050 pages into two hours. Well . . . no, it's definitely too frightening to think about it. They would have been better off just not attempting to make the movie in the first place. The writer didn't even follow the plot. For those of you who haven't read the book, it might be interesting for you to know that when Jonnie was captured along by Terl (the movie really screwed this up) he was kept for nearly a year until they both went to Scotland and picked up the eight-one people from there. I guess they just wanted to condense the story so they captured Jonnie with a few other people and took him to a compound where there were already a few hundred humans. The real stinger to this all is this quote from the official Battlefield Earth website, and this is a real quote:". . .the grand adventure of Battlefield Earth awaited only the right script adaptation before everything came together to make it a movie reality. With a Corey Mandell screenplay, which captures the immense scope and irrepressible spirit of Hubbard's novel, that time has at last arrived."Poor Corey Mandell; you almost feel sorry for him. Almost.

I thought the movie was very entertaining and enjoyed it from start to finish the movie did seem to be rushed near the end and things started happening all over the place with no explanations on what had taken place but altogether the movie on a whole was allright and worth a look if you are into sci-fi

reviews.review_title: That film was great, critics must be blind or know nothing of SF!
reviews.content: I got the DVD for this film and enjoyed the movie and especially the bonus material. Not only I was highly impressed by the movie itself and the world that has been presented to us, but I am convinced that it will become a cult SF movie in the future. It is not Pulp Fiction, and it is useless to try to find the Travolta of Grease in this movie, but as Science Fiction goes these days, this is a five stars film in the likes of Dune. Anyone saying otherwise should tell us what kind of films they usually like, so we can balance their comments. See it for yourself, it is really impressive and intelligent.

I collect bad films, it's my guilty secret. My DVD collection has such gems as 'Fortress 2' and 'Universal Soldier: The Return'. So when it comes to bad sci-fi, I know what i'm talking about.I also read quite a few IMDB reviews before I bought this DVD, largely quite damning.Imagine my horror when I got home with my purchase, to find that this WASN'T A BAD MOVIE.Granted, to fit an entire novel into a 2-hour film, the plot suffered a little, but apart from that, I found it to be deserving of a FAR higher rating.Many of the complaints people made about this film are in fact unjustified. The set, character and production designs were spot-on, the director's artistic decision to use dutch tilt in the entire film fits the style perfectly and doesn't seem out of place. The use of colour and saturation to identify the different 'worlds' aided comprehension.I also loved Travolta's character, reminded me ever so slightly of Ming from Flash Gordon, but in a good way.

Eventually it settles down with the stupid ridiculousness and you get used to the motion sickness but you want it to end after the hour mark. This makes every single cut noticed and add the stupid slow motion in the action scenes and you get a uniquely bad film. No one should watch this without a vomit bag and be prepared to use it.
This is got to be, One of the WORST MOVIES I HAVE EVER SEEN! >:(

The alien technology is laughably incoherent, the whole premise of why the aliens are here seems like it was just told, not done, the way our heroes train and arm themselves is mind-bogglingly improbable (impossible doesn't even begin to describe it) and these are just a few plot holes. Add to that the acting, the way things just seem to happen randomly, the apparent incompetence of the aliens, how the baddie seems to treat our hero as human despite considering him an animal, and yeah, even though the movie is mildly entertaining if you are really hung over, it just contradicts logic too much to work.
Every bit as bad as its reputation.

Battlefield Earth, often considered to be the worst science fiction movie of all time, is an ugly, incomprehensible, and chaotic dystopian mess from start to finish. Based on a work by Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard, this movie focuses on the ultraviolent alien species Psychlos that enslave and study the last living humans in the 31st Century. The humans rebel and join forces to destroy these damn dirty aliens once and for all. As a person who's not quite into science fiction movies, I found out early on why this movie is often considered the worst. The laughable Psychlo designs look like troll dolls covered in moss with dirty mops on their heads. Despite being the leader of the superior conquering alien race, Terl (John Travolta) has no idea how to communicate with the humans or what food they eat. The humans also have inconsistent tendencies, the shopping mall mannequin worshippers that give away their weapons to villains, but yet know to use a nuclear bomb to take out the Psychlos' planet. Seriously, you'd think Terl and his gang would have wiped out the human race on Earth with the use of radioactive fusion, rather than the other way around. So, with that said, Battlefield Earth is one miracle of a sci-fi flop. With the horrendous art direction, baffling idiotic inconsistencies and complete stupidity in the writing and characters, this movie is one giant intergalactic dog that has to be seen to be believed. Set in the year 3000, a millennium after the Psychlo master race invades Earth and enslaves humanity, this has Travolta as a 10-foot-tall alien who gets around in dreadlocks, nose plugs and KISS boots. Even more over-the-top is his performance, which is all mwu-ha-ha-ing and an almost Shakespearean declamation of eeeeeeevil! Barry Pepper's terrible, too, bringing Christian Bale levels of intensity to his cave warrior. What also makes this badly watchable is that director Roger Christian shoots every scene on a weird askew angle.

A film infamous for reaching a badness of extraordinary proportion by being a crash and burn on every technical level. Battlefield Earth has, a story riddled with plot holes and inconsistencies, trashy sets and effects, ludicrous dialogue, hammy performances, cacophonous score, choppy editing and awkward wipe transitions, aliens masqueraded as grubby Rastafarians transparently trudging on four-foot lifts. Worst of all, Battlefield is very off-putting to view with it's incredibly unsightly visuals. This is probably the closest to what "gangrene vision" would look like if it existed, yet even then the film is able to outdo itself in its ugliness by including overabundant dutch angles and tedious slow motion. John Travolta once claimed, 'the film would be like Star Wars only better' but there really is not a hope of successfully comparing Battlefield Earth with any sci-fi film, classic or mediocre. After re-watching the horrendously bad Battlefield Earth, I have many questions.

At the beginning of the film, Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper) is able to avoid his village's security gate by using a nearby hill. So why have the gate? It clearly won't stop human invaders, and it's completely useless against the aliens (Psyclos), who have aircraft.

I get that Psyclos are taller that humans, but why do they look like regular sized people walking on stilts?

Help me understand how the Psyclos can rate human intelligence on par with man's best friend, yet can clearly see signs to the contrary all about them? Hello! Who built all those cities you destroyed? Considering all the evidence to the contrary, why do the supposedly intelligent Psyclos think human beings can't be taught how to mine gold? The very thought of humans operating mining equipment is prosperous to them, so why round them up? Certainly looks like they're put to work, and using basic tools too - and the work they're doing involves moving large quantities of rock, which is mining, right?

How is it possible that human beings with the mental capacity of prehistoric cave dwellers, can learn how to fly Harrier Jump Jets in less than a week? Then tell me how an alien species that can conquer the planet Earth in nine minutes, can't handle that same bunch of flying troglodytes in combat?

Why was most of the movie shot at a weird angle?

A visiting Psychlo complains about Earth's gravity as being 'different'. Since we're to understand this race makes frequent visits to other planets, why haven't they gotten used to the concept that planets with a different mass will have a different gravitational force?

Despite living on Earth for a thousand years, and actually capturing and feeding humans daily. Psyclos have no clue what humans like to eat.

What bet did Forest Whitaker lose that resulted in his appearance in this film?

Did anyone involved in the production of this horrible film actually read the source material? Because the book is actually very good.

Battlefield Earth is one of the most baffling bad movies ever made, and that's saying a lot. Especially coming from me, as I see a lot of these bad movies. I'm not trying to sound like an expert or anything, but just stating the facts. While terrible, it's also one of the funnier bad movies out there. Everything about it just feels wrong and disjointed, in every possible way. From the overuse AND unnecessary use of dutch angles to John Travolta's laughingly-bad performance to Barry Pepper's grunting and groaning - it's all terrible, but it's all entertaining in a so bad that it's good kind of way. It's no wonder that the crew from Rifftrax riffed on this one. It certainly deserves their kind of treatment. I'd say that I'd watch this again, if only for the entertainment value I get out of it, but I have to rate it accordingly. A lot of work went into making it, especially the sets and the costumes, but you can't deny how terrible the finished product is. This is a legendary stinker, of the highest caliber.

The visionary science-fiction classic Battlefield Earth: A Saga of the Year 3000 is a thrilling epic from prolific novelist L. Ron Hubbard.  In the year 3000 Earth has been conquered by a race of aliens called Psychlos who are strip mining the planet for its resources, but when they try to replace their workforce with humans, the humans rebel and attempt to take back the planet.  John Travolta, Forest Whitaker, and Barry Pepper lead the cast and give solid performances; Travolta in particular is especially charismatic as an over-the-top villain.  However, the special effects are pretty bad, as the CGI and green screen effects are quite noticeable.  While there are some glaring script and production problems, Battlefield Earth: A Saga of the Year 3000 is a fun and entertaining sci-fi adventure.

Now this film wanted to be epic, it really tried, Travolta put millions of his own fortune into it and pushed people into helping him create it. These type of catastrophic alien invasion films were all the rage around this time after the success of 'Independence Day'. The films title alone sounds epic, a thundering statement...BATTLEFIELD EARTH!, it sounds like the ultimate sci-fi action film, so what's wrong with it?.

First and foremost it looks like, and for all intense and purposes, is an extended 'Star Trek' episode. The plot is very dull and plays out like a dull episode of Star Trek, one involving lots of dialog about mining for minerals (gold, for what reason? I dunno), slave trading and general alien politics. The mistake made with the alien race (with the rather stupid name of 'Psychlos', is that the best Hubbard could come up with??) in this film is that they are dissected too much. We hear about all sorts of trivial background stuff that isn't required, in the end they just seem like large humans, there is no mystery.

On top of the really overly laboured plot is the simple fact that these aliens look crap. Putting aside the obvious 'Klingon' like appearance, they look like huge platform wearing transvestites with dreadlock-like hair in campy goth space suits. As if they belong in some fetish club or one of those freaky bizarre goth circus's.

Then there's the simple question of why Travolta's face isn't the same as the rest of the alien race? why do all of them have devil/vampire-like faces but Travolta's is normal?. Is this because Travolta didn't wanna be hidden behind makeup?. Who's decision was it to let Travolta have/keep his little goatee? that kinda detracts from the whole alien design don't you think, a humanoid goatee. And who are these really old looking alien politicians with the flabby necks? is that what 'Psychlos' look like with age? why don't they look like the other 'Psychlos' facially?.

Other minor issues spring to mind also such as the fact these guys don't feel pain, Travolta's arm gets blown off yet it doesn't really faze him. Whitaker seems to be the only black alien in the entire race. Then there's the amusing observation that most of the cast clearly can't walk too well in the stilts they are on, no running by these aliens hehe.

Then we have the human element, or what's left of them. OK so humans are almost extinct and the 'Psychlos' have been ruling them for 1000 years apparently. So why has humankind completely forgotten everything about their past? the ability to use their brains, know what basic objects like glass or weapons are, names of places etc...they have forgotten everything which makes no sense. Mankind has been enslaved by aliens but why have they gone backwards to primitive cavemen? they don't know what a city is or what stars in the sky are, they worships Gods like ancient humans once did and they all scream and yelp like monkeys. But they still wear trousers.

The plot totally loses it once the rebellion begins, the last humans led by Pepper conveniently find apparent secret military bases still stocked to the gills with weapons, Harrier jets and power it seems. Little bit of training and many of them are now proficient in guns and even better...can fly Harrier Jump jets no probs!! just like that. So much so that they are able to engage alien ships in a fancy ass dogfight.

There really are so many plot holes and question marks I can't possibly mention them all or remember them all!. I do recall the effects being somewhat bigged up at the time, they were suppose to be pretty neat for the day. I guess they aren't too bad to be honest, some shots look nice, mainly ruined cityscape's, the alien ships are a reasonable design as is some of the ship flight sequences. Sets are pretty bland and uninspired, just faceless metallic facilities whilst the whole film has this quite ugly blue/grey/green tint/hue to it which is unusual.

So for a film called 'battlefield earth' there actually isn't that much in the realms of mega earthbound conflicts going on, its all based in one location. On a certain silly level the film can be enjoyable with its action sequences, it totally jumps on the 'Independence Day' bandwagon that's for sure, but it can still be minor fun.

Had this been a few half hour episodes of a TV sci-fi series then it could be looked on more favourably. I mean the film really isn't much better than a TV show, but I must admit to liking Travolta's wickedly evil campy performance. That and the 'Psychlos' females that we get a glimpse of, a kind of fetish wearing gothic 'Cenobite' with very very long tongues, film highlight for me.
